questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding P50 in the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve.

choices.text: P50 is the Hb saturation at which partial pressure of oxygen is 50 mmHg
Affinity of Hb to oxygen increases as P50 increases
Thyroid hormones increase the value of P50
P50 decreases with increase in 2,3 DPG

questions.solution:
Thyroid hormones, growth hormones, and androgens can all increase the concentration of 2,3-DPG and hence can increase P50.

P50:

  • P50 is the partial pressure of O2 at which Hb is 50% saturated.
  • Normal value: 27 mm of Hg
  • P50 is an index of the affinity of Hb with O2
    • A rightward shift of the dissociation curve increases P50 and lowers hemoglobin’s affinity for oxygen. This displaces oxygen from hemoglobin and releases it to the tissues.
    • A leftward shift decreases P50 and increases hemoglobin’s affinity for oxygen. Hence, the availability of oxygen to the tissues decreases.

2,3 DPG:

  • 2,3-diphosphoglycerate is formed in erythrocytes during glycolysis.

                 HbO2 + 2,3 DPG ⇒ Hb-2,3 DPG + O2

  • High levels of 2,3-DPG: Rightward shift = higher P50 value.
  • Low levels of 2,3-DPG: leftward shift = lower P50 value
  • Acidosis inhibits red cell glycolysis. Therefore the 2,3-DPG concentration falls when the pH is low.

Related Pearl: Factors affecting 2,3 -DPG

↑ in 2, 3-DPG ↓ in 2, 3-DPG
  • Chronic hypoxia
  • Anemia
  • Acclimitization (high altitude)
  • Thyroid hormone
  • Growth hormone
  • Androgens
  • Exercise
  • Stored blood
  • Acidosis

questions.text: Studdiford’s criteria is used for the diagnosis of _____________
questions.solution:
Studdiford’s criteria is used for the diagnosis of primary abdominal pregnancy.

Primary abdominal pregnancy is the rarest type of ectopic gestation. The conceptus implants on the peritoneal surface of the abdomen.

Studdiford’s criteria:

  1. The presence of normal bilateral tubes and ovaries with no evidence of recent or past pregnancy.
  2. No evidence of a uteroperitoneal fistula.
  3. The presence of pregnancy, related exclusively to the peritoneal surface, early enough to eliminate the possibility of secondary implantation

Criteria used in the diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy are:

  • Cervical pregnancy: Paalman and McElin (clinical criteria); Rubin's criteria (histological criteria)
  • Ovarian pregnancy: Spiegelberg’s criteria

Although the incidence of abdominal pregnancy is only 1 in 10,000, diagnosis at the earliest is of utmost importance due to the possible complications. The classic ultrasound finding is the absence of myometrial tissue between the maternal bladder and the conceptus.

questions.text: The diagnosis of Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) requires  _____________.

choices.text: At least one primary tumor type
Two or more primary tumor types
Third degree relative with all three tumor types

questions.solution:
The diagnosis of MEN 1 is made if the patient has

  • ≥2 primary tumor types

                      OR

  • 1st degree relative with 1 tumor + clinical diagnosis of the syndrome

                     OR

  • Germline mutation in the associated gene

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

questions.text: True about hypernephroma is ___________.

choices.text: It is more common in women
It is associated with right sided varicocele in men
Hematuria is the most common presenting symptom

questions.solution:
The true statement is- Hematuria is the most common presenting symptom.

Hypernephroma / Grawitz tumor/ Adenocarcinoma of the kidney

  • It is the most common neoplasm of the kidney (75%)
  • Hematuria is the most common presentation, may be associated with clot colic
  • M: F= 4:1
  • Left-sided varicocele is seen in men because the left gonadal vein is obstructed where it joins the left renal vein.
  • CT scan is the investigation of choice.
  • Nephrectomy is the treatment of choice. It is poorly responsive to radiotherapy or chemotherapy.

Related Pearl: Histologic subtypes of renal cell carcinoma

 Clear-cell type:

  • Most common type
  • Originates from proximal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by deletion of chromosomes 3p & 6p 
  • Associated with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease and tuberous sclerosis

Papillary type:

  • Originates from proximal/distal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by c-met mutation
  • Histology shows Psammoma bodies
  • Associated with hereditary papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Micropapillary variant is associated with long term dialysis

Chromophobe type:

  • Best prognosis
  • Originates from intercalated cells of collecting duct
  • Caused by loss of multiple chromosomes (1, 2, 6, 10, 13) and extreme hypodiploidy
  • Associated with Birt-Hogg- Dubé syndrome
  • Histology shows plant-like cells/ resin like nucleus
  • Cytokeratin positive on IHC 

Collecting (Bellini duct) type:

  • Worst prognosis
  • Originates from collecting tubules
  • Caused by deletion of 1q & monosomy of multiple chromosomes

Medullary type:

  • Poor prognosis
  • Originates from distal nephron
  • Associated with sickle cell anemia

Note: Sarcomatoid change can occur infrequently in all types of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and is an ominous feature.

questions.text: The structure marked “A” in the image given below is _______.
questions.solution:
The structure marked “A” in the image given above is­­ Cooper’s ligament.

Pectineal (Astley Coopers) ligament: A strong fibrous band that extends laterally along the pectineal line from the pectineal attachment of Lacunar ligament.

Gimbernat's (Lacunar) ligament: It is a thick triangular band of tissue formed from fibers of the medial end of the inguinal ligament and fascia lata, lying posterior to it.  It forms the medial wall of the femoral canal. The apex of the triangle is attached to the pubic tubercle.

Inguinal (Poupart’s) ligament: The thick external oblique aponeurosis stretched between the anterior superior iliac spine and pubic tubercle.

questions.text: The most common cause of otitis externa is ____________.
questions.solution:
Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common cause of otitis externa.

Otitis externa is a severe infection of the external auditory canal.

Symptoms include severe otalgia, otorrhoea and fever.

Treatment involves topical antibiotics and/or 2-percent acetic acid and steroid drops in addition to canal debridement as often as is necessary.

If severe swelling occurs, a wick should be placed in the EAC to maintain patency and further direct topical drops.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is alirocumab approved for use?

choices.text: Cystic fibrosis patients >12 years of age

questions.solution:
Alirocumab is a PCSK9 inhibitor that is approved for use in familial hypercholesterolemia.

PCSK9 inhibitors are a new class of lipid-lowering medications that are administered as monthly or bimonthly subcutaneous injections. PCSK9 is a binding protein that is expressed in hepatocytes and on secretion, binds to the LDL receptors, and promotes their degradation. By blocking PCSK9, these drugs increase the availability of LDL receptors leading to better removal of LDL cholesterol from circulation. Another approved PCSK-9 inhibitor is evolocumab.

Other options: 

Option B: Fremanezumab and galcanezumab are anti-CGRP monoclonal antibodies approved by the FDA in 2018 for the preventive treatment of migraine in adults.

Option C: Tezacaftor/Ivacaftor is FDA approved for cystic fibrosis patients >12 years of age. It facilitates the opening of chloride channels.

Option D: Plecanatide is FDA-approved for the treatment of chronic idiopathic constipation. It activates guanylate cyclase-C on endothelial cells in the GI tract and thus draws water into the lumen, leading to stool softening.

questions.text: True about Neutrophilic extracellular Traps (NET) are all except ________.
questions.solution:
Neutrophilic nuclei are lost in Neutrophilic extracellular Traps (NET). Hence it is also called beneficial suicide.

Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs):

  • They are networks of extracellular fibers that provide a high concentration of antimicrobial substances at the site of infection and prevent the spread of the microbes by trapping them in the fibrils.
    • Infectious pathogens: Mainly bacteria and fungi
    • Inflammatory mediators: Chemokines, cytokines (mainly interferons), complement proteins, and ROS
  • During the production of the NETs the nuclei of the neutrophils are lost leading to the death of neutrophils.
  • The extracellular traps consists of a viscous meshwork of nuclear chromatin. These bind and concentrate granule proteins such as antimicrobial peptides and enzymes. It includes antimicrobial proteins such as neutrophil elastase, cathepsin G and histones that have a high affinity for DNA.
  • NETs have been detected in the blood during sepsis. Their formation in the circulation is dependent on platelet activation.
  • The nuclear chromatin in the NETs, which includes histones and associated DNA, has been postulated to be a source of nuclear antigens in systemic autoimmune diseases, particularly lupus.

questions.text: A patient presents with seizures, severe abdominal pain, and dark-colored urine. She has a previous history of repeated hospital admission for similar complaints. A diagnosis of acute intermittent porphyria was made after a detailed workup. Which of the following drugs is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
The administration of barbiturates is contraindicated in acute intermittent porphyria.

Acute intermittent porphyria is a disorder of heme synthesis, characterized by a deficiency of hydroxymethylbilane synthase (HMBS).

Barbiturates are enzyme inducers and they result in the increased synthesis of porphyrins and subsequent precipitation of acute intermittent porphyria. The biochemical basis for the worsening of porphyria by barbiturates is the de-repression/induction of ALA synthase.

Barbiturates are metabolized by microsomal CYP450, a heme-protein oxidase system found in the liver. In patients with porphyria, barbiturates precipitate an attack of porphyria by the following mechanism:

 Barbiturates increase the synthesis of CYP450
 ↓
Enhanced consumption of heme
↓
A decrease in heme concentration in the liver 
↓
De-repression/induction of ALAS-1
↓
Increased synthesis of heme precursors
↓
Precipitation of porphyria


Other options:

Theophylline, chlorpromazine, and benzodiazepine are not contraindicated in acute intermittent porphyria.

Related Pearl: Drugs precipitating porphyria: "BOOST CHAP"

The mnemonic "BOOST CHAP" can be used to remember the drugs precipitating porphyria.

B: Barbiturates

O: OCPs

O: Orphenadrine

S: Sulphonamides

T: Tetracyclines

C: Chloramphenicol, carbamazepine

H: Halothane, Hydralazine

A: Alcohol

P: Phenytoin

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

Most porphyrias are autosomal dominant except:
  • ALAD enzyme deficiency porphyria
  • Congenital erythropoietic porphyria
  • Erythropoietic protoporphyria

questions.text: Palliative surgery is the best option in ___________.
questions.solution:
Palliative surgery is the best option in tricuspid atresia.

Tricuspid Atresia itself cannot be repaired by surgery. The treatment goal is to de-load the usually hypoplastic ventricle, bypass the right heart and allow separation of the pulmonary and systemic circulations. The repair is multi-step and is called the Fontan repair. This consists of a

  1. Right pulmonary artery-to-superior vena cava anastomosis (Glenn repair),
  2. ASD closure
  3. Direct connection of the right atrium to the proximal end of the left pulmonary artery using an aortic homograft.

ASD and PDA can both be repaired and VSD may spontaneously close or can be closed with surgery.

questions.text: Pseudo Meig’s syndrome is seen in all except __________.
questions.solution:
Pseudo Meig’s syndrome is seen in all except Ovarian fibroma.

Ovarian fibroma was originally described in the triad of True Meigs syndrome. Other conditions are seen in Pseudo Meigs’ syndrome.

Note:

  • Meigs syndrome consists of ascites and Right sided pleural effusions that accompany a benign ovarian fibroma.
  • Pseudo-Meigs syndrome consists of pleural effusion, ascites, and benign tumors of the ovary other than fibromas (E.g. Thecoma, Granulosa cell tumor, Brenner tumor) and Leiomyomas.
  • Pseudo-pseudo Meigs’ syndrome is a rare manifestation of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), defined by the presence of ascites, pleural effusions and an elevated CA-125 level.

questions.text: The only abductor of the larynx is innervated by ____________

choices.text: External branch of superior laryngeal nerve
Internal branch of superior laryngeal nerve

questions.solution:
The only abductor of the larynx is the posterior cricoarytenoid. It is innervated by recurrent laryngeal nerve.

Motor supply:

  • All intrinsic muscles of the larynx except cricothyroid are innervated by the recurrent laryngeal nerve.
  • Cricothyroid is innervated by the external branch of superior laryngeal nerve.

Sensory supply:

  • Above the level of vocal folds - Internal laryngeal nerve (Internal branch of superior laryngeal nerve)
  • Below the level of vocal folds - Inferior laryngeal nerve (terminal branch of the recurrent laryngeal nerve)

Related Pearl: Muscles of larynx

Remember 2 exceptions:

  • All muscles are adductors, except PCA (an abductor)
  • All muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, except cricothyroid (superior laryngeal nerve)
Action
Muscle
Opening of the inlet of larynx
Thyroepiglotticus
Closing of the inlet of larynx
Aryepiglotticus, Interarytenoids
Abductor of vocal cords
Posterior cricoarytenoid
Adductor of vocal cords
Lateral cricoarytenoid
Tensor of vocal cords
Cricothyroid
Relaxer of vocal cord
Thyroarytenoid
Modulator of larynx
Vocalis

Safety muscle of larynx: Posterior cricoarytenoid

Safety muscle of tongue: Genioglossus

The muscle of whispering: Lateral cricoarytenoid

Vocalis is known as the modulator of larynx because, the anterior part of the vocalis muscle can tense the vocal cord, and its posterior part can relax the vocal cord.

questions.text: Non-professional antigen presenting cells (APCs) are all except_________
questions.solution:
Immature dendritic cells are not non-Professional antigen presenting cells (APCs), they are an example of a professional APC.

Professional APCs: Express MHC class II

  • Dendritic cells (mature and immature)
  • Macrophage
  • B- cells

Non-professional APCs: Do not express MHC class II while interacting with T cells. They must be induced to express class II MHC molecules and a costimulatory signal, only under certain conditions.

  • Glial cells
  • Fibroblasts
  • Thyroid epithelial cells
  • Endothelial cells
  • Beta cells of pancreas

questions.text: Which of the following is not resected in stapedotomy?
questions.solution:
Lenticular process of incus is not resected in stapedotomy.

Stapedotomy is the treatment of choice for otosclerosis with stapes fixation.

Resecting the stapedius tendon (which connects the neck of stapes to the posterior wall of the tympanic cavity) frees the stapes from its middle ear connections. The stapes superstructure is then freed from the base/ footplate by fracturing both the anterior and posterior crura of the stapes. A fenestration is made in the footplate of the stapes and a prosthesis is placed that articulates with the incus.

questions.text: Preganglionic fibers originating from the inferior salivatory nucleus will pass through ______.
questions.solution:
Preganglionic fibers originating from the inferior salivatory nucleus will pass through otic ganglion.

The preganglionic fibers of otic ganglion originate in the inferior salivatory nucleus and join the glossopharyngeal nerve and its tympanic branch. They travel via the tympanic plexus, lesser petrosal nerve, and pass through the foramen ovale and synapse in the otic ganglion. Postganglionic fibers give communicating branches to the auriculotemporal nerve, which supplies to the parotid gland. When the lesser petrosal nerve is stimulated, it produces vasodilator and secretomotor effects.


Other options:

Option A: Preganglionic fibers originating from the Edinger–Westphal nucleus will pass through the ciliary ganglion.

Option C and D: Preganglionic fibers originating from the superior salivatory nucleus will pass through the pterygopalatine ganglion and submandibular ganglion.

questions.text: The image below shows the logo of which of the following national programmes?
questions.solution:
The image shown is the new logo of the 360-degree holistic Family Planning Campaign.

Logo of other options:

"Beti bachao Beti padhao."

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in Zellweger spectrum disorders?
questions.solution:
Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS) is not included in Zellweger spectrum disorder.

Zellweger spectrum disorders are Peroxisomal Biogenesis Disorders. It includes

a) Zellweger syndrome (also known as Cerebrohepatorenal syndrome) - most severe form

b) Neonatal adrenoleukodystrophy (NALD)

c) Infantile Refsum disease - least severe form

 

 

Zellweger syndrome:

  • Caused by mutations in PEX family of genes -also called as peroxins involved in Peroxisome Biogenesis /Peroxisomal enzymes themselves 
  • Biochemical findings :
    • Accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids
    • abnormalities of the synthesis of bile acids
    • marked reduction of plasmalogens

questions.text: C4b2a acts as a C3 convertase enzyme in which of the following complement pathways?
questions.solution:
• C3 convertase (activates C3) in classical and lectin pathway is C4b2a.
  • C3 convertase in the alternate pathway is C3bBb.

questions.text: All of the following are examples of hyaline cartilage except __________.
questions.solution:
Epiglottis is not an example of hyaline cartilage, it is fibroelastic.

questions.text: A girl baby can stand without support. The highest fine motor skill she is expected to have is ___________.
questions.solution:
A baby that stands without support is most likely to be 12 months. The highest fine motor skill she is expected to have is mature pincer grasp (12 months).

Bidextrous reach is seen at 4 months and unidextrous reach at 6 months. Immature pincer grasp is seen at 9 months.

Related Pearl: Gross motor milestones

questions.text: The next step in a 28-year-old woman with Atypical squamous cells of unknown significance (ASC-US) on Pap smear is ____________.
questions.solution:
HPV DNA testing is indicated in women >25 years showing ASC-US on pap smear.

ASC-US is the most common cytologic abnormality on Pap smear. Cells that suggest SIL but do not fulfill all the criteria are termed ASC-US.

Management of ASCUS in a woman older than 25 years:

HPV testing- If it is positive, colposcopy. If it is negative, repeat pap smear and HPV test in 3 years.

questions.text: The obstetric ultrasound finding of a twin peak sign is seen in:
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Dichorionic diamniotic twins.

The twin peak sign (also known as the lambda (λ) sign) is a triangular appearance of the chorion insinuating between the layers of the inter twin membrane. It is seen in dichorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy. It is best seen in the first trimester (between 10-14 weeks).

The T sign is formed at the point at which the amnions meet the placenta. Twins are separated only by a membrane created by the juxtaposed amnion of each twin. Sonographic image of the “T” sign in a monochorionic diamniotic gestation at 30 weeks.

Related Pearl: Important radiological signs in OBG

Sign
Significance
Bagel sign
Gestational sac in the adnexa with a hyperechoic ring.
USG sign in tubal ectopic.
Ball Sign
X-ray shows a crumpled up spine of the fetus.
Radiological sign of intrauterine fetal death.
Banana Sign
Abnormal anterior curvature of the cerebellum due to the associated Arnold-Chiari malformation.
USG sign in open spina bifida.
Double decidual sac Sign
Two concentric echogenic rings separated by a hyperechoic space.
Normal USG appearance of an intrauterine gestational sac.
Lambda Sign
The chorionic tissue in between the two layers of the membrane between the twins.
USG sign seen in di-chorionic pregnancies.
‘T’ Sign
USG sign seen in monochorionic twins. As the intertwin membrane does not have any chorionic tissue it gives rise to ‘T’ sign in ultrasound.
Bunch of grapes sign
USG appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.
Butterfly sign
Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.
Cloverleaf skull
Seen in craniosynostosis
Empty amnion sign
Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: Which type of Superoxide Dismutase  is found in Mitochondria ?
questions.solution:
Mn-SOD is found in Mitochondria

Superoxide dismutase (SOD) has 3 major families based on Co-factor

Type of SOD Site
Cu/Zn type (which binds both copper and zinc)  Cytosol
Fe and Mn types (which bind either iron or manganese),  Mitochondria
Ni type (which binds nickel).    

Superoxide dismutases (SODs) catalyze the de-activation of superoxide. Any superoxide from the phagosomes that enters the cytosol,is converted to H2O2 by superoxide dismutase. SOD protects aerobic organisms from oxygen toxicity.

questions.text: False positive low APGAR score is seen in all except __________.
questions.solution:
False positive low APGAR score is seen in all of the above except Maternal acidosis.

Maternal acidosis is associated with fetal acidosis and a normal APGAR score i.e. False-negative APGAR.

False positive low Apgar scores i.e no fetal acidosis but low Apgar score is seen in:

  • Prematurity
  • Drugs - analgesics, narcotics, sedatives, magnesium sulphate
  • Acute cerebral edema
  • Spinal cord trauma
  • Diaphragmatic hernia
  • Choanal atresia
  • Congenital pneumonia and sepsis
  • Congenital myopathy/neuropathy
  • Hemorrhage / hypovolemia
  • Precipitous delivery

False-negative APGAR i.e. Normal Apgar score with fetal acidosis is seen in:

  • Maternal acidosis
  • High fetal catecholamine levels
  • Some full-term infants

questions.solution:
Linezolid is an example of a bacteriostatic drug.

questions.text: Bony nasal septal perforation occurs in __________.
questions.solution:
Syphilis causes bony nasal septal perforation.

Chronic granulomatous conditions like sarcoidosis and leprosy cause perforation in the cartilaginous part.

questions.text: Which of the following is the major contributor to demographic burden?
questions.solution:
Demographic burden refers to an increase in the total dependency ratio. It is mostly caused by an increased old-age dependency ratio.

The term demographic bonus denotes the decline in dependency ratio due to declining fertility. A decline in dependency ratio especially the young-age dependency ratio has been identified to be a key factor in the underlying rapid economic development.

The potential support ratio is the number of persons aged 15 to 64 per one older person aged 65 or more. This is the inverse of the old-age dependency ratio.

questions.text: Which is not a risk factor for non-traumatic osteonecrosis?
questions.solution:
Gout is not a risk factor for non-traumatic osteonecrosis.

Causes of non-traumatic osteonecrosis

  • Infections
    • Osteomyelitis
    • Septic Arthritis
  • Haemoglobinopathy
    • Sickle-cell disease
  • Storage disorders
    • Gaucher's Disease
    • Caisson disease
    • Dysbaric Osteonecrosis
  • Coagulation disorders
    • Familial thrombophilia
    • Hypofibrinolysis
    • Hyperlipoproteinemia
    • Thrombocytopenic purpura

Other

  • Perthes’ disease
  • Cortisone administration
  • Alcohol abuse
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Pregnancy
  • Anaphylactic shock
  • Ionizing radiation

questions.text: False about suicide is ______.

choices.text: Men commit suicide more often than women
Parasuicide is self-mutilation without intent to die
Suicide survivor is someone who has attempted suicide and lived
Paradoxical suicide is increased risk of suicide in patients recovering from depression

questions.solution:
The false statement is- suicide survivor is someone who has attempted suicide and lived.

Suicide survivor refers to those who have lost a loved one to suicide. They have increased risk of guilt and depression. They feel if only they had done something differently, the decedent would still be here. There are mutual support groups for suicide survivors.

Para suicide is used to describe patients who injure themselves by self-mutilation (e.g., cutting the skin) but who do not wish to die.

Men commit suicide more often than women. However, women attempt suicide more often than men.

Paradoxical suicide is increased risk of suicide in patients recovering from depression. As the depression lifts, patients become energized and are able to put their suicidal plans into action.

questions.text: 50,000 students have taken Marrow Grand test. Their mean score was found to be 300 marks & 1 S.D. = 20 marks. How many students have scored above 340?
questions.solution:
1250 students have scored above 340.

Mean = 300

1.S.D.= 20

We know, Mean ± 2 S.D covers 95 % of students

I.e. 300 ± (2 x 20) = 260 to 340 marks is scored by 95% of students

Of the remaining 5%,  2.5% students scored below 260

2.5% students scored above 340 i.e.  2.5 × 50000/100 = 1250

1250 students scored above 340

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text: Diatomaceous earth filter is a type of ________.
questions.solution:
Diatomaceous earth filter is a type of Candle filter.

Types of filters:

  • Candle filters:
    • Have different grades of porosity
    • 2 types: unglazed ceramic filter and diatomaceous earth filter
  • Sintered glass filter:
    • Prepared by heat fusing finely powdered glass
    • Low absorptive property
  • Membrane filter:
    • Made up of cellulose esters or other polymers
    • Average pore diameter of 0.22 цm is most commonly used
  • Asbestos filter: Obsolete due to carcinogenic property

questions.text:
Which of the following indicators are used in Waterlow’s classification?
  1. Weight for age
  2. Height for age
  3. Weight for height
  4. BMI for age
  5. Head circumference for age
questions.solution:
Waterlow’s classification makes use of height for age (HFA) and weight for height (WFH) to assess the nutritional status of children.

HFA indicates stunting and denotes the chronicity of malnutrition. On the other hand, WFH indicates wasting and denotes the severity of malnutrition.

The Gomez classification uses weight for age as an indicator of nutritional status. The disadvantage is that it is difficult to determine whether the low weight is due to an acute attack of malnutrition or chronic undernutrition.

questions.text: What is the infant mortality rate in India as per the SRS Statistical Report (2020)?
questions.solution:
The infant mortality rate (IMR) in India as per the SRS statistical report (2020) is 28 per 1000 live births. 

IMR is defined as the number of infant deaths for every 1000 live births. As per the National Family Health Survey - 5 (2019-2021), the IMR is 35.2 per 1000 live births.

IMR is considered the best indicator of the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of health care.

Related Pearl: Demographic Aspects of India

UN Data (2021)

  • India’s population was 1,393,409,000 (1.39 Billion) 
  • In 2021, India ranked 2nd in the list of countries with the highest population
  • Almost 34.5% of India’s population is urban
  • The population growth rate was 1%

SRS Statistical Report (2020)

Vital statistics according to the Sample Registration System data released by the Registrar General of India:

  • Infant mortality rate (IMR) in India - 28 per 1000 live births
  • The crude birth rate (CBR) - 19.5
  • The crude death rate (CDR) was 6.0

questions.text: The first step in the management of a hemodynamically stable patient with the ECG rhythm strip showing ventricular tachycardia is ________.
questions.solution:
Intravenous Amiodarone is the first step in the management of a hemodynamically stable patient with a rhythm strip showing ventricular tachycardia.

 

Intravenous amiodarone is recommended by the AHA/ACC 2015 guidelines for treatment of hemodynamically stable ventricular tachycardia.

Chest compressions are the first step in unresponsive patient without a pulse.

Synchronized cardioversion is the treatment of choice for hemodynamically unstable patients (hypotension, respiratory distress, altered sensorium) with ventricular tachycardia.

questions.text: An 11-year-old anemic boy has a total leucocyte count of 1,38,000 per cu.mmm with 80% blasts on the peripheral smear. Chest X-ray demonstrated a large mediastinal mass. Bone marrow aspirate is as seen below. All of the following statements are true about this condition except ______.

choices.text: Ataxia telangiectasia is a risk factor

questions.solution:
Diffuse PAS positivity on PAS staining is a false statement. It shows block like or dot like PAS positivity.

There is increased leucocyte count with 80% blasts. The age group and presence of a mediastinal mass indicate acute lymphoblastic leukemia with immature T cell phenotype (Tdt/D34/CD7 positive).

ALL:

  • Usually seen in adolescent boys with thymic involvement
  • Mediastinal thymic masses occur in 50% to 70% of T-ALLs, which are also more likely to be associated with lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly.
  • C/F:
    • Abrupt stormy onset within days to a few weeks of the first symptoms
    • Symptoms related to depression of marrow function including anemia, fever, infections, bleeding
    • Mass effects caused by neoplastic infiltration
    • Bone pain resulting from marrow expansion and infiltration of the subperiosteum
    • Generalized lymphadenopathy Splenomegaly, and hepatomegaly
    • Testicular enlargement
    • Central nervous system manifestations such as headache, vomiting, and nerve palsies
    • B cell ALL: Pancytopenia due to marrow involvement
    • T-ALL: Mediastinal mass, lymphadenopathy, compression of large vessels and airways in the mediastinum
  • Ataxia telangiectasia predisposes to ALL
  • T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma (T-ALL) is characterized by aberrant activation of NOTCH1 in over 60% of T-ALL cases

Related Pearl: Prognostic Factors in Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL)

Age younger than 2 years

Female  Male

 t (12;21)  MLL gene rearrangements 
Early precursor B cell phenotype  T cell phenotype

questions.text: Which of the following is a branch of thyrocervical trunk?
questions.solution:
Suprascapular artery is a branch of thyrocervical trunk.

Thyrocervical trunk arises from the front of the first part of the subclavian artery near the medial border of scalenus anterior.

Branches:

  • Inferior thyroid artery
  • Suprascapular artery
  • Superficial cervical artery
  • Transverse cervical artery is seen, which may give rise to superficial cervical artery and dorsal scapular artery. About 1/3rd of superficial cervical and dorsal scapular arteries arise in this way.

(Note: dorsal scapular artery arises from the third, or less often the second part of the subclavian artery)

Other options:

  • Superior thyroid artery - Branch of external carotid artery
  • Deep cervical artery - Branch of costocervical trunk
  • Internal thoracic artery - Branch of subclavian artery (first part)

questions.text: Ploucquet's test is based on the principle of _____?

choices.text: Gelatinous substance in the middle ear is replaced by air after birth.
Ratio of weight of the lungs to the whole body weight is doubled after respiration.
Weight of the lungs gets halved with establishment of respiration.
Specific gravity of lungs decreases with respiration.

questions.solution:
Ploucquet’s test is based on ratio of Weight of lungs to whole body weight.

Before respiration 1/70 of body weight
After respiration 1/35 of body weight

Note :

  • Wredin’s test:
    • changes in the middle ear (gelatinous substance in the middle ear is replaced by air)
  • Fodere’s test:  Weight of lungs gets doubled with respiration
Before respiration 30-35g
After respiration 60-70g
  • Hydrostatic test/ Floatation test/Breslau’s first life test/ Raygat’s test.
    • If the lung pieces float in water, it means that respiration took place, indicating a live birth.(Reason : with respiration specific gravity of lungs becomes less than that of water making it to float )
  • Breslau’s second life test/ Stomach bowel test:
    • organs are placed in water to see if they sink or float
    • floating viscera giving out air bubbles when opened under water is a positive test and suggestive of live birth

questions.text: A patient with hemoptysis and renal failure has a renal biopsy which reveals crescentic proliferative glomerulonephritis. Immunofluorescence micrograph shows smooth, diffuse, linear IgG and C3 and fibrin in crescents. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Immunofluorescence micrograph features are suggestive of Goodpasture syndrome which shows smooth, diffuse, linear IgG and C3; fibrin in crescents.

Goodpasture syndrome: Anti- GBM antibody-mediated disease, characterized by linear deposits of IgG and C3 in the GBM. The antigen common to the alveoli and GBM is a peptide within the noncollagenous portion of the α3 chain of collagen type IV.

IgA nephropathy: IF - mesangial deposition of IgA often with C3 and properdin and lesser amounts of IgG or IgM.

Membranous nephropathy: Characteristic granular immunofluorescent deposits of IgG along the glomerular basement membrane.

FSGS: Immunofluorescence- C3 and IgM deposits in the sclerotic areas and the mesangium.

questions.text: Masked hypertension is defines as ___________.

choices.text: Office BP = 120-129/<80 mm Hg and Home BP >130/80 mm Hg
Office BP <120/<80 and mm Hg and Home BP > 140/90 mm Hg
Office BP = 130-160/80-100 mm Hg and Home BP < 130/80 mm Hg
Office BP >140/>90 mm Hg and Home BP <120/<80 mm Hg

questions.solution:
The latest AHA/ACC 2017 guidelines defines Masked hypertension in patients not on drug therapy as Office BP = 120-129/<80 mm Hg and Home BP >130/80 mm Hg.

White coat hypertension is defined as Office BP = 130-160/80-100 mm Hg and Home BP < 130/80 mm Hg.

questions.text: The first step in the evaluation of abnormal uterine bleeding is __________.
questions.solution:
The first step in the evaluation of abnormal uterine bleeding is to rule out pregnancy by serum (or urine) β-hCG test.

After pregnancy is ruled out, CBC, TSH, prolactin and coagulation tests are done.

After pregnancy has been excluded, endometrial sampling should be performed in women with AUB and an increased risk of endometrial hyperplasia or cancer.

Transvaginal ultrasound and endometrial biopsy are indicated after laboratory tests if severe acute bleeding persists or there is high risk of endometrial carcinoma.

questions.text: Appropriate statistical test to be applied for the following table is  _________.
questions.solution:
Fisher exact test is the appropriate test to be applied for this table.

As one of the variables in the table is less than 5, Fisher exact test is used instead of Chi-square test in testing the significance of the association.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: The test with highest sensitivity for detecting conductive hearing loss is __________.
questions.solution:
256 Hz Rinne test has the highest sensitivity for detecting conductive hearing loss.

The 256-Hz Rinne tuning fork test will detect a conductive deafness above 30 dB in 90 % of patients. The sensitivity and specificity of Weber’s test and Bing test is only slightly better than chance.

Note: 

Though many clinicians use a 516-Hz tuning fork for Rinnes test, the 256-Hz fork give superior sensitivies and specificities. The 256-Hz Rinnes tuning fork test will detect a conductive deafness above 30 dB in 90 percent of patients. Between 20 and 30 dB, the sensitivity will fall to 70 percent and between 10 and 20 dB will be less than 50 percent.

 

Sensitivity and specificity for conductive hearing loss

  • Rinne test > Weber test > Bing test
  • 256 Hz tuning fork > 512 tuning fork

questions.text: Nerve passing through both greater sciatic foramen and lesser sciatic foramen is__________.
questions.solution:
Nerve to obturator internus passes through both greater sciatic foramen and lesser sciatic foramen.

Nerve to obturator internus, pudendal nerve and internal pudendal vessels are the structures in greater sciatic foramen which after a short course in the gluteal region, enter the lesser sciatic foramen.

Related Pearl: Structures Passing Through the Sciatic Foramens

Structures passing through the greater sciatic foramen

The piriformis is the key muscle of this region. It emerges from the pelvis, and fills the foramen almost completely.

Structures passing above the piriformis

  • Superior gluteal nerve
  • Superior gluteal vessels

Structures passing below the piriformis

  • Inferior gluteal nerve         
  • Inferior gluteal vessels
  • Sciatic nerve                                              
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of thigh
  • Nerve to quadratus femoris                  
  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels                                  
  • Nerve to obturator internus

Note: The last three structures, after a short course in the gluteal region, enter the lesser sciatic foramen, where the pudendal nerve and internal pudendal vessels run in the pudendal canal.

Structures passing through the lesser sciatic foramen

  • Tendon of obturator internus
  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels
  • Nerve to obturator internus

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be continued on the day of surgery?
questions.solution:
It is recommended to discontinue NSAIDs (Diclofenac), Angiotensin receptor blockers (Losartan) and oral hypoglycemic agents (Metformin) on the day of surgery.

Related Pearl: Drugs that should be discontinued prior to surgery

Drugs that should be discontinued prior to surgery:

Drug Duration before discontinuation

Topical medications

 Discontinue on the day of surgery

Diuretics (except thiazides) 

Discontinue on the day of surgery

Oral hypoglycemic agents (except SGLT-2 inhibitors)

Discontinue on the day of surgery

SGLT-2 inhibitors

Discontinue 24 hours before elective surgery and 72 hours before intermediate to high risk surgery

Sildenafil 

Discontinue 24 hours before the day of surgery

NSAIDs 

 Discontinue 48 hours before the day of surgery

Warfarin 

Discontinue 4 days before surgery (except for patients having cataract surgery without a bulbar block)

Short-acting Insulins 

 Discontinued (except when given by a continuous pump)

Thienopyridines (e.g., clopidogrel, ticlopidine) 

 Discontinued (Except in cataract surgery, patients with metallic/drug-eluting stents)

Aspirin 

 Discontinued 3 days before the surgery (except in patients with prior PCI, coronary artery disease and stroke)

MAO Inhibitors

 Discontinued 2 weeks prior

questions.text: A screening test was carried out among 114 people out of which 15 have a disease. The test showed 22 people tested positive for the disease among which 14 actually had the disease. What is the sensitivity of the test?
questions.solution:
The sensitivity of the above screening test is 93%.

The given data is represented below

 

Disease +

Disease -

Total

Test +

14(TP)

8(FP)

22

Test -

1(FN)

91(TN)

92

Total

15(TP+FN)

99(FP+TN)

114

TP- true positive, FP- false positive, FN- false negative, TN- true negative

Sensitivity is given as TP/(TP + FN) x 100 = 14/15 = 93%.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: An elderly patient was brought to the emergency room with a severe headache. On examination, his blood pressure was 180/100 mmHg. CT scan of the brain showed bleeding in the globus pallidus. Which of the following will be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Slow writhing movement involving distal joints
Unilateral violent movement of large proximal joints
Semi purposeful, rapid jerky movements of proximal muscles and face
Spasmodic jerky contraction of groups of muscles

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of intracerebral bleed into globus pallidus secondary to hypertension. This results in damage to the globus pallidus resulting in athetosis, which is described as slow writhing movement involving distal joints.

The most common site of hypertensive bleed in the brain is basal ganglia and putamen. Patients typically present with severe headache. The most common cause of intracerebral hemorrhages is hypertension.

Following are the usual locations of ICH: 

  •   Basal ganglia hemorrhage (especially the putamen)
  •   Thalamic hemorrhage
  •   Pontine hemorrhage
  •   Cerebellar hemorrhage 

The investigation of choice in stroke is non-contrast CT.

The following image shows bleeding in the basal ganglia on a non-contrast CT brain:

  • Stroke

questions.text: The most common pattern of renal involvement in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is:
questions.solution:
Class IV lupus nephitis is the most frequent pattern of renal involvement in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

Lupus nephritis is one of the common serious complications seen in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). It occurs due to the deposition of circulating immune complexes of DNA and anti-DNA. This further activate the complement cascade and lead to complement-mediated damage.

Most common finding is proteinuria. Other features include hematuria, hypertension, varying degrees of renal failure. 

Laboratory findings include presence of anti-dsDNA antibodies and reduced complement levels. Red blood cell casts can be present on examination of urine sediment.

It is classified into 6 subtypes (classes) based on histological findings of the biopsy specimen taken from affected kidney. The most common histologic pattern is Class IV with diffuse lesions involving > 50% of all glomeruli.

Treatment is based on the histologic subtype of lupus nephritis:

  • Class I and II - lesions are limited to the renal mesangium. They need no therapy and have an excellent prognosis
  • Class III - characterized by focal nephritis. Mild proliferation involving a small percentage of glomeruli respond well to steroids.
  • Class IV - characterized by diffuse nephritis 
    • Initial therapy - high dose steroids, cyclophosphamide or mycophenolate 
    • Maintainance therapy - low dose steroids, mycophenolate or azathioprine
  • Renal failure due to lupus - renal transplantation is recommended after 6 months of disease inactivity

Related Pearl: Classification of Lupus Nephritis (International Society of Nephrology and Renal Pathology Society)

Class 

Findings

Minimal mesangial lupus nephritis (class I)

Immune complex deposition in the mesangium without structural changes by light microscopy.

Mesangial proliferative lupus nephritis (class II)

Mesangial cell proliferation with mesangial immune deposits

Focal lupus nephritis (class III)

Focal, segmental glomerulonephritis involving less than 50% of all glomeruli.

Focal subendothelial deposits with or without mesangial changes

Diffuse lupus nephritis (class IV)

The most common and severe form of lupus nephritis

Diffuse glomerulonephritis involving more than 50% of all glomeruli

Diffuse subendothelial deposits with or without mesangial changes. “Wire loop” structures on light microscopy.

Membranous lupus nephritis (class V)

Global or segmental subepithelial immune deposits with or without mesangial proliferation

Advanced sclerosing lupus nephritis (class VI)

Sclerosis of more than 90% of the glomeruli 
  • Focal- Involves only a few glomeruli
  • Diffuse- Involves almost all the glomeruli
  • Segmental- Involves only a part of glomerulus
  • Global- Involves entire glomerulus

questions.text: Identify the correct statement.

choices.text: Deep perineal pouch contains the root of penis
Superficial perineal pouch contains pudendal vessels

questions.solution:
Superficial perineal pouch contains pudendal vessels.

The root of penis (Which consists of two crus and one bulb) is the content of the superficial perineal pouch.

Contents of Superficial perineal pouch:

  • Muscles: corpora cavernosa and corpus spongiosum, ischiocavernosus, bulbospongiosus and superﬁcial transverse perineal muscles
  • Vessels and Nerves: branches of the pudendal vessels and nerves
  • In the female, it is crossed by the urethra and vagina and contains the clitoris
  • In the male, it contains the urethra as it runs in the root of the penis

Contents of deep perineal pouch:

  • Membranous urethra
  • Muscles: Sphincter urethrae and deep transverse perinei muscles
  • Nerves: Dorsal nerve of penis and muscular branches of the perineal nerve
  • Vessels: Artery of penis
  • Glands: Bulbourethral glands in males

 

 

In the image given below, Deep perineal pouch is between the "superior layer" and "inferior layer" labeled at bottom left.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an absolute contraindication for the use of recombinant tPA?
questions.solution:
Recent internal bleeding is not an absolute contraindication for use of recombinant tPA.

Recombinant tPA is a fibrinolytic agent. Recent internal bleeding (2-4 weeks) is a relative contraindication for use of recombinant tPA.

Absolute contraindications

  • Prior intracranial hemorrhage
  • Known structural cerebral vascular lesion
  • Known malignant intracranial neoplasm
  • Ischemic stroke within 3 months
  • Suspected aortic dissection
  • Active bleeding or bleeding diathesis (excluding menses)
  • Significant closed head trauma or facial trauma within 3 months

Relative contraindications

  • Uncontrolled hypertension (SBP >180 mm Hg or DBP >110 mm Hg)
  • Traumatic or prolonged CPR or major surgery within 3 weeks
  • Recent internal bleeding (within 2-4 weeks)
  • Non-compressible vascular punctures
  • For streptokinase: prior exposure (more than 5 days ago) or prior allergic reaction to streptokinase
  • Pregnancy
  • Active peptic ulcer
  • Current use of warfarin and INR >1.7

questions.text: Which of the following signs would be seen if a lateral view of the chest is obtained in the patient whose chest X-Ray is as below?
questions.solution:
If a lateral X-ray of the chest is done in a patient with pericardial effusion, Oreo cookie sign is seen.

The chest X-ray PA view shown above has increased cardio-thoracic ratio giving the appearance of water-bottle heart. The most likely diagnosis is pericardial effusion.

On lateral radiographs of the chest, a three-layered appearance is seen with a vertical opaque line (pericardial fluid) in the center, a vertical lucent line (pericardial fat) anteriorly and a similar vertical lucent line (epicardial fat) posteriorly. This resembles an Oreo cookie.

The above image shows pericardial fluid (yellow *) outlined by epicardial fat (blue arrows) and pericardial fat (orange arrows), giving a three layered appearance, known as an Oreo cookie sign. 

Double Oreo cookie sign: Superior labral anterior posterior sign (SLAP tear) of the glenoid labrum.

Licked candy stick sign refers to tapering of the tips of the metacarpals, metatarsals, phalanges or clavicles and is associated with: psoriatic arthropathy, rheumatoid arthritis, leprosy, neuropathic joint

Pancake brain is the classical sign of alobar holoprosencephaly.

questions.text: In Pritchard regimen, maintenance dose is given only if ___________.

choices.text: Urine output <100 ml in last 4 hours

questions.solution:
In Pritchard regimen, maintenance dose is given only if Patellar reflex is brisk.

Magnesium sulfate is used for management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe pre-eclampsia. The two regimens commonly used are tabulated below.

Regimen Loading Dose Maintenance Dose
Intramuscular (Pritchard) 4 g (20% solution) IV over 3–5 min followed by 10 g (50%), deep IM (5 g in each buttock) 5 g (50%) IM 4 hourly in alternate buttock
Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai) 4–6 g IV slow over 15–20 minute 1–2 g/h IV infusion

Patients must be monitored for magnesium toxicity. Repeated IM injections of Magnesium sulfate are continued only if:

  • The patellar reflex is present
  • Respirations are not depressed
  • Urine output in the previous 4 hours exceeded 100 mL

Measurement of serum magnesium levels is indicated to monitor magnesium toxicity if serum creatinine is > 1.0 mg/dL.

Management of magnesium toxicity:

  • Stop magnesium therapy
  • Estimation of serum magnesium and creatinine levels
  • Injection of calcium gluconate 10ml (10% solution) IV

Side effects of MgSO4:

  • Anuria
  • Pulmonary edema

Mechanism of action of MgSO4:

  • It is a membrane stabilizer and a neuroprotector by reducing motor endplate sensitivity to Ach
  • It blocks neuronal Calcium influx
  • Reduced presynaptic release of the neurotransmitter glutamate
  • Blockade of glutaminergic NMDA receptors
  • Potentiation of adenosine action

Note: MgSO4 does not control hypertension

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct statement about Morgagni diaphragmatic hernia?

choices.text: Duodenum is the most common viscus involved
Located in the anterior part of the diaphragm
Due to failure of pleuroperitoneal membrane closure
Most infants with Morgagni hernia are symptomatic

questions.solution:
Morgagni's diaphragmatic hernia is usually located in the anterior part of the diaphragm.

The foramen of Morgagni is present in the anterior part of the diaphragm (a defect between the sternal and costal attachments). Morgagni diaphragmatic hernia is a type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

The most commonly involved viscus in Morgagni hernia is the transverse colon. The diagnosis of Morgagni hernia is often delayed till childhood as most infants are asymptomatic.

Herniation through the foramen of Bochdalek which is in the dome of the diaphragm posteriorly, is due to the failure of pleuroperitoneal membrane closure.

Related Pearl: Congenital diaphragmatic hernias (CDH)

It is due to the failure of the closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal in the developing fetus (Normally the pleuroperitoneal cavities separate by 8-10 weeks of gestation). Left-sided hernias are more common(80%).

The two well-recognized congenital sites where abdominal viscera can herniate into the chest are:

  • The foramen of Morgagni: a hernia in the anteromedial part of the diaphragm with a defect between the sternal and costal attachments. The most commonly involved viscus is the transverse colon.
  • The foramen of Bochdalek: through the dome of the diaphragm posterolaterally

CDH causes pulmonary hypoplasia (bilateral) by compressing the developing lung. These lungs have smaller bronchi, with less bronchial branching and less alveolar surface area than lungs in normal infants. Pulmonary hypertension may also develop due to increased thickness of arteriolar smooth muscle and also by multiple local and systemic vasoactive factors.

Clinical features:

  • respiratory distress at birth
  • grunting respiration
  • chest retractions
  • dyspnea
  • cyanosis
  • scaphoid abdomen
  • decreased breath sounds along with bowel sound over the chest with CDH
  • shifting of heart sounds to the right (for left-sided CDH)

questions.text: Identify the fungus shown in the image given below.
questions.solution:
The image above shows the fungus Cryptococcus, stained with India ink.

The India ink preparation is employed to detect the presence of Cryptococcus neoformans. Direct microscopy of the sample stained by India ink is the most rapid method for the diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis. It is seen as a globular, encapsulated yeast cell with or without budding, between 5 to 20 μm in diameter in size. Cryptococcus has a polysaccharide capsule which is seen against a black background.

Indian ink is a negative staining method that provides a uniformly colored background. The unstained organisms stand out in contrast to the background. It is useful in the demonstration of organisms with capsules that do not take simple stains. It is also used to stain slender bacteria like spirochetes.

Cryptococcus can be cultured from biologic samples like the CSF, sputum, and skin biopsy on routine fungal and bacterial culture media. Colonies are opaque, white-to-cream colored, and may turn orange-tan or brown after prolonged incubation. They have a mucoid appearance due to the presence of the capsule around the yeast cells.

questions.solution:
Upper triangular space contains scapular circumflex vessels.

Upper triangular space:

  • Boundaries:

questions.text: In a triage system, highest priority and dead patients are respectively colour coded by
questions.solution:
Highest priority patients are coded red and dead patients are coded black.

  • Triage consists of rapidly classifying the injured on the basis of the severity of their injuries and the likelihood of their survival with prompt medical intervention.
  • Triage is the only approach that can provide maximum benefit to the greatest number of injured in a major disaster situation.

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text: Which of the following uterine signs of early pregnancy are correctly matched?

choices.text: Ladin’s sign - Softening in the midpoint of the isthmus anteriorly

questions.solution:
The correctly matched sign is Ladin’s sign - Softening in the midpoint of the isthmus anteriorly

Ladin’s sign is the softening in the midpoint of the isthmus anteriorly. It can be seen in the 6th week of pregnancy.

Sign Feature Seen in

Palmer's Rhythmic uterine contraction on bimanual examination 4-8 weeks

questions.text: The change in Lineweaver-Burk plot due to the addition of a competitive inhibitor is ____________.

choices.text: Curve is shifted to the right
Curve is shifted to the left

questions.solution:
In a Lineweaver-Burk Plot, addition of a competitive inhibitor causes change in the x-intercept

Lineweaver-Burk plot is also known as the Double Reciprocal Plot.

Competitive Inhibition : when the active site or catalytic site of an enzyme is occupied by a substance other than the substrate of that enzyme,its activity is inhibited .This type of inhibition is known as Competitive inhibition.

eg: succinate dehydrogenase reaction is inhibited by malonate.

Competitive Inhibition is reversible .

In Competitive inhibition

  • Vmax remains constant
  • Km increases (MNEMONIC: In competition, we run for KILOMETRES i.e. Km; Hence remember as Km increases in Competitive inhibition).

 

Related Pearl: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Reversible inhibitors are of two types:

  • Competitive inhibitors
  • Non-Competitive inhibitors

Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Competitive inhibitors

Non-Competitive inhibitors

Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by Malonate

Pyruvate kinase is inhibited by alanine

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically similar & have same shape

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically not similar & have different shape

Inhibitor binds to active site

Inhibitor binds away from active site, i.e., at allosteric site

Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site

Inhibitor changes the shape of the active site

Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition

Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition

Vmax remains constant

Vmax decreases

Km Increases

Km remains constant

questions.text: The police authorities rescued a girl from being trafficked for sexual exploitation. She is identified to be a refugee. As a part of the Ujjawala scheme, which of the following benefits will she not receive?
questions.solution:
The girl will not receive remuneration (monetary compensation) under the Ujjawala scheme.

The Ujjawala scheme was launched to combat women and child trafficking in India. The components of the scheme include:

  • Prevention of trafficking by awareness, vigilance, education
  • Rescue of victims from the place of exploitation
  • Rehabilitation of victims
  • Re-integration of victims into their family and society
  • Repatriation of cross-border victims to their place of origin

Some other legislations associated with children in India are:

  • The Right of Children to Free and Compulsory Education Act, 2009
  • Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act, 2000
  • Child Labour (Prohibition and Regulation) Act, 1986 (amended in 2006 and 2016)
  • Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO), 2012 under the National Commission for Protection of Child Rights (NCPCR)
  • Prohibition of Child Marriage Act, 2006

questions.text: Which phase of migrating motor complex (MMC) shows irregular electrical activity?
questions.solution:
Phase 2 of migrating motor complex (MMC) shows irregular electrical activity.

Migrating motor complex:

  • It is a type of motility in the intestine that occurs during fasting between periods of digestion.
  • They are initiated by motilin.
  • These cycles (MMC) migrate from the stomach to the distal ileum at a rate of about 5 cm/min and occur at intervals of approximately 90-100 minutes.
  • They likely serve to clear the stomach and small intestine of luminal contents in preparation for the next meal.
  • Upon ingestion of a meal, secretion of motilin is suppressed and the MMC is abolished. The MMC resumes 90-120 minutes after a meal.
  • Each cycle of MMC has 3 phases
    • Phase I - Quiescent period
    • Phase II - Period of irregular electrical and mechanical activity
    • Phase III - Ends with bursts of regular activity

questions.text: The Sparsh campaign was launched to spread awareness about?
questions.solution:
Sparsh Leprosy Awareness Campaign (SLAC) was introduced in 2017 on the occasion of the anti-leprosy day (observed on the last Sunday of January) to promote awareness about various aspects of leprosy.

Sapna refers to a local school-going girl who will help to spread awareness in the community.

The other developments under NLEP are:

  • Mycobacterium Indicus Prani (MiP) vaccine for multibacillary leprosy patients and their contacts (it is in a project mode).
  • Nikusth: A web-based system for the data management of leprosy cases.

The posters below depict the role play by Sapna:

World Leprosy Eradication Day, is observed on 30th January every year, which coincides with the anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi's death. The theme for the year 2021 is “Beat Leprosy, End Stigma and advocate for Mental Wellbeing ”.

questions.text: Life expectancy minus duration of disability is _________.
questions.solution:
Disability free life expectancy is calculated as Life expectancy minus duration of disability.

  • It is the average number of years an individual is expected to live free of disability, if current pattern of mortality and disability continue to apply.
  • Calculated by

Life expectancy - duration of disability

Note:

  • It is also known as Sullivan's index/ active life expectancy
  • It doesn’t take into account premature death.

questions.text: The RDA of Calcium and Vitamin D in post-menopausal women are _____________.
questions.solution: The RDA of Calcium and Vitamin D in post-menopausal women are 1200 mg and 800 IU respectively.

questions.text: Methimazole acts by __________.

choices.text: Inhibition of deiodinase type 1 and type 2

questions.solution:
Methimazole is an anti-thyroid drug that acts by inhibition of thyroid peroxidase. It interferes with the oxidation of iodide ion and iodotyrosyl residues resulting in decreased formation of active hormones.

Mechanism of action of anti-thyroid drugs:

  • Drugs inhibiting hormone synthesis
    • Propylthiouracil
    • Methimazole
  • Drugs Inhibiting iodide trapping
    • Thiocyanates
    • Perchlorates
    • Nitrates
  • Drugs inhibiting hormone release
    • Iodine
    • Sodium iodide
    • Potassium iodide
    • Organic iodide
  • Drugs that destroy thyroid tissue
    • Radioactive iodine

Note: Iodides of sodium and potassium and Lugol's iodine act by inhibiting thyroid hormone release. Hence, they are also called thyroid constipating agents. They are the fastest acting agents.

questions.text: All of the following are Anaplerotic reactions except __________.
questions.solution:
Conversion of Pyruvate to Lactate is not an Anaplerotic reaction.

Anaplerotic reactions are those reactions which regenerate/fill up intermediates of TCA Cycle.

They include:

  • Pyruvate to Oxaloacetate
  • Pyruvate to Malate
  • Glutamate to Alpha ketoglutarate
  • Aspartate to oxaloacetate

questions.text: Which of the following paraneoplastic syndromes are not correctly matched with corresponding cancer?

choices.text: Cushing syndrome -  small cell carcinoma lung

questions.solution:
The incorrectly matched paraneoplastic syndrome and cancer are Acanthosis nigricans -  Thymoma.

All the other cancers are correctly matched to their paraneoplastic syndromes.

Acanthosis nigricans:

  • It is a disorder characterized by gray-black patches of thickened, hyperkeratotic skin with a velvety appearance.
  • In about 50% of the cases, it is associated with cancer.
  • It is commonly associated with Gastric carcinoma, lung carcinoma, and Uterine carcinoma.
  • The causal mechanism is immunologic; secretion of epidermal growth factor.

questions.text: Erythropoietin is produced by all of the following except ______
questions.solution:
Erythropoietin is not produced by blood vessel.

Erythropoietin:

  • Source
    • In adults, about 85% of erythropoietin comes from the kidneys and 15% from the liver
      • Interstitial cells in the peritubular capillary bed of the kidneys
      • Perivenous hepatocytes in the liver
    • It is also produced in the brain , where it exerts a protective effect against excitotoxic damage triggered by hypoxia; and in the uterus and oviducts, where it is induced by estrogen and appears to mediate estrogen-dependent angiogenesis.
  • Chief function
    • Erythropoietin increases the number of erythropoietin-sensitive committed stem cells in the bone marrow that are converted to RBC precursors and subsequently to mature RBC.
  • Stimuli that increase erythropoietin secretion
    • Hypoxia (most potent)
    • Cobalt salts
    • Androgens
    • Alkalosis that develops in high altitude
    • Catecholamines via β adrenergic mechanism

questions.text: Grade II lymphedema is __________.

choices.text: Pitting edema up to the knees

questions.solution:
Grade II lymphedema is non-Pitting edema up to ankle.

Grading of Edema (Brunner)

Subclinical (latent) - No clinically apparent lymphoedema (excess interstitial ﬂuid and histological abnormalities in lymphatics and lymph nodes)

I -- Edema pits on pressure and swelling largely or completely disappears on elevation and bed rest

II -- Edema does not pit and does not signiﬁcantly reduce upon elevation, positive Stemmer’s sign

III -- Edema is associated with irreversible skin changes, i.e. ﬁbrosis, papillae

questions.text: True about the structure given below is ________

choices.text: They are nuclear remnants in RBC

questions.solution:
The image shows Heinz bodies which are seen in G6PD deficiency.

Heinz bodies:

  • Exposure of G6PD deficient red cells to high levels of oxidants causes the cross-linking of reactive sulfhydryl groups on globin chains. These become denatured and form membrane-bound precipitates known as Heinz bodies.
  • Visualized by supravital staining.
  • Bite cells - as the splenic macrophages pluck out these inclusions, bite cells are produced.

Howell Jolly bodies:

  • Small nuclear remnants seen as inclusions in red cells due to asplenia.
  • They can also be seen in sickle cell anemia due to auto splenectomy or in Hereditary spherocytosis or thalassemia post splenectomy in some red cells but it is not characteristic. The image shows Howell Jolly bodies in peripheral blood smear.
