questions.text: The electroretinogram (ERG) of a person is given below. In this ERG, wave B is due to?
questions.solution:
The image shown is a normal electroretinogram (ERG) in which wave B is due to Muller cells.

Electroretinography measures the changes in the resting potential of an eye, induced by the light stimulus. Waves of ERG include a,b and c. Among these, a and c are negative waves and b is a large positive wave as shown below. The c wave is only seen in the dark-adapted eye. 

Uses of ERG:

  • Diagnosis and prognosis of retinal disorders
  • Early detection of functional abnormalities of the outer retina up to the bipolar cell layer
  • Assessment of retinal function in babies with possible impaired vision and in cases where fundus examination is difficult (in the presence of dense cataracts and corneal opacity).
  • Focal ERG is used to evaluate the diseases of the macula.

Note: Diseases involving ganglion cell layer and higher visual pathways may show a normal ERG.

Abnormal ERG response:

  • Subnormal b-wave response is seen in early cases of retinitis pigmentosa.
  • Extinguished response is seen when there is a complete failure of rods and cones function e.g., advanced retinitis pigmentosa, complete retinal detachment, central retinal artery occlusion.
  • A negative response is seen in gross disturbances of the retinal circulation.

questions.text: Reconstituted vaccine should not be stored for more than 6 hours because of ___________.
questions.solution:
Reconstituted vaccine should be discarded after 6 hours because of the risk of bacterial contamination (mainly staph aureus).

Reconstitution means that the lyophilized (freeze-dried) vaccine powder or wafer in one vial must be reconstituted (mixed) with the diluent (liquid) in another.

WHO RECOMMENDATIONS ON HANDLING VACCINE DILUENTS:

     • Never reconstitute a vaccine with a different diluent to the one specified by the manufacturer.

          - Never replace a vaccine diluent with water for injection

          -Never inject an oral vaccine or a diluent used to reconstitute an oral vaccine   

  • Never freeze a vaccine diluent containing an active substance 
  • Never use a reconstituted vaccine if foreign particulate matter is observed.

Note:

For Meningitis A conjugate vaccine: Diluent contains Aluminium phosphate (adjuvant) and thiomersal (preservative)

The storage location of vaccines:

questions.text: Concentration of Bupivacaine used for “mobile” epidural is ___________.
questions.solution:
0.0625% Bupivacaine is used for mobile epidural.

Very dilute local anesthetic mixtures (0.0625%) generally do not produce motor blockade and allow patients to ambulate (“walking” or “mobile” epidural).

Concentrations of local anesthetics used for epidural analgesia:

  • Without opioid
    • Bupivacaine: 0.25%
    • Ropivacaine: 0.2%
  • With opioid:
    • Bupivacaine 0.0625% to 0.125%
    • Ropivacaine 0.0625% to 0.2%

Note:

  • Bupivacaine and Ropivacaine are preferred over lidocaine and chloroprocaine for labor analgesia because of their differential blockade.
  • They produce less motor blockade as compared to sensory blockade. This preserved motor function enables voluntary bearing down efforts.
  • Bupivacaine is preferred because of its long duration of action
  • Ropivacaine has lower cardiac toxicity
  • Lower the concentration of the local anesthetic the greater the concentration of opioid that is required

questions.text: Pulmonary fibrosis and blue-gray skin discoloration are side effects of ________
questions.solution:
Pulmonary fibrosis and blue-gray skin discoloration are side effects associated with Amiodarone.

Side effects of amiodarone:

  • CVS: Torsades de pointes, heart block, bradycardia, QT prolongation
  • Hyperthyroidism, hypothyroidism
  • RS: Pulmonary alveolitis and fibrosis
  • GI upset, hepatitis
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Corneal micro deposits, optic neuropathy
  • Blue gray skin coloration

questions.text: False about polyarteritis nodosa is __________

choices.text: It is associated with chronic hepatitis B
It is a disease of medium sized arteries

questions.solution:
Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is not associated with ANCA.

PAN:

  • Systemic vasculitis of small or medium-sized muscular arteries.
  • It typically involves the renal and visceral vessels but spares the pulmonary circulation.
  • No association with ANCA, but about 30% of patients with PAN have chronic hepatitis-B.
  • Vessels of the kidneys, heart, liver, and gastrointestinal tract are involved in descending order of frequency.
  • It is the most common vasculitis associated with mononeuritis multiplex.
  • Most Common vessel involvement in PAN – Renal

questions.text: The following instrument is used to measure ______.

choices.text: Air movement, Humidity and Low air velocity
Air movement and low air velocity
Air temperature, Humidity, Air movement and Low air velocity

questions.solution:
The image shown is kata thermometer which is used to measure Air temperature, Humidity, Air movement and low air velocity

The Kata thermometer is an alcohol thermometer with a glass bulb 4 cm long and 1.8 cm in diameter

  • A kata thermometer was originally devised to measure the cooling power of air but is now used to measure low air velocities
  • Air temperature, humidity and air movement are collectively called cooling power of air.

Types of Kata thermometer: 

Based on Bulb:

  1. Dry Kata : reading of 6 and above
  2. Wet kata : reading of 20 and above, were regarded as indices of thermal comfort

Based on colour of alcohol:

  1. Red Kata : Standard one 
  2. Dark Blue :
  3. Magneta :

Note : 

Kata thermometers have silvered bulbs to reduce the errors due to radiation.

Related Pearl: Measurement of Air Temperature

A number of thermometers that employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.

These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.

The instruments used to measure air temperature are:

1) Dry bulb thermometers:

These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level

2) Wet bulb thermometers:

These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.

3) Maximum thermometer

This is a mercury thermometer that has a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb

4) Minimum thermometer

The liquid in this thermometer is a spirit that has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it

5) Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer

  • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
  • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
  • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available

5) Globe thermometer:

  • It is used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
  • It has a hollow metal globe (6 inches diameter) that has matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
  • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.

7) Kata thermometers:

  • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
  • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
  • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text: First line therapy in symptomatic endometriosis is __________
questions.solution:
The first line therapy in symptomatic endometriosis is NSAIDs.

NSAIDs ± Oral contraceptive pills are used as first line therapy in suspected endometriosis.

Laparoscopy is indicated in endometriosis for

  • Confirmation of diagnosis
  • No response to medical therapy
  • Treatment of infertility

Laparotomy is indicated when there are severe adhesions leading to bowel or bladder fisulas.

questions.text: Community-acquired pneumonia with watery diarrhea and confusion is due to _______.
questions.solution:
Legionella pneumophilia causes community acquired pneumonia with watery diarrhea and confusion.

Streptococcus pneumoniae causes typical lobar pneumonia. Mycoplasma and Chlamydia are common causes of Atypical pneumonia. However, they are not associated with extrapulmonary symptoms.

Legionnaires disease (Legionella pneumophila pneumonia)

Etiopathogenesis: Legionella pneumophila, Travel-associated, contaminated water supplies

Clinical features:

  • High grade fever with relative bradycardia
  • GI symptoms: Watery diarrhea
  • CNS symptoms: Headache and confusion

Laboratory findings:

  • Hyponatremia
  • Gram stain: many neutrophils with no organisms

Diagnosis: Legionella urine antigen test

Treatment: Levofloxacin or Azithromycin

questions.text: Floating teeth is seen in ________.
questions.solution:
The phenomenon of floating teeth is seen in Le Fort I fracture.

Related Pearl: Le-Fort's classification of Maxillary Fracture

Le-Fort I is a transverse fracture of the maxilla
  • Fracture line passes through the lower part of nasal septum, maxillary antra and the pterygoid plates
  • It separates palate from the rest of the face leading to floating teeth or palate
  • Also called Guerin’s fracture. 
Le-Fort II is a pyramidal fracture
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, floor of the orbit, upper part of the maxillary sinus and pterygoid plates
  • X-ray or CT appears like hanging maxilla
  • It is associated with CSF rhinorrhea.
Le-Fort III is craniofacial dysjunction i.e., facial skeleton completely disconnected from its cranial attachment
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, ethmo-frontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral wall of the orbit, fronto-zygomatic and temporo-zygomatic sutures and the upper part of pterygoid plates
  • It is also associated with CSF rhinorrhea.

questions.text: Which of the following risk factors is commonly associated with pelvic actinomycosis?
questions.solution:
Pelvic actinomycosis is commonly due to Intrauterine contraceptive device use.

Actinomyces israelii is a gram-positive, slow-growing, anaerobic bacterium that constitutes the normal vaginal flora. It is an uncommon cause of pelvic inflammatory disease in general.

Management includes antibiotic therapy while retaining the IUD in asymptomatic women. For those with symptoms, the IUD is removed and antibiotic therapy can be instituted.

questions.text: The immunofluorescence of the skin sample is shown below. Which of the following is true about blisters seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The blisters seen in this condition rupture frequently.

The immunofluorescence pattern shown above is suggestive of Pemphigus vulgaris. 

Direct immunofluorescence of skin samples with anti- IgG shows intercellular IgG deposits in the epidermis. This fish net appearance is characteristic of Pemphigus vulgaris due to anti-desmoglein IgG antibodies deposited on the desmosomes, which are present intercellularly.

The bullae (blisters) of Pemphigus vulgaris occur from destruction within the epidermis, therefore they are

  • Thin and fragile- rupture frequently
  • Painful (not pruritic)
  • Involves oral mucosa
  • Nikolsky’s sign positive -Slight rubbing of the skin results in peeling off of the epidermis. It is also seen in staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis.

The bullae of Bullous pemphigoid are deep, tense, do not rupture frequently, spare the oral mucosa and are Nikolsky’s sign negative. The immunofluorescence pattern seen in Bullous pemphigoid is a linear, subepithelial staining pattern.

  Pemphigus Vulgaris Bullous pemphigoid
Age 30-40 years 70-80 years
Antibody Anti-desmoglein Anti-hemidesmosome
Location of target antigens Intraepithelial Subepithelial
Immunofluorescence Fish-net pattern Linear, shoreline pattern
Bullae Thin and fragile Deep and tense
Mouth involved Yes No
Nikolsky’s sign Positive Negative
Symptom Painful Pruritic
Severity Life-threatening Resolves

Related Pearl: Differences between pemphigus vulgaris and bullous pemphigoid

Location of target antigens Intraepidermal Subepidermal

questions.text: Nature of Histone protein is ______.
questions.solution:
Histones are strongly basic proteins

Note: They are soluble in water & dilute acids

  • Histones are the most abundant chromatin protein
  • H1 histones are the ones least tightly bound to chromatin
  • The Nucleosome Contains Histone & DNA

Nucleosome :  Basic unit of DNA packaging in eukaryotes, consisting of a segment of DNA wound in sequence around eight histone protein cores

Nucleosomes contain four major types of histones: H2A, H2B, H3, and  H4

These four histones are called as Core Histones 

These four core histones are subject to six types of covalent modification or posttranslational modifications

  • Acetylation,
  • Methylation,
  • Phosphorylation,
  • ADP-ribosylation,
  • Monoubiquitylation,
  • Sumoylation.

Note : 

  • H3 and H4 form a tetramer

  • H2A and H2B form dimers

Related Pearl: Role of Histones

Types

Function

H1 histones

Stabilize the 30-nm chromatin fiber

H2 histones

H2A–H2B dimers stabilize the primary particle and firmly bind two additional half-turns of DNA

H3 histones

(H3–H4)2 tetramer has a central role in the formation

of the nucleosome

H4 histones

questions.text: World Blood Donor day is celebrated on ________
questions.solution:
World Blood Donor Day is celebrated on 14th June.

NOTE:

  • The slogan for this year’s campaign is 'Safe Blood For All'.
  • The theme of this year’s campaign is 'blood donation and universal access to safe blood transfusion, as a component of achieving universal health coverage'.
  • The host country for World Blood Donor Day 2019 is Rwanda.

questions.text: In which of the following is hyperviscosity syndrome more common?
questions.solution:
Hyperviscosity syndrome is more common in Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia.

Normal relative serum viscosity ranges from 1.4 to 1.8 units. However, symptoms of hyperviscosity syndrome are not seen at <4 units. It typically requires a viscosity >5 units. Hyperviscosity in plasma cell dyscrasias is due to excess IgM paraprotein. Symptomatic hyperviscosity is much more common in Waldenström's macroglobulinemia (10 to 30%) than it is in myeloma (2 to 6%). Less frequently, it also occurs in multiple myeloma (with myeloma proteins IgA and IgG3 types) and connective tissue diseases. Clinical features include:

  • Visual impairment
  • Neurologic problems
  • Bleeding
  • Cryoglobulinemia

questions.text: A primigravida with O negative blood group was found to have anti-D antibody titer of 1:16 at 28 weeks. The most likely cause is ________.
questions.solution:
The most likely cause in this patient with Rh alloimmunization is concealed placental abruption.

A blood type and antibody screen should be performed at the first prenatal visit, and unbound antibodies in maternal serum are detected by the indirect Coombs test. If initial screen is negative and pregnancy is uncomplicated the antibody screen is repeated at 28 weeks gestation and at delivery.

The critical titer is the level at which significant fetal anemia could potentially develop. This usually ranges between 1:8 and 1:32.

A patient with O negative blood group is not expected to have anti-D antibody titers. A titer of 1:16 at 28 weeks is suggestive of prior sensitization with Rh positive blood. All the options can cause Rh alloimmunization.

However, this scenario previous Rh-positive pregnancy is ruled out as she is a primigravida. Ectopic is ruled out as it is unlikely to be viable for 28 weeks. The most likely condition at this period of gestation is placental abruption which may be asymptomatic if concealed.

Causes of Alloimmunization

Pregnancy loss

  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Spontaneous abortion
  • Elective abortion
  • Fetal death

Procedures

  • Chorionic villus sampling
  • Amniocentesis
  • Fetal blood sampling

Other

  • Delivery
  • Trauma
  • Placental abruption
  • Unexplained vaginal bleeding during pregnancy
  • External cephalic version

For each of the above, anti-D immune globulin is recommended.

questions.text: Which of the following is an enrichment media?
questions.solution:
Tetrathionate broth is an example of enrichment media.

Enrichment media:

  • It is used to suppress the commensal bacteria while allowing the pathogen to remain viable and grow.
  • Examples:
    • Tetrathionate broth – It inhibits coliforms and allows typhoid and paratyphoid bacilli to grow.
    • Selenite F broth – Used for the dysentery causing bacteria.

Other options:

  • Chocolate agar – enriched media
  • MacConkey agar – differential media
  • Thayer martin media – selective media

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Lowe's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Symblepheron is not a feature of Lowe's syndrome

Lowe's Syndrome: Oculo-cerebral-renal syndrome which is an inborn error of amino acid metabolism

Ocular features:

  • Congenital Cataract
  • Glaucoma
  • Posterior lenticonus

Systemic features:

  • Mental retardation,
  • Dwarfism,
  • Osteomalacia,
  • Muscular hypotonia,
  • Frontal prominence.

questions.text: To diagnose a 5-year-old child with acute lymphoblastic leukemia, a pathologist has to see at least ____ percentage of blast cells in a bone marrow biopsy.
questions.solution:
The lower cut-off percentage for diagnosing acute lymphoblastic leukemia on bone marrow biopsy is 25%. 

Unlike with myeloid leukemias, there is no agreed-upon lower limit for the proportion of blasts required to establish a diagnosis of lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). In general, the diagnosis should be avoided when there are < 20% blasts. 

The image below shows numerous lymphoblasts seen on a peripheral smear.

Work-up of ALL:

It is important that all studies necessary to confirm a diagnosis and adequately classify the type of leukemia be performed, including bone marrow aspiration and biopsy, flow cytometry, cytogenetics, and molecular studies. The initial evaluation should also include a CSF examination. If lymphoblasts are found and the CSF leukocyte count is elevated, overt CNS or meningeal leukemia is present. This finding reflects a poorer stage and indicates the need for additional CNS and systemic therapies. 

Related Pearl: Morphological Characteristics of Blasts Cells in Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia vs. Acute Myeloid Leukemia

Blast population Homogeneous Heterogeneous, with the exception of the undifferentiated form 
Size Variable, mainly small  Variable, mainly large 
Nucleus Central, mainly round; sometimes indented. 
 		 Eccentric, round, oval, or angulated; sometimes convoluted, particularly in the form with a monocytic component 
Chromatin Fine, with dispersed condensation. 
Very condensed in small lymphoblasts 		 Fine, granular, delicately dispersed 
Nucleoli Absent in small lymphoblasts. 
Sometimes indistinct 		 Present. Often large and prominent, double or triple

Sometimes with a single long projection (hand-mirror cell) 		 Variable. 
Abundant in monoblasts, 
with protrusions in erythroblasts and megakaryoblasts 
Granules Rarely present. Negative for peroxidase, esterases, and toluidine blue  Present in forms with differentiation and positive with cytochemical stains
  • Peroxidase in the neutrophil and eosinophil lineages
  • Nonspecific esterase in the monocyte lineage 
Auer rods Absent  Can be present. 
Typically present in the hyper granular promyelocytic form 
Vacuoles Can be present Can be present. 
Almost always present in forms with a monocytic component

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents with sudden onset of severe breathlessness with wheezing. Her peak expiratory flow rate is reduced significantly. Which of the following enzymes is important for the pathogenesis of the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Sudden onset of severe breathlessness and wheezing with a reduced peak expiratory flow rate is suggestive of acute exacerbation of asthma. 5-lipoxygenase enzyme is important for the pathogenesis of this condition. 

Acute exacerbation of asthma is characterized by bronchoconstriction due to chemicals mediators like leukotrienes (LTB4, LTC4, LTD4 etc.). Leukotrienes are produced from the breakdown of arachidonic acid by 5-lipoxygenase via the lipoxygenase pathway. 

Leukotrienes are eicosanoic acid derivatives formed in leukocytes, mast cells, platelets, and macrophages. They are potent constrictors of the bronchial airway. Leukotrienes also cause increased vascular permeability and activation and attraction of leukocytes. Thus, they are involved in many inflammatory or immediate hypersensitivity reactions, such as asthma.

questions.text: Plasma concentration of a substance is 12.5mg/mL and its urine concentration is 125mg/mL. If the urine flow is 1.8ml/min, the renal clearance should be _________.
questions.solution:
Renal clearance in this scenario is 18ml/min

Renal clearance is the volume of plasma completely cleared of a substance by the kidneys per unit time.

  • It is calculated by the formula:
  • C = Clearance (mL/min)
  • [U]x = Urine concentration of substance x (mg/mL) =125mg/mL
  • V= Urine flow rate per minute (mL/min) =1.8mL/min
  • [P]x = Plasma concentration of substance x (mg/mL) = 12.5mg/mL
  • Substituting the values,

C=125 x 1.8/12.5=18ml/min

questions.text: Denitrogenation is __________.

choices.text: Addition of Nitrous oxide to the breathing circuit
Addition of high flow xenon into the breathing circuit.

questions.solution:
Denitrogenation also called preoxygenation is done by providing 100% oxygen via facemask for 3-5 minutes.

Nitrous oxide is a weak general anesthetic and is generally not used alone. It may be used in general anesthesia in a 70% concentration (in combination with 30% oxygen) or as a carrier gas with more potent general anesthetic agents.

Addition of high flow xenon into the breathing circuit is used to transition from 100% oxygen to closed circuit xenon-oxygen anaesthesia.

questions.text: Which of the following is an allosteric activator of muscle glycogen phosphorylase?
questions.solution:
5'AMP serves as the allosteric activator of muscle glycogen phosphorylase.

Glycogen phosphorylase catalyzes the rate-limiting step in glycogenolysis. It is regulated by allosteric mechanisms and covalent modification by reversible phosphorylation and dephosphorylation in response to hormone action.

In both liver and muscle, the glycogen phosphorylase is:

  • Activated by phosphorylation catalyzed by phosphorylase kinase (to yield phosphorylase a)
  • Inactivated by dephosphorylation catalyzed by protein phosphatase-1 (to yield phosphorylase b)

Muscle phosphorylase differs from the liver isoenzyme in having a binding site for 5′ AMP. It acts as an allosteric activator of the (inactive) dephosphorylated b-form of the enzyme.

  Allosteric Activator Allosteric Inhibitor
Liver  
  • ATP
  • Glucose-6-phosphate
  • Free glucose
Muscle 

    5' AMP
  • ATP
  • Glucose-6-phosphate

questions.text: Vaccine not included in National Immunization schedule is _________.
questions.solution:
Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV) is not included in National Immunization schedule.

The pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV) was launched as part of the National immunization schedule in Himachal Pradesh in May 2017 and is expected to expand all over the country in a phased manner. Himachal Pradesh, Bihar, Uttar Pradesh, Rajasthan and Madhya Pradesh are currently covered.

All other vaccines are included in National immunization schedule.

questions.text: In Pritchard regimen, maintenance dose is given only if _________.

choices.text: Urine output <100 ml in last 4 hours

questions.solution:
In Pritchard regimen, maintenance dose is given only if Patellar reflex is brisk.

Magnesium sulfate is used for management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe pre-eclampsia. The two regimens commonly used are tabulated below.

Regimen Loading Dose Maintenance Dose
Intramuscular (Pritchard) 4 g (20% solution) IV over 3–5 min followed by 10 g (50%), deep IM (5 g in each buttock) 5 g (50%) IM 4 hourly in alternate buttock
Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai) 4–6 g IV slow over 15–20 minute 1–2 g/h IV infusion

Patients must be monitored for magnesium toxicity. Repeated IM injections of Magnesium sulfate are continued only if:

  • The patellar reflex is present
  • Respirations are not depressed
  • Urine output in the previous 4 hours exceeded 100 mL

Measurement of serum magnesium levels is indicated to monitor magnesium toxicity if serum creatinine > 1.0 mg/dL.

Management of magnesium toxicity:

  • Stop magnesium therapy
  • Estimation of serum magnesium and creatinine levels
  • Injection of calcium gluconate 10ml (10% solution) IV

Side effects of MgSO4:

  • Anuria
  • Pulmonary edema

Mechanism of action of MgSO4:

  • It is a membrane stabilizer and a neuroprotector by reducing motor endplate sensitivity to Ach
  • It blocks neuronal Calcium influx
  • Reduced presynaptic release of the neurotransmitter glutamate
  • Blockade of glutaminergic NMDA receptors
  • Potentiation of adenosine action

Note: MgSO4 does not control hypertension

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding complications seen in undescended testis?
questions.solution:
In cases of undescended testes/cryptorchidism, there's no increased risk of epididymo-orchitis than usual.

Complications of cryptorchidism are as follows (remembered by the mnemonic TESTIS):

  • T- Torsion

  • E- Epididymorchitis

  • S- Sterility

  • T- Trauma (increased risk)

  • I- Increased risk of inguinal hernia (most commonly occurring complication)

  • S- Seminoma (increased risk)

Cryptorchidism is the failure of the descent of the intra-abdominal testes into the scrotal sac.  It is the most common congenital abnormality of the genitourinary tract. The testes can arrest anywhere during descent, and the most common site is the inguinal region.

Phases of testicular descent:

  • Transabdominal phase- testes come to lie in the lower abdomen or pelvis, and this descent is regulated by Mullerian-inhibiting substances.
  • Inguinoscrotal phase- testes descend along the inguinal canal and reach the scrotal sac, and this phase of the descent is regulated by androgen-induced calcitonin gene-related peptide from the genitofemoral nerve.

The exact pathogenesis remains unknown; however, deficiency in gonadotropins and Mullerian-inhibiting substance (MIS) and increased expression of estradiol in the placenta are thought to play a role. 

Cryptorchidism is histopathologically characterized by the following: 

  1. Testicular atrophy- thickening of the basement membrane, arrested germ cell development, marked hyalinization
  2. Tubules showing Sertoli cells but no spermatogenesis
  3. Increase in the interstitial Leydig cells 
It is associated with testicular atrophy and dysfunction, which result in sterility. Cryptorchid testes carry a 3–5-fold higher risk for testicular cancer (usually seminoma). Thus, observation is never the preferred treatment.
 
When the testis is impalpable, ultrasound may be helpful in identifying the intracanalicular testis, while laparoscopy may be needed to differentiate between the abdominal testis and a truly absent testis. Since here testis is made out in the inguinal region, laparoscopy is not the next best line of management.
 
Orchidectomy should be considered if the incompletely descended testis is atrophic, particularly in the postpubertal boy if the other testis is normal. Orchidopexy is usually performed before the boy reaches 12 months of age to avoid complications later on in life. 

The given flowchart summarizes the treatment protocol for undescended testis:

questions.text: Infrequent blinking seen in Graves ophthalmopathy is known as _________
questions.solution:
Infrequent blinking seen in Graves ophthalmopathy is known as Stellwags sign.

Graves ophthalmopathy: Most frequently affected extra ocular muscle in Grave's ophthalmopathy is Inferior Rectus.

Classification: Acronym ‘NOSPECS’:

  • Class 0 : No signs and symptoms
  • Class 1 : Only signs, no symptoms. Signs are limited to lid retraction with or without lid lag and mild proptosis
  • Class 2 : Soft tissue involvement with signs of class 1 and symptoms including lacrimation, photophobia, lid or conjunctival swelling
  • Class 3 : Proptosis is well established
  • Class 4 : Extraocular muscle involvement (limitation of movements and diplopia)
  • Class 5 : Corneal involvement (exposure keratitis)
  • Class 6 : Sight loss due to optic nerve involvement with disc pallor or papilloedema

EARLY Graves : class 1 and 2

Late Graves : class 3 to 6

Related Pearl: Signs in Grave’s ophthalmopathy

von Graefe's sign Lid lag, i.e., when the globe is moved downward, the upper lid lags behind

Stellwag's sign Infrequent blinking
Gifford's sign Difficulty in eversion of the upper lid
Mobius’ sign Convergence weakness
Joffroy’s sign Lack of wrinkling of the forehead on superior gaze
Jellinek's Sign Abnormal pigmentation of the upper lid

questions.text: True about supreme court verdict of 7 March 2018 is __________.

choices.text: Sexual intercourse by a man with his own wife without her consent is considered rape
The age of consent for sexual intercourse was increased to 18 years for married girls
The administration of lethal compounds for the purpose of ending life was legalized
A living will to withdraw life support in a patient in a vegetative state will be honored

questions.solution:
In a landmark verdict on 7th March 2018, supreme court has given legal sanction to passive euthanasia by permitting living will to withdraw life support in a patient in a vegetative state.

In March 2011, in connection with the Aruna Shaunbag case, the court laid out guidelines for passive euthanasia. The 2011 Passive Euthanasia law specified:

  • The brain-dead for whom the ventilator can be switched off
  • Those in a Persistent Vegetative State (PVS) for whom the feed can be tapered out and pain-managing palliatives be added, according to laid-down international specifications.

Sexual intercourse by a man with his own wife without her consent is not considered as rape by IPC (marital rape).

On October 11, 2017, the exception 2 of IPC 375 was ruled down. The age of consent for sexual intercourse was increased from 15 to 18 years for married girls.

The administration of lethal compounds for the purpose of ending life was legalized as active euthanasia and is not legal in India. Active euthanasia is legal in Netherlands, Belgium, Colombia, Luxembourg and Canada.

questions.text: Which of the following is involved in windlass mechanism?
questions.solution:
Plantar aponeurosis is involved in windlass mechanism.

Windlass mechanism:

When there is a dorsiflexion of the great toe, the plantar aponeurosis shortens and it draws the two pillars together. This leads to a heightening of the medial longitudinal arch. This is called the ‘windlass’ mechanism. 

Posterior part of the inferior calcaneal surface and the three metatarsal heads respectively form the posterior and anterior pillars of the medial longitudinal arch.

 

Median longitudinal arch:

Arch between the heel proximally and the medial three metatarsophalangeal joints.

Bones involved: Calcaneus, talar head, navicular, the three cuneiforms and the medial three metatarsals.

Stability of arch:

  • Plantar aponeurosis (most important)
  • Spring ligament
  • Talocalcaneal ligaments
  • Deltoid ligament
  • Muscles: Flexor hallucis longus, Flexor digitorum longus, abductor hallucis flexor digitorum brevis, Tibialis posterior and anterior
  • Bones

questions.text: According to the Erlanger and Gasser classification, which type of nerve fiber carries proprioceptive signals?
questions.solution:
According to the Erlanger and Gasser classification, proprioception is carried by Aα fiber.

Erlanger and Gasser classified nerve fibers into types A, B, and C, with type A fibers further subdivided into α, β, γ, and δ fibers.

  • Type A fibers are the typical large- and medium-­sized myelinated fibers of spinal nerves.
  • Type B fibers are smaller fibers with minimal myelination. They transmit impulses of the ANS, including the bladder. (B for Bladder)
  • Type C fibers are small unmyelinated nerve fibers that conduct impulses at low velocities.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with a complaint of pain in the wrist. He was diagnosed to have carpal tunnel syndrome. He is a patient with chronic kidney disease who is on hemodialysis. This is caused due to deposition of which of the following ?
questions.solution:
Carpal tunnel syndrome secondary to hemodialysis in a patient with chronic kidney disease is due to the deposition of Aβ2 microglobulin

Aβ2 microglobulin is present in high concentrations in the serum of patients with renal disease. It is retained in circulation as it is not filtered through dialysis membranes. It gets deposited in the synovium, joints, and tendon sheaths. When this deposition takes place in the carpal ligament of the wrist it leads to the development of ‘carpal tunnel syndrome’.

questions.text: The transverse ligament of atlas is a part of ______.
questions.solution:
The transverse atlantal ligament and longitudinal components together constitute the cruciform ligament.

  • The transverse atlantal ligament is a strong band that arches across the atlantal ring and is attached laterally to a small but prominent tubercle on the medial side of each atlantal lateral mass.
  • From its upper margin, a strong median longitudinal band arises that inserts into the basilar part of the occipital bone and from its inferior surface a weaker and less consistent longitudinal band passes to the posterior surface of the axis.
  • These transverse and longitudinal components together constitute the cruciform ligament.

questions.text: In the following pressure-volume loop diagram of left ventricle, the mitral valve will close at the point:
questions.solution:
The closure of the mitral valve corresponds to point 2, which marks the beginning of the isovolumetric contraction phase.

 The pressure-volume curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure (Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

  • Point 1 - Mitral valve opens
  • Point 2 - Mitral valve closes
  • Point 3 - Aortic valve opens
  • Point 4 - Aortic valve closes

Phase I: Period of filling:  

  • In the given diagram, the period of filling lasts from point 1 to point 2.
  • At point A, the volume of blood present in the left ventricle is the end-systolic volume which corresponds to about 50 ml. It is at this point that the mitral valve opens and the venous blood flows into the left ventricle from the left atrium.
  • At point B, the end of the period of filling—the amount of blood present in the left ventricle is called the end-diastolic volume which corresponds to about 120 ml. It is at this point that the mitral valve closes.

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction:

  • In the given diagram, the period of isovolumetric contraction lasts from point 2 to point 3.
  • At point B, the mitral valve closes and the volume of the ventricle does not change as all the valves are closed. However, the pressure inside the ventricle continues to rise.
  • At point C the ventricular pressure increases to become equal to the pressure in the aorta (80 mm Hg) and then the aortic valve opens.

Phase III: Period of ejection

  • In the given diagram, the period of ejection lasts from point 3 to point 4.
  • At point C, the aortic valve opens and the volume of the ventricle decreases as the blood flows out of the ventricle into the aorta.
  • The systolic pressure continues to rise as the ventricle contracts.
  • At point D the aortic valve closes.

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation

  • In the given diagram, the period of relaxation lasts from point 4 to point 1.
  • At point D, the aortic valve closes and the ventricular pressure falls back to the diastolic pressure level. 
  • This decrease in intraventricular pressure occurs without any change in volume.
  • At point A, the ventricle now has an end-systolic volume of 50 ml of blood similar to the beginning of the cycle.

questions.text: The most common source of infection in lactational mastitis is
questions.solution:
The most common source of infection in lactational mastitis is infant's nasopharynx.

Lactational mastitis:

  • Most common organism: Staphylococcus aureus
  • Most common source: Infant’s nasopharynx > Maternal skin flora

Pathogenesis: Bacteria enters ducts through nipple and multiplies in stagnant milk.

Risk factors:

  • Prior history of Mastitis
  • Engorgement and inadequate milk drainage due to:
    • Poor latch
    • Cracked nipple
    • Tight clothing
    • Weaning
    • Replacing nursing with formula or pumped breast milk
    • Sudden increase in sleep duration

Clinical features: Fever. A firm, red, tender, swollen quadrant of unilateral breast, +/- myalgias, chills, malaise

Treatment:

  • Analgesia
  • Frequent breast feeding or pumping
  • Antibiotic of choice: Dicloxacillin or Cephalexin
  • Risk factors of MRSA: Clindamycin, TMP-SMX, Vancomycin

Note: Breast Engorgement is characterized by bilateral breast tenderness and swelling typically presents 24 to 72 hours post-partum, peaks 3 to 5 days after delivery and resolves spontaneously. Antibiotics are not indicated. Treatment is by cold compresses and analgesics.

questions.text: Interpositus nucleus of cerebellum is made up of _______.
questions.solution:
Interpositus nucleus of cerebellum is made up of Globose and emboliform nuclei.

Cerebellum:

Has 3 layers, 4 deep nuclei, 5 types of neurons

  • external molecular layer
  • Purkinje cell layer
  • internal granular layer

There are four deep nuclei: D,E,F,G

  • Dentate
  • Emboliform
  • Fastigial nuclei
  • Glo­bose

Interpositus nucleus- Globose and the emboliform nuclei together.

There are five types of neurons in the cortex:

  • Purkinje
  • granule
  • basket
  • stellate
  • Golgi cells

questions.text: The variant of Reed Sternberg cell shown below is seen in which type of Hodgkin's lymphoma?
questions.solution:
The image shows the lymphohistiocytic variant (Popcorn Reed Sternberg cell) along with multiple infolded nuclear membranes, small nucleoli, fine chromatin, and abundant pale cytoplasm. It is seen in the lymphocyte-predominant type of HL.

Reed Sternberg cell:

  • Hodgkins lymphoma is characterised by the presence of a giant cell called as Reed Sternberg cell (RS cell).
  • It is derived from the germinal center B cell.
  • It has a classic owl eyed appearance due to the presence of symmetric or mirror image bilobed nucleus with prominent nucleoli surrounded by a clear space.
  • RS Cells can be present in certain other conditions like infectious mononucleosis, solid tissue tumours and immunoblastic lymphoma.
  • There are several variants to RS cells like: Lacunar variant, Mononuclear variant, Pleomorphic, Lymphohistiocytic variant (L&H)

Classical Reed-Sternberg cell has two nuclear lobes, large inclusion-like nucleoli, and abundant cytoplasm, and  is surrounded by lymphocytes, macrophages, and eosinophil.

Lacunar variant has a folded or multilobated nucleus and lies within a open space, which is an artifact created by disruption of the cytoplasm during tissue sectioning.

Related Pearl: Important Features of the Different Types of Hodgkin's Lymphoma (HL)

Classic subtypes

  • Nodular sclerosis 
  • Mixed cellularity 
  • Lymphocyte-rich
  • Lymphocyte depletion

Non-Classical subtype

  • Lymphocyte predominant

Note: Mixed cellularity is most commonly associated with HIV due to its high incidence.

questions.text: The treatment of choice for severe Clostridium difficile colitis is ___________.
questions.solution:
Oral Vancomycin is the first choice of treatment for severe Clostridium difficile colitis.

First choice treatment of C. difficile colitis:

Severity Treatment
Mild to moderate Oral Vancomycin
Severe (WBC >15,000/cu.mm, Creatinine >1.5 times baseline Oral Vancomycin
Severe, Complicated (Shock, Ileus, Toxic Megacolon) Oral Vancomycin + IV Metronidazole ± Rectal Vancomycin

*Fidaxomicin is an alternative in all cases.

*Metronidazole now reserved for non-severe infections in settings where access to first-line drugs is limited or cost is an issue. 

Recent update: Harrison's 20th edition recommends the use of vancomycin over metronidazole in the treatment of initial episodes which are mild to moderate in severity. Metronidazole is recommended only if vancomycin or fidaxomicin are not accessible. Oral metronidazole is less effective than the other options and may necessitate a longer treatment course for response

Recent update: British Society of Gastroenterology/Healthcare Infection Society working group recommended the guideline that considers the use of faecal microbiota transplant (FMT) for the treatment of recurrent or refractory Clostridium difficile infection.It was recommended that  FMT should only be considered after recurrence of symptoms following resolution of an episode of CDI that was treated with appropriate antimicrobials for at least 10 days and treatment with extended/pulsed vancomycin and/or fidaxomicin before considering FMT as treatment for recurrent CDI and those with severe or complicated CDI, which appears to be associated with reduced cure rates, consideration should be given to offering patients treatment with medications which are associated with a reduced risk of recurrence (eg, fidaxomicin and bezlotoxumab), before offering FMT.

questions.text: Claustrum is separated from putamen by _______.
questions.solution:
Claustrum is separated from putamen by external capsule.

The lentiform complex lies deep to the insular cortex, they are separated by a thin layer of white matter and by the claustrum. The latter splits the insular subcortical white matter to create the extreme and external capsules.

  • The external capsule separates the claustrum from the putamen.
  • The Extreme capsule lies between claustrum and insular cortex.
  • The internal capsule separates the lentiform complex from the caudate nucleus.
  • The lentiform complex has two parts, the laterally placed putamen and the more medially placed globus pallidus (pallidum). These are separated by a thin layer of fibres, the external medullary lamina.
  • The globus pallidus is itself divided into two segments, a lateral (external) segment and a medial (internal) segment They are separated by an internal medullary lamina.

questions.text: Glucocorticoids are indicated in Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia (PCP) if

choices.text: PaO2 < 55 mm Hg and A-a gradient > 35 mm Hg
PaO2 < 55 mm Hg and A-a gradient > 25 mm Hg
PaO2 < 70 mm Hg and A-a gradient > 35 mm Hg
PaO2 < 70 mm Hg and A-a gradient > 25 mm Hg

questions.solution:
Indication for glucocorticoids in PCP is PaO2 < 70 mm Hg and A-a gradient > 35 mm Hg.

Treatment of PCP:

  • Drug of Choice is Trimethroprim/Sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX)
  • Side effects of TMP-SMX are skin rash and bone marrow suppression
  • Alternative treatments for mild to moderate PCP include dapsone/ trimethoprim, clindamycin/primaquine, and atovaquone.
  • IV pentamidine is the treatment of choice for severe disease in patients unable to tolerate TMP/SMX.
  • Glucocorticoids are indicated if Pao2 <70 mmHg or with an A–a gradient >35 mmHg.

Prophylaxis of PCP:

  • Indications: CD4+ T cell count <200/uL (CD4 cell %<15), recent oropharyngeal candidiasis and prior PCP.
  • Drug of choice is Trimethroprim/Sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX)
  • Other drugs: Dapsone/pyrimethamine + leucovorin or aerosolized pentamidine.

questions.text:
Hemodynamic measurements in Septic shock are:
1-Right atrial pressure
2-Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure
3-Cardiac index
4-Systemic vascular resistance
5-Mixed venous oxygen saturation
questions.solution:
Septic shock has low right atrial pressure, low pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, high cardiac index, low systemic vascular resistance and high mixed venous oxygen saturation.

  • The hallmark of septic shock is a decrease in systemic vascular resistance that occurs due to endothelial injury.
  • Generalized maldistribution of blood volume and diffuse capillary leakage of intravascular fluid heads to decreased preload (right atrial pressure and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure).
  • Oxygen utilization by tissues is impaired leading to increased mixed venous oxygen saturation.

Option A corresponds to Hypovolemic shock and Option C corresponds to Cardiogenic shock.

Parameter Hypovolemic shock Cardiogenic shock Septic shock

Right atrial pressure (preload)

questions.text: The scab formed following an abrasion falls off after _______.
questions.solution:
The scab formed following an abrasion falls off after 7 days or one week.

Definition: Scab is the destruction of the skin which usually involves the superficial layer of epidermis only.

Types:

  • Linear abrasions (Scratches): caused by relative movement of a pointed object on the skin
    • eg. nail, thorn, the point of sword or knife
  • Grazed abrasions (sliding /scrapping/grinding abrasion): caused by relative movement of a rough surface on a wide area of skin.
    • known as Brush burns
    • eg. fall, a victim being dragged on the ground, road traffic accidents
  • Imprint abrasions (patterned abrasions): caused by the impact of a rigid hard rough surface over a localized area of the skin without any movement
    • eg. fingernail, tire, grills, bicycle chain, bite marks
  • Friction abrasions (Pressure Abrasion): caused by pressure upon the skin with an agent with a smooth surface accompanied by movement.
    • eg. ligature marks around the neck in hanging,

Note :

  • Grazed abrasion is the most common type of abrasion

Related Pearl: Age of bruise and abrasion

Age and color change of bruise/contusion:

 

Colour Due to Duration  
Red Haemoglobin (fresh blood) Fresh  
Blue Deoxygenated haemoglobin Few hours to 3 days 
Bluish black/ brown Hemosiderin 4th day  
Green Hematoidin 5 to 6 days 
Yellow Bilirubin 7 to 12 days 
Normal colour Pigment removed by phagocytes  2 weeks

 

The image given below shows the age and colour change of bruise:

 

Age of abrasion:

Colour of scab Duration
Bright red 12-24 hrs
Reddish brown 2-3 days
Dark brown to brownish black 4-7 days
Scab dries shrinks and falls off After 7 days

questions.text: Which of the following is not a suicide enzyme?
questions.solution:
Transaminase is not a suicide enzyme.

Suicide enzymes are the ones which undergo suicidal inhibition.

Suicidal inhibition is a type of irreversible inhibition

Here the inhibitor makes use of the enzyme's own reaction mechanism to inactivate it i.e a self-catalyzed destruction.

eg. Cyclo-oxygenase, Xanthine oxidase, Transpeptidase (Mechanism of penicillin action)

Reaction catalysed by transaminases

questions.text: Alice in Wonderland effect is _________.
questions.solution:
Alice in Wonderland effect is also called dysmegalopsia. It is a disorder of perception in which there is a distortion in the size and shape of objects.

The symptoms are similar to the strange experiences described by Lewis Carroll in his classic, Alice in Wonderland and its Disney adaptation.

Folie a deux: Mental illness shared by two persons, usually involving a common delusional system; if it involves three persons, it is referred to as folie a trois. Also called shared psychotic disorder.

Fausse reconnaissance: False recognition, a feature of paramnesia. Can occur in delusional disorders.

Dysmnesia: impaired memory.

questions.text: Modified Goeckerman regimen is _____________.
questions.solution:
Coal tar + Narrowband UVB (311–313 nm) is known as Modified Goeckerman regimen. It is the recommended first-line therapy for most patients with moderate to severe psoriasis.

Coal tar + Broadband UVB (290–320 nm) was used for nearly 100 years as part of the Goeckerman regimen. The optimal wavelength for treating psoriasis was found to be 312 nm. Hence, the modified regimen is preferred as it is more efficient and better tolerated.

Psoralens and long‐wave ultraviolet radiation (UVA 320–400 nm) is also called PUVA. The efficacy is comparable to Modified Goeckerman regimen. However, it is not preferred as the first line due to its side effect profile. Side effects include erythema, blistering, neurogenic itch (PUVA itch- crawling sensation underneath the skin) and increased risk of non-melanoma skin cancers. Psoralens are teratogenic.

Topical calcipotriol is used in the treatment of mild plaque psoriasis. Calcipotriol ointment enhances the efficacy of PUVA and UVB phototherapy. it is recommended that calcipotriol is not applied immediately prior to phototherapy exposures.

Related Pearl: Drug of choice for different types of psoriasis

Type Drug of choice
Chronic Plaque Psoriasis Methotrexate
Erythrodermic Psoriasis Methotrexate 
Psoriatic Arthritis Methotrexate / Apremilast
Pustular Psoriasis Acitretin
Psoriasis in HIV patients Acitretin
Impetigo Herpetiformis

1. Systemic Corticosteroids

2. Cyclosporine
Erythrodermic Psoriasis in Pregnancy Systemic Corticosteroids

questions.text: The petechial hemorrhages seen over the facial skin in cases of death by hanging are called:
questions.solution:
Petechial hemorrhages over the facial skin in someone who died by hanging are referred to as Tardieu's spots.

Tardieu's spots or petechial hemorrhages are important external as well as internal autopsy findings in a victim of asphyxia. In cases of hanging, they are seen on the skin above the level of obstruction, i.e., over the face, behind the ears, and on the conjunctiva & sclera. They appear due to an acute increase in venous pressure, resulting in distension and rupture of thin-walled peripheral vessels and capillaries. 

Tardieu's spots are also seen internally as postmortem findings of asphyxia. They can occur on the undersurface of the scalp, brain, heart, lungs, and rarely on the parietal pleura & peritoneum.

Other options: 

Option A: Tache noir is a black-colored deposition of cell debris and mucous on the sclera that occurs within 3-4 hours of death. It occurs if the eyes remain open after death as the areas of the sclera exposed to the air dry out.

Option C: Paultauf's hemorrhages are small subpleural intrapulmonary hemorrhages seen as postmortem findings in cases of drowning.

Option D: Kevorkian sign is the segmentation of retinal blood columns which occurs immediately after death.

questions.text: The only FDA approved drug for primary progressive multiple sclerosis is _________.
questions.solution:
Ocrelizumab is the only FDA approved drug (2017) for the treatment of primary progressive multiple sclerosis (PPMS)

  • Natalizumab is FDA approved for the treatment of relapsing remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS) and Crohn’s disease. It increases the risk of Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy(PML).
  • Alemtuzumab is also FDA approved for relapsing forms of MS. It contains a black box warning for serious fatal autoimmune conditions.
  • Glatimer acetate is found to be effective in RRMS.

Treatment of multiple sclerosis:

  • Glucocorticoids are used to manage either first attacks or acute exacerbations. Intravenous methylprednisolone, 500–1000 mg/d for 3–5 days, followed by a course of oral prednisone beginning at a dose of 60–80 mg/d and gradually tapered over 2 weeks is given. They reduce the severity and shorten the duration of attacks.
  • Disease modifying therapies for relapsing forms of multiple sclerosis are:
    1. IFN-β-1a (Avonex)
    2. IFN-β-1a (Rebif)
    3. IFN-β-1b (Betaseron or Extavia)
    4. Glatiramer acetate
    5. Natalizumab
    6. Fingolimod
    7. Dimethyl fumarate
    8. Teriflunomide
    9. Mitoxantrone
    10. Alemtuzumab

questions.text: Normal physiologic change in pregnancy is ___________.
questions.solution:
Chronic respiratory alkalosis is a normal physiologic change seen in pregnancy.

Progesterone directly stimulates central respiratory centers to increase tidal volume and minute ventilation. This leads to increased PaO2 and decreased PaCO2. This paradoxically causes physiological dyspnea. It is an increased awareness of a desire to breathe.

This results in a chronic respiratory alkalosis. Metabolic compensation of respiratory alkalosis leads to decrease in bicarbonate level from approximately 26 to 22 mmol/L.

questions.text: Which of the following develops in the retroperitoneal region?
questions.solution:
Urogenital remnant mesentric cysts develop in the retroperitoneal space and project into the peritoneum.

Many of these are derived from remnants of the Wolffian ducts. Differentiation from other retroperitoneal tumors is difficult clinically, or even with radiology and often requires surgery for confirmation of source.

Most common mesenteric cyst is chylolymphatic. Enterogenous cysts often share the blood supply with the bowel and so bowel resection is needed for complete removal.

questions.text: The most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism is :
questions.solution:
Single parathyroid adenoma accounts for  more than 80% of the cases of primary hyperparathyroidism.

Primary Hyperparathyroidism:

  • Single parathyroid adenoma (83%)
  • Multiple adenomas (6%)
  • Hyperplasia (10%)
  • Carcinoma (1%)

Other features:

  • It is commonly sporadic than familial.
  • Adenoma are most commonly located in inferior parathyroid glands.
  • It affects women more than men.
  • It may occur as part of MEN syndrome/ familial HPT/ Familial HPT with jaw tumor syndrome.

Related Pearl: Parathyroid Diseases

questions.text: False about spleen is

choices.text: 25% of all ruptured splenic artery aneurysms are in pregnancy
15% of accessory spleens are seen behind the head of pancreas
Splenic abscess can be secondary to otitis media
Pancreatic necrosis can give rise to splenic artery aneurysm

questions.solution:
Head of pancreas is not a common site for accessory spleens.

Location of accessory spleen:

  • splenic Hilar region, 54%;
  • splenic vascular pedicle, 25%;
  • tail of pancreas, 6%;
  • splenocolic ligament, 2%;
  • greater omentum, 12%;
  • mesentery, 0.5%;
  • left ovary, 0.5%.

Causes of splenic abscess:

  • Infected splenic embolus, in association with typhoid and paratyphoid fever,
  • osteomyelitis,
  • otitis media
  • puerperal sepsis,
  • pancreatic necrosis

Clinical Note: Failure to identify and remove superneumary spleen at the time of splenectomy may give rise to persistent disease. Splenic Artery aneurysms are the most common visceral artery aneurysm. Women are four times more likely to be affected than men.upto 25% of ruptures occur in third trimester and labour. Pancreatic necrosis or intra-abdominal sepsis may give rise to these.

questions.text: Identify the artery marked in the image _________
questions.solution:
The artery marked in the image is superior cerebellar artery.

The superior cerebellar artery arises near the distal portion of the basilar artery, immediately before the formation of the posterior cerebral arteries. The superior cerebellar artery supplies the pons, pineal body, superior medullary velum and tela choroidea of the third ventricle.

Circle of Willis or circulus arteriosus: Large arterial anastomosis that unites the internal carotid and vertebrobasilar systems. It lies in the subarachnoid space within the basal cisterns that surround the optic chiasma and infundibulum.

The anterior cerebral arteries are derived from the internal carotid arteries and are linked by a small anterior communicating artery.

Posteriorly, the two posterior cerebral arteries are formed by the division of the basilar artery. They are joined to the ipsilateral internal carotid artery by a posterior communicating artery.

questions.text: A person working in the smelting industry noticed the following changes in the nails. This finding can be seen in chronic poisoning with which of the following?
questions.solution:
The image shows transverse white lines of 1 to 2mm in breadth across the nail which is called Aldrich-Mees lines and is usually seen in chronic arsenic and thallium poisoning.

Chronic Arsenic Poisoning :

  • Source: Occurs in persons engaged in smelting or refining ore or long-term exposure to arsenic compounds

Manifestations of chronic arsenic poisoning: 

System involved Symptoms
Skin Melanosis, Bowen’s disease facial edema, hyperkeratosis, cutaneous cancer, raindrop hyperpigmentation 
Nails Aldrich Mees Line: Transverse white lines in the fingernails 
Neurologic Polyneuritis, anesthesias, paraesthesia,
encephalopathy. 
GI tract Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia, weight loss
Liver Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis
Haematologic Bone marrow hypoplasia, anemia, leukopenia, basophilic stippling, and karyorrhexis
Cardiovascular Blackfoot disease due to platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries

Diagnosis: Urinary level of > 100 mg/ 24 hours suggestive of arsenic toxicity. Blood levels and hair levels are not reliable.

Laboratory tests to detect arsenic poisoning are:

  • Marsh’s test
  • Reinsch test
  • Atomic absorption spectroscopy

Management:

  • Hemodialysis is the treatment of choice for massive arsenic poisoning.
  • Chelation with BAL(British Anti Lewisite). Penicillamine or DMSA can be used instead of BAL.
  • Gastric lavage with warm water and milk

Other options:

  • Lead poisoning is characterized by a blue line on the gums called the Burtonian line. It can also be seen in mercury poisoning.
  • Mercury poisoning is characterized by mercurial tremors or Hatters shake.

Related Pearl: Arsenic poisoning

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

Characteristic clinical findings are as follows: Mnemonic-ARSENIC

A- Aldrich mees lines

R- raindrop pigmentation, rash, red velvety mucosa

S- subendocardial haemorrhage

E- Excessive pigmentation- Blackfoot disease

N- Neuritis

I- Iron oxide + BAL –treatment

C- Cholera like illness

Diagnosis: 24-hour urine arsenic

Treatment: BAL; succimer(DMSA)

Clinicopathological findings in acute and chronic arsenic poisoning:

System

Melanosis, Bowen’s disease facial edema, hyperkeratosis, cutaneous cancer, hyperpigmentation.

Mees’s lines in 2-3 weeks post ingestion.

Mees' lines

Neurologic

Hyperpyrexia, convulsions, tremors, coma

Encephalopathy, polyneuropathy, tremors, axonal degeneration

GI tract

Abdominal pain, dysphagia, vomiting, bloody or rice water diarrhea, mucosal erosions.

Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia, weight loss

Liver

Fatty infiltration

Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis

Kidney

Tubular and glomerular changes – oliguria and uremia

Nephritic finding

thrombocytopenia, impaired folate metabolism

Bone marrow hypoplasia, anemia, leukopenia, basophilic stippling, and karyorrhexis.

Cardiovascular
  • S-T wave abnormalities,
  • prolonged QT interval
  • ventricular fibrillation
  • atypical ventricular tachycardia 

There is platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries leading to blackfoot disease

Reproductive system

Arsenic crosses the placental barrier and infant death shortly after birth.

questions.text:
The line joining the points O, N and F is called ______.
(Where, O is the fixation point, N is the center of the lens, F is the Fovea, R is the center of the retina and P is the center of the cornea)
questions.solution:
Visual axis is the line joining the fixation point(O), nodal point/the center of the lens (N), and the fovea (F).

OTHER AXIS OF EYE

  • Optical axis:

                      The line passing through the center of the cornea (P), the center of the lens (N) and meets the retina (R) on the nasal side of the fovea.

                      It is also referred to as Principal axis

  • Fixation axis:

                      The line joining the fixation point (O) and the center of rotation (C).

VISUAL ANGLES

  • Angle alpha. It is the angle (ONA) formed between the optical axis (AR) and visual axis (OF) at the nodal point (N).
  • Angle gamma. It is the angle (OCA) between the optical axis (AR) and fixation axis (OC) at the center of rotation of the eyeball (C).
  • Angle kappa. It is the angle (OPA) formed between the visual axis (OF) and pupillary line (AP).

Note:

  • A positive angle kappa results in pseudo-exotropia
  • A negative angle kappa results in  pseudo-esotropia

Related Pearl: Axes of the Eye

Axes of the eye: 

Axis  Description
Optic Axis  Line passing through the center of the cornea and centre of the lens to meet the retina on the nasal side of the fovea.
Visual Axis   Line joining the fixation point (object), nodal point (centre of the lens), and the fovea
Fixation Axis   Line joining the fixation point (object) and the centre of rotation

Angles of the eye: 

  Visual axis Line of sight Fixation axis
Pupillary axis Kappa (κ) Lambda (λ)  
Optic Axis Alpha (α)   Gamma (γ)

questions.text: Which of the following is called autosomal hemophilia?
questions.solution:
Autosomal hemophilia is also called type 2N von Willebrand disease (vWD), as the clinical presentation is similar to hemophilia.

The types of vWD are:

Type Inheritance Mechanism Important characteristics
1 AD Partial quantitative deficiency of VWF Most common type
3 AR Complete quantitative deficiency Most severe VWD
2A AD Loss of VWF multimers (increased cleavage by ADAMS13) Platelet adhesion defect
2B AD Increased binding of VWF to platelets causing VWF-platelet complex destruction Thrombocytopenia
2M AD Decreased affinity of VWF to platelets Platelet adhesion defect, very rare
2N AR Decreased affinity of VWF to Factor VIII Autosomal hemophilia

In pseudo vWD, the vWF is normal. However, platelets have an increased affinity for vWF. It presents similar to vWD 2B with thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: Lermoyez syndrome is

choices.text: Episodic vertigo followed by progressive sensorineural hearing loss
Progressive sensorineural hearing loss followed by recovery and vertigo
Episodic vertigo with normal cochlear function in early stages of the disease
Progressive hearing loss with absent vertigo in early stages of the disease

questions.solution:
Lermoyez syndrome is Progressive sensorineural hearing loss followed by recovery and vertigo.

Explanation:

Lermoyez syndrome is a variant of Meniere’s wherein the symptoms appear in reverse order. The patient develops progressive sensorineural hearing loss followed by an attack of vertigo and recovery of hearing loss.

Episodic vertigo followed by progressive sensorineural hearing loss is the normal sequence of Meniere’s disease. It is also called Endolymphatic hydrops. The cardinal symptoms of Meniere’s disease are:

  • Episodic vertigo
  • Fluctuating hearing loss
  • Tinnitus

Episodic vertigo with normal cochlear function in early stages of the disease is a Meniere’s disease variant known as vestibular hydrops.

Progressive hearing loss with absent vertigo in early stages of the disease is a variant of Meniere’s disease known as cochlear hydrops.

questions.text: As an intern, you see a patient with hyperkalemia in the emergency room. Which of the following drugs would NOT be implicated in this case?
questions.solution:
β2 agonists (terbutaline) cause an intracellular shift of potassium leading to a transient decrease in potassium levels (hypokalemia). Therefore, it is used in the management of hyperkalemia.

Causes and mechanisms of drug-induced hyperkalemia

Medication Mechanism

β-blockers

 Interferes with beta-2 mediated intracellular potassium uptake.

 Inhibition of Na+/K+/ATPase pump.

 Blocks aldosterone activity.

 Causes extracellular leakage of potassium through acetylcholine receptors.

NSAIDs

 Decreases renal perfusion resulting in decreased K+ delivery to the collecting ducts.

questions.text: The most likely cause of this fetal heart rate pattern?
questions.solution:
The fetal heart rate pattern above shows late decelerations which are most likely to be caused by Fetal acidosis.

Deceleration is defined as a decrease in heart rate >15 bpm for >15s but <2 minutes.

The fetal heart tracing above shows decelerations which are delayed as compared to the contraction. The nadir of deceleration occurs after peak of contraction. This is characteristic of late decelerations. Uteroplacental insufficiency, fetal hypoxia and fetal acidosis cause late decelerations.

Types of decelerations:

  • Early decelerations: gradual onset, symmetric to contraction, nadir of deceleration corresponds to the peak of contraction.
  • Late decelerations: gradual, delayed compared to contraction, nadir of deceleration occurs after peak of contraction.
  • Variable deceleration: Abrupt, not associated with contractions.

Related Pearl: Deceleration patterns on cardiotocography (CTG)

Early deceleration: seen in head compression

 

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia

 

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression

questions.text: Which of the following statements are false with respect to the inverse stretch reflex?
questions.solution:
Option D is a false statement as the inverse stretch reflex can be stimulated by a passive stretch as well as an active contraction.

When the tension in the muscle increases and surpasses a limit, contraction suddenly ceases and the muscle relaxes. This relaxation in response to an overt stretch is called the inverse stretch reflex.

The receptor involved in this reflex is the Golgi tendon organ (Option B). The Golgi tendon organ consists of a net-like collection of nerve endings that are arranged in series (Option C) within the muscle fibers. This arrangement allows for Golgi tendon organs to be stimulated by both active contraction and passive stretch of the muscle, unlike muscle spindles. One Golgi tendon organ innervates 3-25 muscle fibers. 

The afferents from the Golgi tendon organ are the Ib myelinated nerve fibers. The Ib nerve fibers synapse with inhibitory interneurons present in the spinal cord, which in turn synapse with the motor neurons supplying the muscles. Thus, this is a disynaptic reflex (Option A).

Related Pearl: Summary of Muscle Reflexes

Relaxation of muscle

Polysynaptic

Ipsilateral flexion; contralateral extension

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding apoptosis?
questions.solution:
The plasma membrane is intact in apoptosis.

Apoptosis is a pathway of programmed cell death and can occur due to physiological requirements (such as elimination of harmful self-reactive lymphocytes) or in pathological conditions (such as DNA damage or infection-induced).

The morphological features seen in apoptosis include:

  • cell shrinkage with dense and eosinophilic cytoplasm.
  • chromatin condensation is the most characteristic feature of apoptosis.
  • formation of cytoplasmic blebs followed by fragmentation into apoptotic bodies.
  • phagocytosis of apoptotic cells by macrophages.

The other options are all features of necrosis (type of cell death). It is characterized by leakage of cellular contents through damaged membranes, local inflammation, and enzymatic degradation of the injured cell. The nucleus undergoes pyknosis (nuclear shrinkage and increased basophilia), karyorrhexis (fragmentation of pyknotic nucleus) and followed by karyolysis (chromatin fades).

Related Pearl: Necrosis vs Apoptosis

questions.text: A Norovirus outbreak occurs in an urban slum where you are posted as the PHC medical officer. Which is the best method to teach the people about ORS?
questions.solution:
The best method to teach an urban slum about ORS is by demonstrations.

Demonstration is a carefully prepared presentation on how to perform a certain task or skill or procedure. It shows the step-by-step process of a task. It arouses interest and incites ‘learning by doing,’ and ‘seeing is believing’ philosophies.

questions.text: The inheritance pattern shown below is
questions.solution:
The inheritance pattern shown above is mitochondrial. None of the above options correspond to this pattern.

Mitochondrial inheritance:

  • Caused by mutations of the mitochondrial genome.
  • Inherited exclusively from the affected mother (ovum) as an individual’s mitochondrial genome is entirely derived from the mother because sperm contain few mitochondria, which are typically shed upon fertilization.
  • Both male and female children born to an affected mother will inherit the disease.
  • These diseases include: Mitochondrial encephalopathy, Lactic acidosis and Stroke like episodes (MELAS) and other disorders tabulated below (mnemonic: KLMNOP).

M. marinum (e.g. of Photochromogen):

questions.text: Which of the following are correctly matched?
questions.solution:
• Asteatotic dermatitis is also called Winter eczema.
  • Cradle cap and Dandruff are types of seborrheic dermatitis.
  • Bindi dermatitis is a type of allergic contact dermatitis.
  • Halo dermatitis is the occurrence of an eczematous ring surrounding a melanocytic nevus. It is also called Meyerson nevus or Meyerson phenomenon.
  • Vesicular dermatitis or Pompholyx is a form of eczema of the palms and soles in which edema fluid accumulates to form visible vesicles or bullae.

Dermatitis or Eczema is a reaction pattern caused by inflammation of the epidermis that typically manifests as scaling or crusting of the skin.

It is classified based on the etiology into Exogenous and Endogenous eczemas.

Condition Examples/ Synonyms Description
Exogenous eczemas: external factors predispose to eczema    
Allergic contact dermatitis Nickel dermatitis, Bindi dermatitis Delayed type of hypersensitivity reaction to a previously sensitized allergen
Irritant contact dermatitis Wear and tear dermatitis, Housewives eczema Cutaneous response to the physical/toxic effects of a range of environmental exposures.
Endogenous eczemas: Internal constitutional factors predispose to eczema      
Asteatotic dermatitis Winter eczema/Eczéma craquelé ‘Crazy paving’ pattern on legs due to dry skin, flares in winter
Atopic dermatitis Eczema infantum, eczema flexurarum, Hay fever eczema, asthmatic eczema Itchy, chronic relapsing condition that often starts in early childhood (<2 years) with erythema, papules/ papulovesicles, excoriation and lichenification in flexural distribution
Nummular dermatitis  Discoid eczema Circular or oval plaques of eczema with a clearly demarcated edge
Seborrheic dermatitis
  • Dandruff/ Sebo-psoriasis/ Pityriasis capitis/ Pityrosporal dermatitis
  • Cradle cap 
 Erythematous patches with superficial scaling, affecting areas with a high density of sebaceous glands- scalp, face, central chest, and anogenital areas

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement?

choices.text: Primitive streak appears on the ventral aspect of embryonic disc
Notochordal process is mesenchymal in origin
The primitive groove and pit result from the invagination of hypoblasts
Prochordal plate determines the craniocaudal axis

questions.solution:
Notochordal process is mesenchymal in origin.

Some mesenchymal cells migrate through the primitive streak and as a consequence, acquire mesodermal cell fates. These cells migrate cranially from the primitive node and pit, forming a median cellular cord, the notochordal process.

Other options:

Option A. Primitive streak appears on the dorsal aspect of embryonic disc.

Option C. The primitive groove and pit result from the invagination (inward movement) of epiblastic cells.

Option D.

  • The cranial end of the embryo is established with the formation of prochordal plate.
  • The caudal end is established, or the craniocaudal axis is established with the formation of primitive node.
  • The craniocaudal axis and the right and left sides of the embryo is determined with the formation of the midline structure, the notochord.

questions.text: The only measure that decreases mortality in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is
questions.solution:
Home oxygen therapy and smoking cessations are the only measures known to decrease mortality in COPD.

The indications for home oxygen therapy are:

  • Resting O2 saturation (SaO2) ≤88%
  • Resting O2 saturation <90% with signs of pulmonary hypertension or right heart failure
  • Partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) ≤55%
  • Hematocrit >55%
  • Cor pulmonale

questions.text: Calculation of diffusion potential when the membrane is permeable to several ions is by _______
questions.solution:
Calculation of diffusion potential when the membrane is permeable to several different ions is by Goldman equation.

When a membrane is permeable to several different ions, the diffusion potential that develops depends on three factors:

  • The polarity of the electrical charge of each ion
  • The permeability of the membrane (P) to each ion
  • The concentrations (C) of the respective ions on the inside (i) and outside (o) of the membrane.

Goldman equation or the Goldman-Hodgkin-Katz equation gives the calculated membrane potential on the inside of the membrane when two positive ions, sodium (Na+) and potassium (K+), and one negative ion, chloride (Cl−), are involved.

 

Other options:

  • Donnan and Gibbs showed that in the presence of a nondiffusible (protein) ion, the diffusible ions distribute themselves (K+ and Cl-) so that at equilibrium their concentration ratios are equal.
  • Nernst equation→ Calculation of equilibrium potential
  • Henderson equation (Henderson – Hasselbach equation) → Calculation of pH (acid-base balance).

questions.text: All are true about Michaelis-Menten elimination except________

choices.text: Amount of drug eliminated per unit time is constant
Rate of elimination does not depend on plasma concentration
Clearance is more at lower concentrations

questions.solution:
In case of Michaelis Menten elimination (Zero order kinetics/ capacity limited elimination), half life of the drug is less at low concentration and more at high concentration.

 

First order Zero order
Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time
Rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration Rate of elimination is independent of plasma concentration
Clearance remains constant Clearance is more at low conc and less at high conc
Half life remains constant Half life is less at low conc and more at high conc
Most of the drugs follow first order kinetics Very few drugs follow pure zero order kinetics e.g alcohol

questions.text: Which of the following changes occur if you exercise at high altitude?
questions.solution:
Rise in urinary bicarbonate level is observed if a person exercises at high altitude.

Adaptation at high Altitudes:

  • The work capacity is reduced at high altitudes and this reduction is in direct proportion to the decrease in O2 uptake.
  • Immediate exposure to low PO2 at higher altitudes stimulates the arterial chemoreceptors, and this stimulation increases alveolar ventilation.
  • This immediate increase in pulmonary ventilation upon rising to a high altitude blows off large quantities of CO2, reducing the PCO2 and increasing the pH of the body fluids causing Respiratory alkalosis (not metabolic). This raised pH inhibits the brain stem respiratory center and opposes the increased ventilation. So, respiratory alkalosis will hinder maximal exercise effort.
  • To compensate for this respiratory alkalosis, kidneys reduce hydrogen ion secretion and increase bicarbonate excretion. This reduces plasma and cerebrospinal fluid bicarbonate concentration and brings the pH towards normal. It removes the inhibitory effect of alkalosis on respiration. Hence fall in blood bicarbonate facilitates the exercise effort.
  • Lactic acid levels increase which causes extreme fatigue. When there is insufficient oxygen (at high altitudes), most of the pyruvic acid is converted into lactic acid, which diffuses out of the muscle cells into the interstitial fluid and blood.

questions.text: The rhythm strip shows:
questions.solution:
The above EKG shows:

  • Heart rate > 100
  • Irregular rhythm
  • Discrete P waves with more than 3 different morphologies (black arrows)
  • Variable PR interval
  • Narrow QRS complex

Multifocal AT (MAT) is characterized by at least three distinct P-wave morphologies with rates typically between 100 and 150 beats/min.

It is the most common arrythmia seen in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). It is also seen in hypoxia and pulmonary hypertension.

There is no risk of thromboembolism in MAT.

Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT).

Rhythm is regular. Rate is 150-200 bpm. P wave may be buried in the QRS complex. PR interval may not be possible to measure. Narrow QRS complex.

PSVT can occur in a normal heart. Drug of choice for PSVT is adenosine.

Atrial fibrillation:

Rhythm is irregularly irregular. Rate is >300 bpm. P wave is absent, these irregular waves are known as fibrillation waves, which are characteristic of A. Fib.

Atrial flutter:

Rhythm is regular. Rate is 250-300 bpm. Normal P waves are replaced by saw tooth shaped waves known as flutter waves.

questions.text: False about Lateral medullary syndrome is:

choices.text: Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature on the face
Contralateral loss of pain and temperature on the trunk and limbs
Ipsilateral laryngeal, pharyngeal and palatal hemiparalysis
Contralateral upper motor neuron deficit on the trunk and limbs

questions.solution:
The false statement about lateral medullary syndrome is contralateral upper motor neuron deficit on the trunk and limbs. Corticospinal fibers are not involved in lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome).

Lateral medullary syndrome: occlusion of vertebral, posterior inferior cerebellar, superior, middle, or inferior lateral medullary arteries.

  • Descending sympathetic tract- Horner’s syndrome (miosis, ptosis, decreased sweating)
  • Ninth and Tenth nerve fibers- Dysphagia, hoarseness, paralysis of palate, paralysis of vocal cord, diminished gag reflex:

On opposite side:

  • Spinothalamic tract: Impaired pain and thermal sense over half the body, sometimes face
