questions.text: Most common mechanism involved in Angelman syndrome is ________
questions.solution:
Deletions on maternal chromosome 15 are seen in about 90% cases of Angelman syndrome.

Angelman syndrome:

Clinical features - Mental retardation, ataxia, seizures, and inappropriate laughter (Happy puppets)

Mechanisms:

  • Deletions (90%): Deletion of band q12 on the long arm of maternal chromosome 15.
  • Paternal uniparental disomy (3-7%): Inheritance of both chromosomes of a pair from one parent is called uniparental disomy. Both chromosomes are inherited from the paternal chromosome in the case of Angelman syndrome. (Prader Willi syndrome – both chromosome inherited from maternal chromosome).
  • Defective imprinting (2-4%): Defect in the resetting/maintaining of imprints during gametogenesis or after fertilization.

questions.text: True regarding colon cancer is

Left colonic cancers typically present with features of anaemia
Right colonic cancers present with diarrhea

questions.solution:
Synchronous polyps or multiple carcinomas can occur in 3-5 % of people.

Other options:

  • Left colonic cancers typically present with change in bowel habit or bleeding.
  • Right sided and proximal tumors typically present with anemia or mass.
  • Intravenous urogram is not used in colon cancer staging.  Spiral CT is the standard investigation for staging.

questions.text: A patient develops holosystolic murmur 4 days after an anterior wall myocardial infarction. It is most likely due to
questions.solution:
Apical septal rupture is the most likely cause of a holosystolic murmur that develops 4 days after an anterior wall myocardial infarction (MI).

Mechanical complications that occur 3-5 days following an MI include:

  • Papillary muscle rupture
  • Interventricular septal rupture

Papillary muscle rupture causes holosystolic murmur due to flail leaflet and mitral regurgitation. This most often occurs on the first day, with a second peak several days later.

Interventricular septal rupture causes holosystolic murmur due to Left to right shunt. It is associated with a step up in oxygen saturation from Right atrium to right ventricle.

The artery supplying the anterior wall is the left anterior descending (LAD) branch of the Left coronary artery.  It also supplies the apical septum and anterolateral papillary muscle.

Arterial trunk Frequency of involvement Region of myocardium affected
LAD 40-50%

Anterior wall of left ventricle near the apex

Anterior portion of ventricular septum

Apex circumferentially
RCA 30-40%

Inferior/posterior wall of left ventricle

Posterior portion of the ventricular septum

Inferior/posterior right ventricular free wall (in some cases)
LCX 15-20% Lateral wall of left ventricle except at the apex

Note:

  • Anterolateral papillary muscle – LAD & LCX
  • Posteromedial papillary muscle - RCA

Apical septal rupture is the best answer since the anterolateral papillary muscle receives dual blood supply from left circumflex (LCX) branch as well as LAD and is not prone to rupture.

The posteromedial papillary muscle and basal septum are supplied by the right coronary artery. The posteromedial papillary muscle rupture is the more likely to develop ischemia and rupture due to its single blood supply.

questions.text: Blunting of calyceal fornices on voiding cystourethrogram is first seen in
questions.solution:
Blunting of calyceal fornices on voiding cystourethrogram is seen in  Grade III vesicoureteral reflux.

VUR severity is graded based on the appearance of the urinary tract on a contrast voiding cystourethrogram.

It is classified into 5 grades (Grade I to V):

Grading of vesicoureteral reﬂux:

  • Grade I: VUR into a non-dilated ureter
  • Grade II: VUR into the upper collecting system without dilation
  • Grade III: VUR into the dilated ureter and/or minimal blunting of calyceal fornices
  • Grade IV: VUR into a grossly dilated ureter and blunting of calyceal fornices
  • Grade V: Massive VUR, with significant ureteral dilation and tortuosity and loss of the papillary impression

Chief judicial magistrate Upto 7 years unlimited
1st class judicial magistrate Upto 3 years 50,000 Rs
2nd class judicial magistrate Upto 1 year 10,000 Rs


The maximum sentence that a District and Sessions Judge (DSJ) may pass is a Death sentence, but it must be confirmed by the High Court.

questions.text: Sexual gratification obtained by merely feeling female body parts or articles belonging to a woman is known as ______
questions.solution:
Sexual gratification obtained by merely seeing or feeling female body parts /articles belonging to women is known as fetishism.

Fetishism is a type of paraphilia where the sexual focus is on a particular object which is associated with the human body (a shoe for example). This is found mostly in men. The object of desire usually plays a part during masturbation or sexual intercourse.

Types of Sexual perversions:

  • Eonism/Transvestism: Sexual gratification is achieved by wearing the dress of the opposite sex.
  • Fetishism: Gets sexual gratification by merely seeing or feeling female body parts, certain articles belonging to a woman, such as a sari, footwear, stockings, undergarments, hankies, hairpins, etc.
  • Masochism: Sexual gratification is obtained by being tortured by the sex partner. (opposite of Sadism)
  • Sadism: Sexual gratification is achieved by inducing pain in the sex partner.
  • Voyeurism/Peeping Tom or Scotophilia: Sexual gratification by secretly watching others getting undressed, taking a bath, or performing sexual intercourse, etc.
  • Troilism: Gets sexual gratification by watching his own wife performing, sexual intercourse with another man.
  • Nymphomaniac: A type of perversion of excessive sexual desire in a woman
  • Satyriasis: Excessive sexual desire, arousal, and drive in men.
  • Frotteurism: Gets sexual gratification by pressing/rubbing his genital part through the dresses worn, against the body parts of a female in front of him.
  • Undinism: Gets sexual gratification by watching the act of passing urine or defecating by a woman.

Related Pearl: Paraphilic disorders

DSM-5 includes eight specific paraphilic disorders:

Disorder Description
Exhibitionistic disorder Sexual arousal from exposing their genitals to a stranger
Pedophilic disorder Sexual arousal to a prepubescent individual, generally 13 years of age or younger
Voyeuristic disorder Sexual arousal from observing other's sexual activities
Sexual sadism disorder Sexual arousal upon inflicting suffering or humiliation  
Frotteuristic disorder Sexual arousal by touching or rubbing against a non-consenting person
Fetishistic disorder Sexual arousal from the use of inert objects, such as female
undergarments
Transvestic disorder Sexual arousal from cross-dressing
Sexual masochism Sexual arousal from being humiliated, beaten, bound, or made to suffer

As per ICD-11, the first five are included under paraphilic disorders. Two other subclasses in addition to this are:

  • Other paraphilic disorders involving non-consenting individuals (e.g., arousal patterns involving corpses or animals)
  • Paraphilic disorders involving solitary behaviour or consenting individuals (e.g., asphyxophilia, fetishism, fetishistic transvestism).

questions.text: Neil Mooser reaction is positive in _______.
questions.solution:
Neil Mooser's reaction is positive in case of Rickettsia typhi.

Neil Mooser reaction:

Seen in endemic typhus which is caused by R. typhi.

When male guinea pigs are inoculated intraperitoneally with blood from a case of endemic typhus, they develop a fever and a characteristic scrotal inflammation.

The scrotum becomes enlarged and the testes cannot be pushed into the abdomen.

It is also known as the tunica reaction. It is negative with R.prowazekii

questions.text: Arterial blood gas analysis of an unconscious woman shows pH = 7.39, PaCO2 = 20 mm Hg and Bicarbonate = 12 mEq/L. The acid-base abnormality is:
questions.solution:
In the above ABG, pH is within normal range (7.35-7.45). However, PaCO2 (Normal: 40 mmHg) and Bicarbonate (Normal: 22 mEq/L) are low.

Here, we start with the bicarbonate levels. Bicarbonate levels of 12 mEq/L indicates metabolic acidosis.

Now, we check whether the decrease in PaCO2 is within the expected range of compensation by applying Winter’s formula.

Expected PaCO2 = [1 .5 X HCO3-] + 8 ± 2

                        = [1.5 X12] + 8 ± 2

                        = 26 ± 2 mm Hg

Because the observed PaCO2 (20 mm Hg) is lower than the expected value (26± 2 mm Hg), there is a coexisting primary respiratory alkalosis.

Hence, the acid-base abnormality is Mixed metabolic acidosis-respiratory alkalosis.

We arrive at the same conclusion by starting with the low PaCO2 i.e respiratory alkalosis.

The expected compensation is calculated by the formula

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.2 x [decrease in PaCO2] (since it is acute, replace by 0.5 in chronic)

                           = 0.2 X (40-20)

                           = 0.2 X 20 = 4

Therefore, expected bicarbonate in compensatory metabolic acidosis is 22 - 4 = 18

The actual bicarbonate (12 mEq/L ) is lower than expected (18 mEq/L).This implies a co-existing metabolic acidosis.

Mixed metabolic acidosis-respiratory alkalosis is seen in Acute salicylate toxicity.

  • It leads to respiratory alkalosis by stimulating the respiratory center in the medulla and causing

tachypnea (with resultant low PaC02 as the C02 is blown off).

  • It then causes an anion gap metabolic acidosis by uncoupling of oxidative phosphorylation in the mitochondria leading to anaerobic metabolism (with resultant low HCO3- from acid buildup).

Hint: In compensated acid base disorders, the pH never reaches normal range, hence options A and B can be ruled out. Option D is ruled out because the primary acid base disorders are opposite to values of bicarbonate and PaC02 given.

questions.text: The most effective method of emergency contraception is
questions.solution:
The most effective method of emergency contraception is the copper intrauterine device.

Note:

  • The most effective oral emergency contraceptive is Ulipristal.
  • The most effective over-the-counter emergency contraceptive is Levonorgestrel.

The emergency contraceptive methods with their pregnancy prevention rates are tabulated below:

Method Copper intrauterine device Ulipristal pill Levonorgestrel Combined oral contraceptive
Mechanism Copper causes an inflammatory response that is toxic to sperm and ova and impairs implantation Antiprogestin, delays ovulation Progestin, delays ovulation Progestin, delays ovulation
Timing after unprotected intercourse 0-120 hours 0-120 hours 0-72 hours 0-72 hours
Efficacy 99% ≥85% 85% 75%
Contraindications Acute pelvic infection or cervicitisUndiagnosed vaginal bleedingWilson’s disease Renal/Hepatic impairmentUncontrolled Asthma None None

questions.text: A micturating cystourethrogram (MCU) in a child who presented with recurrent UTI showed the following. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Micturating cystourethrogram shows the keyhole sign
Valve is usually distal to verumontanum

questions.solution:
The given image of a micturating cystourethrogram (MCU) shows dilated prostatic urethra and transverse filling defects corresponding with the posterior urethral valves. This is suggestive of a posterior urethral valve. The pathological valve is usually distal to the verumontanum.

Posterior urethral valves are the most common cause of severe obstructive uropathy in children. The pathological valves are membranes that have a small posterior slit within them, which typically lie just distal to the verumontanum. They act as flap valves and are obstructive to antegrade urinary flow. 

Diagnosis is most commonly made antenatally with ultrasound, which demonstrates bilateral hydronephrosis above a distended bladder. Antenatal USG would also demonstrate oligohydramnios and pulmonary hypoplasia. If the diagnosis is not made antenatally, then babies typically present with urinary infections in the neonatal period or with uremia and renal failure. Clinically a poor urinary stream, dribbling, and palpable bladder (due to diverticula) can be present. The investigation of choice is micturating cystourethrography

Treatment is initially supportive by inserting a urinary catheter to relieve symptoms of obstruction. Definitive treatment involves the destruction of valves and symptomatic management of urinary tract infections. 

The below image shows the micturating cystourethrogram (MCU) with dilated prostatic urethra and transverse filling defects(constriction) corresponding with the posterior urethral valves.

The ultrasound shows the typical 'key-hole' sign in which the bladder and the proximal urethra are dilated.

Related Pearl: Causes of Hydronephrosis

Unilateral hydronephrosis

Extramural obstruction

  • Tumor from adjacent structures, e.g., cervix, prostate, rectum, colon, or cecum
  • Retrocaval ureter
  • Aberrant renal vessels
  • Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (Ormond’s disease)

Intramural obstruction

  • Congenital PUJ obstruction - most common congenital cause
  • Congenital stenosis
  • Ureterocele
  • Ureteric stricture - iatrogenic/ inflammatory
  • Neoplasm of the ureter or bladder involving the ureteric orifice

Intraluminal obstruction

  • Renal stones - most common acquired unilateral cause
  • Sloughed papilla in papillary necrosis (especially, in patients with diabetes, analgesic abuse, or sickle cell disease)

Bilateral hydronephrosis

Congenital

  • Posterior urethral valves (associated with pulmonary hypoplasia)
  • Urethral atresia
  • PUJ obstruction

Acquired     

  • Benign prostatic hypertrophy or carcinoma of the prostate
  • Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (Ormond's disease)
  • Postoperative bladder neck scarring
  • Urethral stricture
  • Phimosis

questions.text: A 35-year-old man has come with complaints of hair loss. On examination, findings as shown in the image below are seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Short, easily extractable broken hairs, known as exclamation mark hairs, are seen in the trichoscopy image above, and the scalp image below shows circumscribed, hairless, smooth patch. This is characteristic of alopecia areata.

Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease that causes non-scarring hair loss. It is a T-cell mediated inflammatory disease. It is associated with several autoimmune diseases including thyroiditis, lupus erythematosus, vitiligo, and psoriasis. It mainly affects the scalp, but can also affect the beard, eyebrows, and eyelashes. In some cases, this progresses to a total loss of scalp hair (alopecia totalis) or a loss of all hair on the body (alopecia universalis).

The lesions of alopecia areata are characterized by a smooth circumscribed patch of alopecia. It affects pigmented hair and spares white hair. It can cause fine stippled pitting of the nails and roughening of the nail bed, which is called trachyonychia. Histopathology will show perifollicular and intrafollicular T-lymphocyte infiltration.

Spontaneous remission occurs in a majority of the patients. Topical steroids like clobetasol can be useful in patchy alopecia areata. Intralesional steroids are the most effective treatment for patchy alopecia areata. A depot steroid-like triamcinolone administered by fine-needle injection into the upper subcutis can stimulate hair growth at the site. Multiple injections are usually required.

Severe and long-standing alopecia areata requires oral corticosteroids.

Other options - 

Option A: Tinea capitis is the ringworm of the scalp. The appearance may vary from a dull grey, broken‐off hairs with a little scaling to a severe, painful, inflammatory mass covering the entire scalp. Predominantly seen in children, however, adults can also be affected due to infection by T.tonsurans.

The image below shows tinea capitis.

 

Option B: Telogen effluvium can occur 2-3 months after systemic stress such as surgery or illness, but it causes diffuse hair loss, not patchy as in this patient.

The image below shows a patient with telogen effluvium.

 

Option D: Trichotillomania is a behavioral disorder characterized by compulsive pulling of hair. It presents as an area of patchy hair loss, often in a bizarre pattern. The hairs are often twisted and broken at various distances from the scalp or may be present as a uniform, coarse stubble. The scalp skin appears normal. Sites other than the scalp can also be affected, for example- eyelashes, eyebrows, beard, mons pubis, and perianal region.

The image below shows a patient with trichotillomania.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Alpha blockers is false?

choices.text: Prazosin blocks all alpha1 receptor subtypes
Silodosin is an alpha 1A selective blocker
Alfuzosin is a long acting alpha blocker

questions.solution:
• Alfuzosin: It is a short acting alpha blocker (t1/2 – 3to 5hours). It is used in the symptomatic treatment of BHP.
  • Prazosin nonselectively blocks all alpha1 receptor subtypes.
  • Silodosin is an alpha 1A selective blocker. Hence it has lesser incidence of hypotensive adverse effects.
  • Tamsulosin is a non-quinazoline benzene sulfonamide with no apoptosis effect on prostatic smooth muscle cells.
  • Terazosin and doxazosin have shown apoptosis effect on prostatic smooth muscle cells. This could be related to their quinazoline moiety.

questions.text: An intern who aspires to be a surgeon did not qualify in the entrance exam. He now claims that the syllabus changed completely this year as compared to the previous year. What is the defense mechanism being used here?
questions.solution:
Justifying his inability to qualify for the exam with an excuse that the syllabus changed completely is an example of rationalization.

Reaction formation is an unconscious defense mechanism in which the person develops a wish or impulse that is a direct antithesis to the ones that are harbored consciously or unconsciously. It develops against impulses that are unacceptable to the ego.

Projection is an immature defense mechanism and it involves attributing one's own unacknowledged feelings to others.

Repression is a type of psychological defense mechanism that involves keeping certain thoughts, feelings, or urges out of conscious awareness. The goal of this form of defense is to keep unacceptable desires or thoughts out of the conscious mind in order to prevent or minimize feelings of anxiety.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: Rapidly progressive dementia with myoclonus is seen in
questions.solution:
Prion disease (Creutzfeldt Jakob disease) is characterized by rapidly progressive dementia and myoclonus.

Lewy body dementia, Frontotemporal dementia and AIDS dementia complex are slowly progressive dementias with following unique characteristics

  • Lewy body dementia: Spontaneous parkinsonism, Visual hallucinations, fluctuating cognition
  • Frontotemporal dementia: Personality changes, disinhibition, frontotemporal atrophy
  • AIDS dementia complex: Late AIDS illness with high viral loads, neuropsychiatric symptoms such as apathy, depression, anxiety, and psychosis

questions.text: Features suggestive of benign lung nodule are
questions.solution:
Popcorn calcification on CT is suggestive of benign lung nodule.

Calcification inside the lesion is a sign of benign disease. Popcorn pattern is most common in hamartomas. CT findings characteristic of benign lesions include small size, calcification within the nodule, and stability over time.

Four patterns of benign calcification are common: diffuse, solid, central, and laminated or “popcorn.” Granulomatous infections such as tuberculosis can demonstrate the first three patterns.

Infectious granulomas arising from a variety of organisms account for 70% to 80% of benign solitary nodules in endemic areas; hamartomas are the next most common single cause, accounting for about 10%.

CT findings characteristic of malignancy include growth over time; increasing density on CT scan ; size >3 cm; irregular, lobulated, or spiculated edges; and the finding of the corona radiata sign (consisting of fine linear strands extending 4–5 mm outward and appearing spiculated on radiographs). Calcification that is stippled, amorphous, or eccentric is usually associated with cancer.

Related Pearl: Incidence of lung cancer according to histology

questions.text: Larval stage of which species of mosquito has no siphon tube ?
questions.solution:
Anopheles larvae has no siphon tube & it lies parallel to under surface of water.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia

Eggs: 100-250. 

 Laid singly. Boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star-shaped clusters.

Larval stage

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to the undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Striped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artificial collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis, Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 

Called Nuisance mosquitoes

These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called tiger mosquitoes

Day biters

They get the tiger's name from the white stripes on its legs.

 Big, black, or brown mosquitoes with sparkling wings and legs. 

 

 

Culex mosquito keeps their bodies horizontal while feeding.

 Anopheles mosquito tends to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high.

Aedes mosquito has a striped body pattern.

questions.text: Initial dose of edrophonium for diagnoisis of myasthenia gravis is_____________
questions.solution:
Edrophonium is used in Ameliorative test for diagnosing myasthenia gravis. An initial dose of 2mg is given as IV push over 15-30sec..

  • Initially, 2 mg is administered. If improvements of symptoms do not occur within 45 seconds, an additional 8 mg can be administered.
  • Improvement of strength unaccompanied by lingual fasciculations is a positive test.
  • Edrophonium is short-acting because
    • The binding site of edrophonium to acetylcholine esterase: choline subsite of the active center
    • No reaction with the enzyme: reversible binding only
    • Quaternary structure: rapid elimination

Edrophonium in Reversal of Nondepolarizing Neuromuscular Blockers:

  • 10 mg IV over 30-45 secs

questions.text: As per WHO 2017 Global Recommendation, the latest addition to the treatment of postpartum hemorrhage is:

choices.text: Late cord clamping is recommended for all births
Oxytocin 10 U IV/IM is the recommended uterotonic drug in the prevention of PPH
Intravenous oxytocin alone is the recommended uterotonic drug for the treatment of PPH
Early use of intravenous tranexamic acid is recommended in all cases of PPH

questions.solution:
The latest update in treatment of Postpartum Hemorrhage (PPH) as per WHO 2017 Global recommendations is the early use of intravenous tranexamic acid (a competitive inhibitor of plasminogen activation) is recommended in all cases of PPH.

PPH is the leading cause of maternal mortality worldwide and in India.

WHO 2012 recommendations included a conditional recommendation to use TXA for treatment of PPH when uterotonics fail to control the bleeding or the bleeding is thought to be due to trauma.

In 2017, WHO updated its 2012 PPH treatment recommendations to include use of TXA for treatment of PPH.

WHO 2017 Global Recommendation, latest addition to the treatment of PPH:

  • Early use of intravenous tranexamic acid (TXA) within 3 hours of birth for women with clinically diagnosed postpartum haemorrhage (PPH).
  • TXA should be used in all cases of PPH, regardless of the cause.
  • TXA should be administered at a fixed dose of 1 g in 10 mL (100 mg/mL) IV at 1 mL per minute (i.e., administered over 10 minutes), with a second dose of 1 g IV if bleeding continues after 30 minutes.
  • TXA should be administered via an IV route only for treatment of PPH.

WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage (2012)

  • Oxytocin (10 IU, IV/IM) is the recommended uterotonic drug for the prevention of PPH.
  • Intravenous oxytocin alone is the recommended uterotonic drug for the treatment of PPH.
  • If oxytocin is unavailable, other injectable uterotonics (ergometrine/methylergometrine or the fixed drug combination of oxytocin and ergometrine) or oral misoprostol (600 µg) is recommended.
  • Late cord clamping (performed after 1 to 3 minutes after birth) is recommended for all births.
  • Controlled cord traction is the recommended method for removal of the placenta in caesarean section.

In 2017, the results of World Maternal Antifibrinolytic Trial showed that early use of IV TXA (within 3 hours of birth and as soon as possible after onset of bleeding) reduces death due to bleeding in women with PPH, regardless of cause, and with no adverse maternal effects. In response to this new evidence, WHO updated its 2012 PPH treatment recommendations to include use of TXA for treatment of PPH. This recommendation supersedes the recommendation on TXA in the existing 2012 WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of PPH. The goals of the WHO 2017 recommendation on TXA for PPH treatment are to improve the quality of care for women with PPH and prevent maternal deaths due to PPH

Recent Update: In 2020, the WHO issued a guideline which recommends the preference of IV oxytocin over IM oxytocin for the prevention of PPH, in situations where women giving birth vaginally already have IV access. This recomendation supercedes its 2012 recommendation for the prevention of PPH.

questions.text: Bioenergetics is __________

choices.text: Conversion of energy from one form to another
Utilization of energy in metabolic processes
Synthesis of compounds by burning energy

questions.solution:
Bioenergetics means conversion of energy from one form to another.

Bioenergetics, or biochemical thermodynamics, is the study of the energy changes accompanying biochemical reactions.

questions.text: The first internal organ to putrify is  usually the __________
questions.solution:
The order of putrefaction of organs from first to last:

Larynx and trachea—> Stomach, intestine, spleen—>Liver and lungs —> Brain—>Heart—->Kidney and the bladder—>Prostate and uterus—>Bones

  • first external sign: Greenish discoloration of the skin over the region of the caecum.
  • Earliest internal change: Reddish-brown discoloration of the inner surface of vessels, especially of the aorta.
  • Sulphmethemoglobin is the agent imparting greenish color.

Related Pearl: Order of Putrefaction

  • Larynx and trachea – first organ to putrify   
  • Stomach, intestine, and spleen
  • Liver and lungs
  • Brain
  • Heart
  • Kidney and bladder
  • Prostate and uterus – virgin uterus resists putrefaction whereas uterus soon after delivery putrefies rapidly.
  • Skin, muscle, tendon
  • Bones


NOTE: This is only a generalised order of putrefaction, as each case must be assessed as per the attending factors, both endogenous and exogenous.

questions.text: All of the following drugs should be avoided in a patient on aspirin therapy except_______
questions.solution:
Mannitol may be prescribed in a patient on aspirin therapy.

Interactions OF aspirin:

  • Aspirin displaces warfarin, naproxen, sulfonylureas, phenytoin and methotrexate from binding sites on plasma proteins. It may lead to toxicity of these drugs. Its antiplatelet action increases the risk of bleeding in patients on oral anticoagulants.
  • Aspirin at analgesic doses inhibits tubular secretion of uric acid and antagonizes uricosuric action of probenecid. Tubular secretion of methotrexate is also interfered.
  • Aspirin blunts diuretic action of furosemide and thiazides and reduces K+ conserving action of spironolactone.
  • Aspirin reduces protein bound iodine levels by displacement of thyroxine; but hypothyroidism does not occur.

questions.text: The superior strait is______________
questions.solution:
The superior strait is the plane of the pelvic inlet.

The pelvis is described as having four imaginary planes:

  • The plane of the pelvic inlet—the superior strait.
    • Boundaries: Anteriorly- Horizontal pubic rami and pubic symphysis, Posteriorly Promontory and ala of sacrum and laterally linea terminalis.
    • Diameters:
      • True conjugate (11cm): extends from the uppermost margin of the symphysis pubis to the sacral promontory
      • Obstetrical conjugate (10 cm): shortest distance between the sacral promontory and the symphysis pubis.
      • Diagonal conjugate (12.5 cm): distance from the lowest margin of the symphysis to the sacral promontory
  • The plane of the midpelvis—the least pelvic dimensions.
    • Boundaries: measured at level of ischial spines
    • Diameter: Interspinous diameter (10 cm)
  • The plane of the pelvic outlet—the inferior strait.
    • Boundaries: 2 triangular areas: Common base: line drawn between the two ischial tuberosities.
    • Posterior triangle: apex is the tip of the sacrum, and the lateral boundaries are the sacrotuberous ligaments and the ischial tuberosities.
    • Anterior triangle: descending inferior rami of the pubic bones unite to form the apex
  • The plane of greatest pelvic dimension—of no obstetrical significance.

Plane of pelvic inlet and outlet

Plane of mid pelvis

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient complains of palpitations. He is hemodynamically stable. An ECG is obtained and is given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows wide complex tachycardia (QRS complexes are >120 ms in duration), with regular QRS complexes with uniform morphology in each lead. This is suggestive of ventricular tachycardia (VT). Since this patient is hemodynamically stable, the best management is IV amiodarone. 

In patients with sustained VT who are hemodynamically stable, medical treatment with intravenous amiodarone is preferred. Alternative drugs that can be given are lignocaine and procainamide. However, if the VT fails to resolve with medical management or if the patient's symptoms worsen, DC cardioversion is the next step. 

Other options:

Option A: Carotid massage has no role in the management of VT. It is used as an initial step in paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia to block the AV node and terminate the arrhythmia.

Option B: Chest compressions are done until the defibrillator is arranged to ensure some amount of cardiac output even during this period.

Option C: If a patient with VT has hemodynamic compromise due to hypotension or impaired consciousness or has pulmonary, electrical cardioversion is performed.

questions.text: Which of the following is a sellar joint?
questions.solution:
First carpometacarpal joint is a saddle joint(sellar joint).

Saddle joint(sellar joint) :

  • Articular surfaces are reciprocally concavoconvex. Movements are similar to those permitted by an ellipsoid joint.
  • Free movements are permitted around both the axes, flexion and extension around the transverse axis, and abduction and adduction around the anteroposterior axis.
  • Combination of movements produces circumduction.
  • In addition, there is some rotation (conjunct rotation) around a third axis which cannot occur independently.
  • Examples: First carpometacarpal joint, Sternoclavicular joint

 

 

The following image shows,

1 Ball-and-Socket-Joint
2 Ellipsoid Joint
3 Saddle Joint
4 Hinge Joint
5 Plane Joint

 

Other options:

A. Inferior tibiofibular joint - syndesmosis

B. Dentoalveolar joint - gomphosis/ peg and socket joint

C. Radiocarpal joint – Ellipsoid joint

questions.text: The image given below is histological section of ________
questions.solution:
The given histological image is of Jejunum.

Histology of jejunum:

  • A prominent and permanent fold of plica circularis extends into the jejunal lumen.
  • Numerous fingerlike extensions, the villi, cover the plica.
  • Between the villi are the intervillous spaces, and at the bottom of the villi are the intestinal glands located in the lamina propria. The intestinal glands (crypts of Lieberkühn) open into the intervillous spaces. In the lumen, each villus exhibits a columnar lining epithelium with striated border and goblet cells.
  • Below the lining epithelium in the lamina propria is a lymphatic nodule with a germinal centre.
  • The small intestine is surrounded by the muscularis externa that contains an inner circular smooth muscle layer and an outer longitudinal smooth muscle layer.
  • A visceral peritoneum or serosa surrounds the small intestine.

Other options:

  • Duodenum: Villi are broad, tall, and numerous, with fewer goblet cells in the epithelium. Branched duodenal (Brunner’s) glands with mucus-secreting cells in the submucosa characterize this region.
  • Ileum: Characteristic feature is the aggregations of lymphatic nodules called Peyer’s patches.
  • Colon: The colon does not have villi or plicae circulares. The outer muscle layer is condensed into three broad, longitudinal bands called taeniae coli.

questions.text: Which of the following is the content of Littre's hernia?
questions.solution:
Meckel's diverticulum is the content of Littre's hernia.

Littre's hernia is a rare inguinal hernia where Meckel's diverticulum is the content of the sac. Meckel’s diverticulum is the embryological remnant of the distal 1/3rd of the vitellointestinal duct.

Other options:

Option A: Hernia with hydrocele is Gibbon's hernia.

Option B: Amyand’s hernia is an inguinal hernia in which the hernia sac contains a normal or acutely inflamed appendix.

Option C: Maydl's hernia contains two loops of bowel arranged like a 'W'.

questions.text: Orthotopic graft is_________

choices.text: Graft from same individual placed in different location
Graft from different individual placed in the normal location

questions.solution:
Orthotopic graft is when the organ or transplanted tissue is placed in the normal anatomical location.

Related Pearl: Types of transplants

Type  Definition
Orthotopic

Organ implanted in the same anatomic location in the recipient as it was in the donor. Diseased organ is removed. Eg: heart, lung, liver, intestine
Heterotopic

Organ implanted in a different anatomic location. Diseased organ is left in place. Eg: Kidney, pancreas
Auxiliary transplantation Partial tissue from the donor is used which acts as temporary support for the recipient's injured organ, which remains in place. Eg: left lobe of liver
Autotransplant  Transfer of cells/tissues/organs within the same person. 
Allotransplant Transfer of cells/tissues/organs within the same species. 
Xenotransplant Transfer of cells/tissues/organs in a different species.
Isograft Transfer of organ or tissue within genetically identical individuals. Eg: Identical twins

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about baroreceptors?

choices.text: Increase in discharge of baroreceptors increases the cardiac output.
Afferent nerve fibres from aortic arch receptor travel via glossopharyngeal nerve.
GABA neurotransmitter is secreted by the baroreceptors.
Baroreceptors are less sensitive to mean pressure than pulse pressure.

questions.solution:
Baroreceptors are less sensitive to mean pressure than pulse pressure. A decline in pulse pressure without any change in mean pressure decreases the rate of baroreceptor discharge. This provokes a rise in systemic blood pressure and tachycardia. Hence pulse pressure is more sensitive.

Baroreceptors: Stretch receptors located in the heart and adventitia of the blood vessels

  • Types based on location
    • Carotid sinus and aortic arch receptors (high-pressure regions)
    • Cardiopulmonary receptors (low-pressure regions)
  • Nerves:
    • Carotid sinus: branch of Glossopharyngeal nerve (IX CN) called the carotid sinus nerve (sinus nerve of Hering)
    • Aortic arch receptor: branch of Vagus nerve (X CN) called the aortic depressor nerve
  • Afferent fibres from baroreceptors secrete excitatory neurotransmitter, glutamate.
  • Center for Reflex : Medulla (Nucleus Tractus Solitarius)
  • The baroreceptors are stimulated by distension of the struc­tures in which they are located, and so they discharge at an increased rate when the pressure in the carotid sinus and aortic arch rises. Increased baroreceptor discharge inhibits the tonic dis­charge of sympathetic nerves and excites the vagal innervation of the heart. These neural changes produce vasodilation, venodila­tion, hypotension, bradycardia, and a decrease in cardiac output.

questions.text: Which is the most inferior structure at the hilum of the left lung?
questions.solution:
The inferior pulmonary vein is the most inferior structure at the hilum of the left lung.

The usual vertical sequence of structures at the left hilum is (ABV)

  • Pulmonary artery
  • Principal (hyparterial) bronchus
  • Inferior pulmonary vein

 

The usual vertical sequence of right hilar structures is BABV:

  • Superior lobar (eparterial) bronchus
  • Pulmonary artery
  • Principal bronchus
  • Inferior pulmonary vein

Related Pearl: Structures related to the mediastinal surface and hilum of the lungs

Right lung:

  • Anterior to the hilum - superior vena cava and right brachiocephalic vein.
  • Posterior to this groove-  azygous vein.
  • Behind the hilum and pulmonary ligament- oesophagus.
  • The cardiac impression - right auricle, right atrium and right ventricle
  • Posteroinferiorly - inferior vena cava

Left lung:

  • The cardiac impression - left ventricle and auricle and right ventricle
  • Large groove that arches over the hilum and descends behind -  Arch of aorta and descending aorta.
  • Arrow groove that ascends to the apex- left subclavian artery
  • Superior to the aortic groove-  thoracic duct and esophagus.
  • Anterior to subclavian groove - left brachiocephalic vein.

questions.text: Expressed breast milk can be stored at room temperature for _________.
questions.solution:
Expressed breast milk can be stored at room temperature for 6-8 hours. ( 8> 6)

Expressed breast milk:

  • Glass or plastic containers should be used to collect the milk, and milk should be refrigerated.
  • Containers should be cleaned with hot soap water, rinsed, and air dried after each use.
  • Expressed breast milk can be refrigerated and used within 24 hours.
  • Frozen milk should be thawed rapidly by holding under running tepid water and used completely within 24 h after thawing.
  • Breast Milk should never be microwaved.

Note: This is a controversial question. A difference of opinion among authors is noted regarding refrigeration of expressed breast milk. Nelson's (20th ed) mentions that breast milk can be refrigerated and used within 48 hours and frozen for up to 6 months and used within 24 hours of thawing. However, Ghai (9th ed) mentions that breast milk can be refrigerated up to 24 hours and frozen at -20 degree C for about 3 months.

questions.text: Endometrial biopsy shows endometrial thickening with mildly crowded glands, nuclear rounding and visible nucleoli. The risk of progression to endometrial carcinoma is
questions.solution:
Endometrial biopsy showing mildly crowded glands with nuclear rounding and visible nucleoli is suggestive of simple hyperplasia with atypia. The risk of progression to endometrial carcinoma is 8%.

Endometrial hyperplasia is defined as endometrial thickening with proliferation of irregularly sized and shaped glands and an increased gland-to-stroma ratio. It is a pre-malignant lesion for endometrial carcinoma.

WHO Classification of endometrial hyperplasia based on histology:

  • Simple without atypia: glands are mildly crowded with normal tubular shape or mild gland-shape abnormalities. Nuclei are bland
  • Complex without atypia: glands are markedly crowded with architectural abnormalities such as papillary infoldings. Nuclei are bland.
  • Complex with atypia: glands are markedly crowded with papillary infoldings. Nuclei show variable atypia.
Type of hyperplasia Progression to cancer
Simple without atypia 1%
Complex without atypia 3%
Simple with atypia 8%
Complex with atypia 29%

questions.text: You are assessing the drinking water quality in your locality. According to WHO, the safe limit of radioactivity in drinking water is:
questions.solution:
The safe limit of radioactivity in drinking water is alpha activity 0.5 Bq/L and beta activity 1Bq/L.

Radioactivity is the number of nuclear disintegration per unit of time. Its unit of measurement is the becquerel (Bq). 1 Bq = 1 disintegration per second.

These guideline values include both naturally occurring and man-made radioactivity. When it is below the guideline values, the drinking water is considered safe and it does not need any radiological examination.

The variables that are assessed in the drinking water are physical parameters, chemical parameters, biological parameters and radiological parameters. 

Related Pearl: WHO Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality, 2017

WHO Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality, 2017

I) Physical parameters:

  Guideline values Comments
Turbidity Ideally, no visible turbidity but permissible standard is < 1.0 NTU (nephelometric turbidity units) for household drinking water. 

It describes the cloudiness of water.

  • >4 NTU – cloudiness visible to naked eye.
  • <4 NTU – measured only by instruments. 
Color Ideally, no visible color but permissible standard is <15 TCU (true color units).  >15 TCU is detectable by the naked eye. 

Taste, odor and temperature

 No health based guideline values It may be indicative of contamination and pollution. High water temperature may enhance growth of microorganisms and influence taste, odor and color.

 

II) Chemical parameters:

  Guideline values
Ammonia

No health based guideline value.

Natural levels in surface and ground water is 0.2 mg/l. Anaerobic groundwater may have up to 3 mg/l.
Aluminium up to 0.9 mg/l
Arsenic

up to 0.01 mg/l

Levels in natural water range from 1 to 2 µg/l.
Chloride

250 mg/l, as above this a detectable taste appears.

Maximum permissible level is 600 mg/l. Sodium thiosulphate can be used to dechlorinate drinking water or tap water.
Copper

up to 2 mg/l.

Excess copper in water can have gastrointestinal effects.
Fluoride

up to 1.5 mg/l. Above this, there is risk of dental and skeletal fluorosis.

Artificial fluoridation range is 0.5 to 1.0 mg/l.
Hydrogen sulphide

Taste and odor threshold is between 0.05 and 0.1 mg/litre.

A rotten egg smell of water indicates hydrogen sulphide.
Nitrates 50 mg/l as nitrate ion, to prevent methaemoglobinaemia and thyroid effects
Nitrites 3 mg/l as nitrite ion, to prevent methemoglobinemia in bottle-fed infants and general population.
pH Acceptable pH is in the range of 6.5 – 8.5.
Lead

up to 0.01 mg/l

The concentration of lead must be kept as low as possible. It is the most undesirable metal in drinking water.
Mercury

0.006 mg/l for inorganic mercury

It is nephrotoxic
Polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAH)

Benzo(a)pyrene up to 0.0007 mg/l

They are to be kept in traces as they are carcinogenic/mutagenic
Sodium Above 200 mg/l may give an unacceptable taste.
Total Dissolved Solids (TDS)

Less than 600 mg/l is generally considered palatable.

TDS consists of inorganic salts and small amounts of organic matter dissolved in water. Water is completely unpalatable above 1200mg/l.

 

III) Biological indicators:

  • Total coliform bacteria:
    • They are the primary bacterial indicators for drinking water.
    • Total coliforms are good indicators of water disinfection because they are abundant in the human intestine and are foreign to potable water.
    • E. coli is considered the best indicator of fecal contamination of water when resources for supplementary microbiological examination are limited.
    • Guidelines state that coliforms must not be detectable in 100ml of sample water. 
    • Multiple tubes method:
      • This is a test of bacteriological surveillance of drinking water for coliforms and thereby fecal contamination.
      • This test is based on the most probable number (MPN) of coliform organisms.
      • Acid and gas production from fermentation due to coliforms are observed for in multiple tubes and a presumptive coliform count is arrived at.
      • Confirmation of E. coli can be done by testing for indole formation at 44-45 degrees Celsius or by another test called Eijkman test.
    • Faecal streptococci: Their presence in water indicates recent contamination with feces and are regarded as specific indicators of human faecal pollution.
    • Clostridium perfringens: They are spore-forming organisms that are resistant to many disinfection methods. They are used as an indicator of protozoa in water and also of remote/intermittent fecal contamination. Their spores are also indicators of the effectiveness of filtration processes.
    • Viruses like enteric viruses can also be used as indicators of the disinfection process.
    • Heterotrophic plate counts measure a wide range of heterotrophic organisms including bacteria and fungi.
    • Coliphages and Bacteroides fragilis phages are evidence of fecal contamination of water. 

IV) Radiological aspects:

  • The proposed guidelines for gross alpha activity is 0.5 Bq/litre and for gross beta activity, it is 1.0 Bq/litre of drinking water.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Sibson’s fascia is incorrect?

Thoracic nerve passes through its anterior border
Subclavian artery passes above the fascia

questions.solution: The first thoracic nerve escapes through a foramen present at the posterior border (not anterior) of sibson’s fascia.

questions.text: Ether dome is located in _________
questions.solution:
Ether dome is a surgical operating Amphitheatre located in Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, Massachusetts, USA. It was the site of the first public demonstration of inhaled ether as a surgical anesthetic on October 16, 1846 (Ether day).

William Thomas Green Morton, a dentist, used ether to anesthetize Edward Gilbert Abbott. Dr. John Collins Warren then painlessly removed part of a tumor from Abbott's neck. After Abbott regained consciousness, Dr. Warren asked the patient how he felt. Reportedly, Abbott said, "Feels as if my neck's been scratched". Warren then turned to his medical audience and uttered "Gentlemen, this is no Humbug".

[All the other options are interesting because they are historic sites of landmark scientific discoveries which were publicly demonstrated. However, they may not be relevant to this exam]

  • Pouilly-le-Fort, France (May 1881): Louis Pasteur’s public demonstration of Anthrax vaccine on livestock.
  • St. Louis, Missouri, USA (March 1st 1893): Nikola Tesla’s first public demonstration of Radio
  • Menlo Park, New Jersey, USA (Dec 31,1879): Thomas Alva Edison’s first public demonstration of his incandescent lightbulb.]

questions.text: What is the most common site of thrombus formation in cases of chronic pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
The splenic vein and portal vein are the common sites of venous thrombosis in chronic pancreatitis.

Complications of chronic pancreatitis:

Intrapancreatic complications:

  • Pseudocysts
    • Duodenal or gastric obstruction
    • Thrombosis of splenic vein
    • Abscess
    • Perforation
    • Erosion into the visceral artery
  • Inflammatory mass in the head of the pancreas
    • Bile duct stenosis
    • Portal vein thrombosis
    • Duodenal obstruction
  • Duct strictures and/or stones
    • Ductal hypertension and dilatation
  • Pancreatic carcinoma

Extrapancreatic complications:

  • Pancreatic duct leak with ascites or fistula
  • Pseudocyst extension beyond lesser sac into mediastinum, retroperitoneum, lateral pericolic spaces, pelvis, or adjacent viscera

Related Pearl: Pancreas - Most Commons

M/C cause of acute pancreatitis: Gallstones

M/C cause of chronic pancreatitis: Alcohol

M/C cause of chronic pancreatitis in children: Cystic fibrosis

M/C cause of pancreatic calcification: Alcohol

M/C congenital variant: Pancreas divisum

M/C site of thrombosis in chronic pancreatitis: Splenic vein 

M/C site of pseudoaneurysm in chronic pancreatitis: Splenic artery 

Related Pearl: Chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic exocrine insufficiency: TIGAR-O classification system

Toxic-metabolic

  • Alcoholic
  • Tobacco smoking
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Chronic renal failure
  • Medications—phenacetin abuse
  • Toxins—organotin compounds (e.g., dibutyltin dichloride, DBTC)

Idiopathic

  • Early onset
  • Late onset
  • Tropical

Genetic

  • Cationic trypsinogen (PRSS1)
  • Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene (CFTR)
  • Calcium-sensing receptor (CASR)
  • Chymotrypsin C gene (CTRC)
  • Pancreatic secretory trypsin inhibitor gene (SPINK1)

Autoimmune

  • Type 1 autoimmune chronic pancreatitis
  • IgG4 systemic
  • Type 2 autoimmune chronic pancreatitis

Recurrent and severe acute pancreatitis

  • Postnecrotic (severe acute pancreatitis)
  • Recurrent acute pancreatitis
  • Vascular diseases/ischemia
  • Radiation-induced

Obstructive

  • Pancreas divisum
  • Duct obstruction (e.g., tumor)
  • Periampullary duodenal wall cysts
  • Posttraumatic pancreatic duct scars

questions.text: The sclera is the thinnest at which of the following locations?

choices.text: Anterior to attachment of the superior rectus
Posterior to attachment of the superior rectus

questions.solution:
The sclera is the thinnest posterior to the insertion of the rectus muscles.

The sclera is 1mm thick posteriorly, with maximum thickness around the optic nerve, 0.66 mm at the insertions of the rectus muscles and 0.33 mm beneath the rectus muscles and thinnest behind their insertions

questions.text: Which of the following special stains is used for staining Treponema pallidum?
questions.solution:
Treponema pallidum can be demonstrated by the Levaditi staining method.

Silver impregnation smears used for Treponema pallidum can be stained by any of the following methods:

  • Fontana's method for staining films
  • Levaditi's method for tissue sections.

The image given below shows a hepatic tissue section stained using Levaditi stain.

Albert’s stain is one of three stains that can be used to demonstrate the volutin granules (metachromatic/ Babes-Ernst granules) of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. 

The two other stains used for this purpose are Neisser’s stain and Ponder’s stain. The bacilli are usually arranged in pairs or palisades or small groups, at various angles to each other, resembling the letters V or L. This has been called the chinese letter or cuneiform arrangement.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: Number of home visits, a ASHA worker has to do after institutional deliveries ?

choices.text: No visits as it is an institutional delivery

questions.solution:
An ASHA worker has to do 6 home visits after an institutional delivery.

ASHA home visits:

  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

  • A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).
  • ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

questions.text: Congenital complete heart block is seen in
questions.solution:
Congenital complete heart block is seen in Neonatal lupus

Neonatal lupus results from the transplacental passage of maternal autoantibodies anti-Ro (SSA) and anti-La antibodies (SSB) to the fetus. This results in reaction with Ro and La antigens exposed on cardiac cells close to the atrioventricular node leading to fibrosis of the conducting system.

Clinical manifestations of neonatal lupus include: Macular rash, Prolongation of the PR interval to complete heart block, endocardial fibroelastosis, and hydrops fetalis.  

Congenital heart defects seen in other options include:

Congenital rubella syndrome is a triad of cataract, sensorineural deafness, congenital heart defects.

The congenital heart defects include:

  • Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA)
  • Peripheral pulmonic stenosis
  • Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD)
  • Myocarditis

Ebstein’s anomaly is characterized by a downward displacement of the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle resulting in a thin-walled, low-pressure “atrialized” segment of right ventricle.

  • Tricuspid regurgitation, Tricuspid atresia (Himalayan P wave) - dysplastic tricuspid valve
  • Cyanosis at birth: Right to Left shunt through foramen ovale or ASD
  • Functional pulmonary atresia
  • Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW)

Noonan syndrome: Pulmonic stenosis, ASD

questions.text: Blood supply to which area of brain is affected by an occlusion of vessel present in the Sylvian Fissure?
questions.solution:
Artery related to the lateral cerebral fissure/ Sylvian fissure is the MCA, chief artery of the superolateral surface of the brain.

Blood supply of brain:

Blood is mainly supplied by Internal Carotid artery and vertebrobasilar arteries.

Cortical supply is mainly by corical arteries (Anterior, Middle and Posterior).

Anterior Cerebral Artery

  • Course - Curves around the corpus callosum within the sagittal fissure
  • Supply - Dorsomedial frontal and parietal lobes

Middle Cerebral Artery

  • Course - Runs within Sylvian fissure
  • Supply - Lateral convexity of the cerebral cortex

Posterior Cerebral Artery

  • Course - Curves behind the midbrain
  • Supply - Occipital lobe and inferior and medial temporal lobe

questions.text: A patient  diagnosed with papillary thyroid carcinoma is found to have a mutation of the RET oncogene. Which of the following chromosomes is implicated in the pathogenesis?
questions.solution:
The mutation of RET proto-oncogene, which is located on chromosome 10, is associated with the pathogenesis of thyroid cancers.

The RET proto-oncogene encodes for receptor tyrosine kinase. It serves as a binding site for several growth factors including glial-derived neurotrophic factor and neurturin.

The mutations of RET proto-oncogene may be of various types such as germline mutations, somatic mutations or RET/PTC rearrangements.

  • Germline mutations of RET proto-oncogene are associated with MEN2A, MEN2B, familial medullary thyroid cancer (FMTC) and Hirschsprung’s disease.
  • Somatic mutations are seen in tumors derived from the neural crest such as medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC), and phaeochromocytomas.
  • RET/PTC rearrangement occurs when the tyrosine kinase domain of RET fuses with other genes by rearrangement. They are associated with papillary thyroid carcinomas (PTC). Young age and radiation exposure are risk factors for RET/PTC rearrangements.

Selpercatinib, a kinase inhibitor is recently approved by the FDA to treat three types of tumors – non-small cell lung cancer, medullary thyroid cancer, and other types of thyroid cancers in patients with a mutation in the RET gene.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman had diabetes mellitus that was not controlled with oral hypoglycemic agents. She was started on short-acting insulin to prevent post-prandial glycemia. Which of the following drug would have been used?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, insulin aspart is a short-acting insulin that has better control of meal time hyperglycemia and lower rates of postprandial hypoglycemic events. 

The short-acting insulin analogs are absorbed more rapidly from subcutaneous sites and should be injected 15 min or less before a meal. When used to treat glycemia after meals, the short-acting analogs have lower rates of hypoglycemia and improved A1c levels. It has rapid absorption and a shorter duration of action due to instantaneous dissociation into monomers. Short-acting insulin analogs are:

  • Insulin lispro is identical to human insulin except at positions B28 and B29.
  • Insulin aspart is formed by the replacement of proline at B28 with aspartic acid, reducing self-association.
  • Insulin glulisine is formed when glutamic acid replaces lysine at B29 and lysine replaces asparagine at B3.

Regular insulin has slow absorption following subcutaneous injection and should be injected 30–45 min before a meal. 

Short-acting insulins are used in the management of diabetes mellitus, diabetic ketoacidosis (regular insulin) and in non-ketotic hyperosmolar hyperglycemic coma.

Related Pearl: Insulin Classification According to Duration of Action

Inhaled insulin (2-3 hours)

  • Afrezza 

Rapid acting (3-4 hours)

  • Aspart
  • Glulisine
  • Lispro

Short acting (6-8 hours)

  • Regular

Intermediate acting (10-16 hours)

  • NPH
  • Lente

Long acting (12-24 hours)

  • Detemir
  • Glargine
  • Degludec (24-42 hours)

questions.text:
The flow-volume curve after the spirometry of a patient is given below. The most likely diagnosis in this patient is:

The dotted curve indicates the normal pattern.
questions.solution:
The given image shows an obstructive pattern on the flow-volume curve. So the most likely diagnosis of this patient is bronchial asthma.

The flow-volume curve above shows a concave upward pattern in the expiratory limb. This is also called a scooped-out or coved pattern and is observed in conditions responsible for airflow obstruction like asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, etc. 

Other options: 

Option A: Myasthenia gravis shows a restrictive pattern on the flow-volume curve. It is characterized by decreased total lung capacity and vital capacity. Hence, the loop shrinks or narrows and shifts towards the right.

Option B: Tracheal stenosis shows a fixed upper airway obstruction pattern on the flow-volume curve. In this condition, there is obstruction and limitation of airflow during both inspiration and expiration. This leads to the flattening of both inspiratory and expiratory limbs of the flow-volume loop. 

Option C: Vocal cord paralysis shows a variable upper airway obstruction pattern on the flow-volume curve. It is characterized by flattening in the inspiratory limb of the loop. 

The image below shows various patterns of flow-volume curves.

Related Pearl: PFT for obstructive vs restrictive diseases

Restrictive disease

Decreased (<80% predicted)

  • Decreased in emphysema

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with cancer risk?
questions.solution:
Schatzki’s ring is not associated with cancer risk.

Schatzki’s ring is a thin submucosal ring encircling lumen of the esophagus, usually situated at the squamocolumnar junction. It is associated with Hiatal hernia and gastroesophageal reflux. Schatzki ring is one of the most common causes of intermittent food impaction. Also known as "steakhouse syndrome" because meat is a typical instigator.

The best form of treatment of a symptomatic Schatzki’s ring in patients who do not have reflux consists of esophageal dilation for relief of the obstructive symptoms. In patients with a ring who have proven reflux and a mechanically defective sphincter, an antireflux procedure is necessary to obtain relief and avoid repeated dilation.

Eosophageal achalasia and zenker's diverticulum are linked with metaplasia and increased risk of cancer.

Pseudoachalasia is caused by an adenocarcinoma of the esophagus.

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

questions.text: When the value of Reynold’s number is 2500, the flow is said to be _______.
questions.solution:
Reynold’s number  Type of blood flow
<2000 Laminar
2000-3000 Transitional
>3000 Turbulent

Turbulent blood Flow:

The probability of turbulence is related to the velocity, diameter of the vessel, and viscosity of the blood. This probability can be expressed by Reynold’s formula.

  • Re - Reynolds number
  • v – velocity of flow – cm/sec
  • ρ – density of blood
  • D – diameter of the vessel in cm
  • µ – viscosity of blood in poise

The turbulence of flow depends upon Reynold’s number.

In the proximal portions of the aorta and pulmonary artery, Reynold’s number can rise to several thousands during the rapid phase of the ejection, which causes considerable turbulence due to the following:

  • High velocity of blood flow
  • Pulsatile nature of the flow
  • Sudden change in vessel diameter
  • Large vessel diameter

questions.text: False statement about Paul-Bunnell test is _____

choices.text: It is a heterophile agglutination test

questions.solution:
Paul Bunnel test is used to identify heterophile antibodies that agglutinate sheep erythrocytes (not ox red cells).

Paul-Bunnell test :

  • It is a heterophile agglutination test.
  • It is positive in infectious mononucleosis (glandular fever) due to EBV. In these cases, antibodies are produced that react and agglutinate sheep erythrocytes.
  • It is a diagnostic procedure for EBV.
  • Similar antigens present on dissimilar organisms are heterophile antigens.
  • Antibodies reacting with such antigens are called heterophile antibodies.
  • Serologic tests employing these heterophile antigens are called Heterophile agglutination tests.

Related Pearl: Serological tests in microbiology

Precipitation test:

  • Ascoli's thermoprecipitin test: Anthrax
  • Streptococci grouping: Lancefield technique
  • VDRL test for syphilis (slide flocculation test)
  • Kahn test for syphilis (tube flocculation test)
  • Elek gel precipitation test for C.diphtheria

Agglutination test:

  • Widal test- typhoid
  • Weil- Felix reaction- Typhus fever
  • Streptococcus MG agglutination test- Mycoplasma pneumoniae
  • Paul Bunnel test- Infectious mononucleiosis
  • Coombs test
  • Rose Waaler test- Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Microscopic Agglutination test- Leptospirosis
  • Anti streptolysin O test

Complement fixation test:

  • Wasserman reaction(syphilis)
  • Treponema pallidum immobilization test

Neutralization test:

  • Schik test for diptheria
  • Anti streptolysin O test
  • Nagler's reaction (clostridium perfringens)

questions.text: Superantigens are produced by which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
Superantigens are produced by Staphylococcus aureus, rabies virus, and Epstein Barr virus.

Superantigens: Protein molecules that activate a very large number of T cells irrespective of their antigenic specificity.

  • It binds outside the antibody binding groove directly to the lateral aspect of TCR β chain which leads to a massive release of cytokines and that causes polyclonal activation of T cells.
  • Highly resistant to proteases and to denaturation by CD4+ T cells.

Examples of superantigens:

  • Staphylococcal enterotoxins, TSST, Exfoliative toxin
  • Streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin
  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis
  • HIV (nef – negative regulatory factor)
  • CMV, EBV and rabies nucleocapsid protein

Maxillary sinus is best visualized in Water’s view and Sphenoid sinus is best visualized in Water’s view with open mouth.

Waters' view (also known as the Occipitomental view) is a radiographic view, where an X-ray beam is angled at 45° to the orbitomeatal line.

questions.solution:

questions.text: The first line therapy for ovarian induction in PCOS patients is:
questions.solution:
For women with polycystic ovary syndrome, letrozole should be considered first-line therapy for ovulation induction because of the increased live birth rate compared with clomiphene citrate.

Recent Update: Letrozole was shown to have a higher pregnancy rate than clomiphene citrate. However, until recent times (ACOG June 2018 Interim update) it was not used for the same, because of the high risk of congenital cardiac and bone malformations.

Clomiphene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM). It acts on ER receptors at the level of the hypothalamus and inhibits estrogenic negative feedback resulting in increased pulsatile GnRH secretion and subsequent release of FSH and LH. It has antiestrogenic action when endogenous estrogen levels are high (partial agonist).

Recombinant hCG has LH activity and is used in patients with hypogonadotropic amenorrhoea.

Metformin is an insulin sensitizer used in the treatment of Polycystic ovarian syndrome. Since hyperinsulinemia plays a pivotal pathogenic role in the development of PCOS, there is an increased frequency of spontaneous ovulation and regularization of menstrual cycles.

questions.text: The most sensitive agent to detect renal cortical scarring is __________
questions.solution:
Tc-99m dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) is the most sensitive agent for detection of renal cortical scarring.

DMSA is an ideal agent for the assessment of renal cortex as it binds to the sulfhydryl groups in proximal tubules at the renal cortex with longer retention than other agents.

Normal cortex shows homogeneous distribution of tracer on high-spatial resolution imaging 2–3 hours after DMSA. Renal scarring appears photopenic. It is indicated in the evaluation of acute pyelonephritis to assess for scarring.

Tc-99m diethylene-triamine-pentaacetate (DTPA) is cleared only via glomeruli with no tubular excretion. Hence used for direct measurement of GFR.

Tc-99m mercaptoacetyltriglycine (MAG3) is eliminated through kidney as via both glomeruli infiltration and tubular excretion. It is used for indirect micturating cystogram in vesicoureteral reflux and captopril renography in renovascular hypertension.

Tc-99m iminodiacetic acid derivatives are taken up by hepatocytes and excreted into bile. It is indicated in hepatobiliary studies.

questions.text: Excitatory Postsynaptic Potential (EPSP) is due to influx of____
questions.solution:
EPSP may be due to:

  • The opening of sodium channels to allow large numbers of positive electrical charges to flow to the interior of the postsynaptic cell.
  • Depressed conduction through chloride or potassium channels, or both.
  • Changes in the internal metabolism of the postsynaptic neuron to increase the number of excitatory membrane receptors or decrease the number of inhibitory membrane receptors.

Related Pearl: Comparison between EPSP vs IPSP

EPSP IPSP
EPSP is an electrical charge on the postsynaptic membrane, which is caused by the binding of excitatory neurotransmitters and makes the postsynaptic membrane more likely to generate an action potential. IPSP is an electric charge on the postsynaptic membrane, which is caused by the binding of inhibitory neurotransmitters and makes the postsynaptic membrane less likely to generate an action potential.
EPSP is caused by Influx of Na+ or Ca2+ ions IPSP is caused by Influx of Cl- ions mainly (also by efflux of K+ ions)
Results in depolarization of membrane Results in hyperpolarization of membrane
Increases the firing rate of action potential on postsynaptic membrane Decreases the firing rate of action potential on post synaptic membrane
Neurotransmitters involved – Glutamate, Aspartate Neurotransmitters involved – Glycine, GABA

 

EPSP- Excitatory PostSynaptic Potentials

IPSP- Inhibitory PostSynaptic Potentials

questions.text: Which of the following findings is seen in a patient with Brown-Sequard syndrome?

choices.text: Contralateral weakness and spasticity of muscle groups.
Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation

questions.solution:
A patient with Brown Sequard syndrome will have an ipsilateral loss of vibration sense.

Brown-sequard syndrome is caused due to hemisection of the spinal cord. It can be caused by fracture dislocation of the vertebral column, by a bullet or stab wound, or by an expanding tumor. The clinical features are:

  • Damage to the fasciculus gracilis or fasciculus cuneatus results in the loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception on the same side of the body below the level of the affected area.
  • When the spinothalamic tract is affected, there is a loss of pain and temperature sensation on the opposite side of the body, starting one or two segments below the lesion.
  • Injury to the corticospinal tract leads to weakness and spasticity in specific muscle groups on the affected side of the body.
 

 

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)
