questions.text: Triad of tenosynovitis, dermatitis and migratory asymmetric polyarthralgia is _________
questions.solution:
Disseminated gonococcal infection is a triad of tenosynovitis, dermatitis and migratory asymmetric polyarthralgia.

It occurs as a result of hematogenous spread following genital infection. The skin lesions appear in crops of 5-50. They are small, tender and initially maculopapular. A central vesicle or pustule appears and progresses to hemorrhage and necrosis. It is most commonly seen peripherally near affected joints. They may also occur on the torso and the palms and soles.

Skin lesion in disseminated gonococcal infection.

Tenosynovitis often affects the hands and fingers. Migratory polyarthralgia affects the knees, elbows, wrists, metacarpophalangeal joints and ankle joints.

Reiter’s syndrome:  Triad of arthritis, conjunctivitis, and nonspecific urethritis. It may follow infection with Chlamydia, Campylobacter, Salmonella or Yersinia.

Behcet’s disease: Triad of recurrent aphthous ulcers, genital ulcerations, and uveitis. It is an autoimmune disease of unknown etiology.

Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome: Perihepatic inflammation and adhesions with pelvic inflammatory disease. It is a rare disease seen following gonococcal infection.

questions.text: Neurotransmitter glutamate is involved in generation of_____
questions.solution:
Neurotransmitter glutamate is involved in generation of both first pain and delayed second pain (protopathic pain).

Nociceptor:

Impulses from nociceptors are transmitted via two fibre types; thinly myelinated Aδ fibres and unmyelinated C fibres.

First pain (fast pain or epicritic pain):

  • Due to activation of Aδ fibres, which release glutamate.
  • It is a rapid response and mediates the ability to localize the site and intensity of the noxious stimulus.

Delayed second pain (slow pain or protopathic pain):

  • Due to activation of C fibres, which release a combination of glutamate and substance P.
  • It is the dull, intense, diffuse, and unpleasant feel­ing associated with a noxious stimulus.

questions.text: Sensation of itch is carried by _____
questions.solution:
Sensation of itch is carried by­­­­­­­­­­ anterolateral system.

Itch:

  • Itch-specific fibers have been demonstrated in the anterolateral spinothalamic tract.
  • Itch and tickle sensation are carried by free endings of unmyelinated nerve fiber C
  • Itching can be produced by
    • Repeated local mechanical stimulation of skin
    • Chemical agents including histamine and kinins released in the skin in response to tissue damage
  • Simple scratching relieves itching because it activates large fast conducting afferents (Aβ) that gate the transmission in the dorsal horn in a manner analogous to inhibition of pain by stimulation of similar afferents (Gate control theory).

questions.text: Action of growth hormone in acute injury is ___________
questions.solution:
GH has direct lipolytic, insulin-antagonising and proinﬂammatory properties in acute injury response and aids in the setting up of the systemic inflammatory response.

Other hormonal changes: hypersecretion of prolactin and growth hormone (GH) low circulatory insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) inactivation of peripheral thyroid hormones and gonadal function.

questions.text: Endoscopic sinus surgery is indicated in all except
questions.solution:
Endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) is indicated in all of the above except acute rhinosinusitis with epidural abscess.

Endoscopic approach is contraindicated in the presence of an intracranial complication of acute infection:

  • Meningitis
  • Subperiosteal abscess
  • Epidural abscess
  • Cavernous sinus thrombosis
  • Any visual loss

Endoscopic sinus surgery is indicated in Chronic bacterial rhinosinusitis, Allergic fungal sinusitis with mycetoma, and Repair of cerebrospinal fluid leak.

questions.text: Which of the following is a formal thought disorder?
questions.solution:
Perseveration is an example of formal thought disorder.

Perseveration refers to the repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas

Formal thought disorder refers to a disorder of thought process (formulation, organization and expression of thoughts)

Delusions and Obsessions are examples of disorders of thought content. Hallucinations are a disorder of perception.

Delusion: false, fixed beliefs that are not shared by others and maintained despite being contradicted by reality or rational argument)

Obsession: unwelcome and repetitive thoughts that intrude into the patient's consciousness

Hallucination: false perception in the absence of external stimulus

Symptom Description
Circumstantiality Overinclusion of trivial or irrelevant details that impede the sense of getting to the point
Clang associations Thoughts are associated by the sound of words rather than by their meaning (e.g., through rhyming or assonance)

Derailment

(loose associations)

 A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.
Flight of ideas A succession of multiple associations so that thoughts seem to move abruptly from idea to idea; often (but not invariably) expressed through rapid, pressured speech.
Neologism The invention of new words or phrases or the use of conventional words in idiosyncratic ways.
Perseveration Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas.
Tangentiality In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic without actually answering the question
Thought blocking A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas.

Related Pearl: Classification of disorders of thought

questions.text: Which of the following arteries does not contribute to the blood supply of the stomach?
questions.solution:
The inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery does not contribute to the blood supply of the stomach. It is a branch of the superior mesenteric artery. It supplies the duodenum (second and third parts) and the pancreas (head and uncinate process).

The arterial supply of the stomach is contributed exclusively by the celiac trunk through its branches:

  • Left gastric artery - supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach
  • Splenic artery:
    • Short gastric arteries - fundus 
    • Left gastroepiploic artery - greater curvature
  • Common hepatic artery:
    • Right gastric artery - lesser curvature
    • Gastroduodenal artery - right gastroepiploic artery arises from this and supplies the greater curvature of the stomach.        

 

Clinical note: The presence of an abnormal, tortuous artery in the submucosa of the lesser curvature is called the Dieulafoy's lesion. As it is superficial, it is more vulnerable to rupture causing significant haemorrhage.

questions.text: The fracture given in the image below is associated with nerve injury. The fracture is ___________
questions.solution:
The x ray shows oblique fracture at the junction of the middle and distal thirds of humerus, associated with radial nerve injury. This is a Holstein–Lewis fracture.

Hoffa fractures are supracondylar femoral fractures. The defining characteristic is the presence of a fracture line in the coronal plane.

Salter-Harris fractures are those that affect the growth plate.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about facial nerve is true?

choices.text: Facial nerve gives rise to chorda tympani in the facial canal
A motor ganglion is located at the first bend of the facial nerve
Diagastric branch supplies anterior belly of diagastric muscle
LMN paralysis of facial nerve causes paralysis of ipsilateral lower half of face

questions.solution:
Facial nerve gives rise to chorda tympani in the facial canal.

Facial canal: Canal running through the temporal bone from the internal acoustic meatus to the stylomastoid foramen.

Branches of Facial nerve in facial canal:

  • Greater petrosal nerve
  • Nerve to stapedius
  • Chorda tympani

Other options:

  • Geniculate ganglion is located at the first bend of the facial nerve, which is a sensory ganglion.
  • Diagastric branch supplies posterior belly of diagastric muscle.
  • LMN paralysis of facial nerve causes paralysis of ipsilateral half of face (Upper + Lower).

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the muscle shown acting in the given graphic ?
questions.solution:
The muscle acting in the given graphic is the platysma which is innervated by the cervical branch of the facial nerve.

The platysma is a broad sheet of muscle in the anterior aspect of the neck.

Origin- It arises from the fascia covering the upper parts of pectoralis major and deltoid. Its fibres cross the clavicle and ascend medially in the side of the neck. Interlacing of the anterior fibres from the contralateral muscle occurs in the midine, below and behind the symphysis menti.

Attachment- The fibres attach to the symphysis menti, the lower border of the mandible, the lower lip, or cross the mandible to attach to skin and subcutaneous tissue of the lower face.

Clinical significance- During neck dissection in the subplatysmal plane, there should be careful elevation of a myocutaneous flap with the platysma and its blood supply. This reduces the risk of skin necrosis and improves wound healing.

Vascular supply- Submental branch of the facial artery and the suprascapular artery supply the platysma. The suprascapular artery is derived from the thyrocervical trunk of the subclavian artery.

Nerve supply- It is innervated by the cervical branch of the facial nerve. This branch descends close to the angle of the mandible, on the deep surface of the muscle and supplies it.

Actions- Contraction of the platysma produces tense, oblique ridges in the skin of the neck. This reduces the concavity between the jaw and the side of the neck. Platysma may assist in depressing the mandible. Due to its labial and modiolar attachments, it can draw down the lower lip and corners of the mouth in expressions of horror or surprise.

Other options:

Option A- The ansa cervicalis is a part of the cervical plexus. It supplies the infrahyoid muscles (sternohyoid, omohyoid, sternothyroid) ,except the thyrohyoid which is supplied bt the first cervical spinal nerve.

Option B- The spinal accessory nerve supplies the sternocleidomastoid and the trapezius.

Option D- The first cervical spinal nerve brances off from the hypoglossal nerve and supplies the thyrohyoid muscle.

questions.text: Nipah virus belongs to family __________.
questions.solution:
Nipah virus belongs to family Paramyxoviridae.

Togaviridae contains chikungunya virus, rubella virus.

Flaviviridae contains yellow fever, dengue virus, Japanese encephalitis virus, Hepatitis C virus.

Bunyaviridae contains sandfly fever, hantaviruses.

questions.text: Amiloride is used in the treatment of_________
questions.solution:
Amiloride is used in the treatment of Liddle syndrome.

Amiloride is an inhibitor of renal epithelial Na+ channels ( K+ sparing diuretic).

Indications:

  • Edema/hypertesion: usually in combination with thiazides
  • Lithium induced polyuria: blocks lithium transport into collecting tubules.
  • Cystic fibrosis: aerolized amiloride enhances mucociliary clearance; acts by inhibitng Na+ absorption from epithelial surfaces and increasing hydration of secretions.
  • Liddle syndome: hyperactive epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) activity is reduced.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text: Which of the following is a supraadditive drug combination?
questions.solution:
Enalapril + hydrochlorothiazide is a supraadditive drug combination.

Additive drug combination: The effect of the two drugs is in the same direction and simply adds up.

  • Aspirin+ Paracetamol: as analgesic/antipyretic
  • Nitrous oxide+ Halothane: as general aanaesthetic
  • Amlodipine + atenolol: as antihypertensive
  • Glibenclamide+ metformin: as hypoglycaemic
  • Ephedrine + theophylline: as bronchodilator

Supraadditive drug combination: The effect of the combination is greater than the individual drugs.

  • Acetylcholine+ physostigmine
  • Levodopa + carbidopa/benserazide
  • Adrenaline + cocaine/desipramine
  • Sulfamethaxozole + trimethoprim
  • Enalapril + Hydrochlorothiazide
  • Tyramine + MAO inhibitor

questions.text: Which of the following is a good prognostic factor in schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
The presence of mood disorders e.g. depression is a good prognostic factor in schizophrenia.

Young age of onset, focal neurological deficits, and family history of schizophrenia suggest poor prognosis in schizophrenia.

Good prognostic factors Poor prognostic factors
Acute onset Insidious onset
Late-onset Early-onset

Good premorbid social, sexual,

and work histories

Poor premorbid social, sexual,

and work histories
Presence of depression No depression
Positive symptoms Negative symptoms
Family history of mood disorder Family history of schizophrenia
Married Single
Catatonic schizophrenia

Hebephrenic schizophrenia

questions.text: Which of the following have the highest risk of acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Exenatide has the highest risk of acute pancreatitis.

The only hypoglycemic agents with a disproportionately increased risk of pancreatitis are the glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) mimetics, particularly Exenatide.

A lower risk of pancreatitis is seen with biguanides (metformin) and dipeptidyl peptidase 4 inhibitors (sitagliptin, vildagliptin, and saxagliptin).

questions.text: Which of the following is true about anthracoid bacilli ?
questions.solution: Anthracoid bacilli show well marked hemolysis.

questions.text: Lithium’s action on phosphatidylinositol pathway is ______
questions.solution:
• Lithium uncompetitively inhibits inositol monophosphatase and inhibits the breakdown of inositol monophosphate to form inositol. The reduction in inositol supply is considered to be one of the most important mechanisms for the mood-stabilizing action of lithium, sodium valproate, and carbamazepine.
  • Option A: Sodium valproate causes inhibition of myo-inositol-1-phosphatase synthase and results in the decrease in inositol synthesis.

questions.text:
A patient presents with fever, headache, and cough with scanty sputum. His chest radiograph shows patchy consolidation of the left lower lobe. The culture of the sputum specimen shows fried egg colonies. Which of the following statements are true regarding the causative organism?
  1. It can be cultured on PPLO broth.
  2. It has a rigid cell wall composed of polysaccharides.
  3. It belongs to the class Mollicutes
  4. The colonies can be demonstrated by Diene’s stain
  5. It utilizes glucose or arginine as the major source of energy.
questions.solution:
The causative organism based on the given clinical scenario showing fried egg colonies on culture points to Mycoplasma pneumoniae. It is devoid of cell walls.

Mycoplasmas are the smallest microorganisms that are pleomorphic and lack cell walls. There are 4 species that are of importance to humans.

  • Ureaplasma urealyticum
  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae
  • Mycoplasma hominis
  • Mycoplasma genitalium

Mycoplasmas, which belong to the class Mollicutes, derive their primary source of energy from glucose or arginine. Ureaplasmas are an exception as they have the capability to hydrolyze urea. To cultivate these bacteria, complex media like PPLO broth are employed, consisting of agar, broth, and biphasic media with enriching substances such as yeast dialysate and horse serum. Penicillin and thallium are added to prevent the growth of other bacteria.

Mycoplasma colonies exhibit a characteristic fried egg appearance, with a central opaque granular region that extends into the depth of the medium, surrounded by a flat, translucent outer zone. For a detailed examination, the Dienes method involves cutting a block of agar containing the colony and placing it on a slide. A cover slip is then applied, onto which an alcoholic solution of methylene blue and azure has been dried.

These bacteria primarily cause pneumonia and genital infections. Ureaplasma urealyticum possesses a unique ability to hydrolyze urea and is responsible for non-gonococcal urethritis. It can exhibit resistance to commonly used antibiotics such as tetracycline and doxycycline.

The image given below shows fried-egg colonies of mycoplasma.

questions.text: Subterminal spores are seen in all except _______.
questions.solution:
Oval and terminal (tennis racket shaped) spores are seen in cl.tertium.

The genus clostridium consists of Gram Positive, anaerobic, spore forming bacilli. 
The spores are wider than the bacillary bodies, giving the bacillus a swollen appearance, resembling a spindle. Hence the name clostridium (Kloster, meaning spindle).

The shape and position of spores:

  1. Central or equatorial:  cl.bifermentans
  2. Subterminal: cl.perfringens, cl.novyi, cl.botulinum
  3. Oval and terminal (tennis racket shaped): cl.tertium, cl.difficle
  4. Spherical and terminal (drumstick appearance): cl.tetani

questions.text: Indicators of incurability in stomach cancer are all except__________
questions.solution:
Involvement of 7-15 Nodes is stage N3A, which does not fit the criteria for incurability.

Unequivocal evidence of incurability is

  • haematogenous metastases
  • involvement of the distant peritoneum
  • N4 nodal disease
  • disease beyond the N4 nodes
  • Fixation to structures that cannot be removed

Related Pearl: TNM staging of gastric carcinoma

T0

Tumor invades lamina propria or muscularis mucosae

T1b

Tumor invades muscularis propria

T4

questions.text: To avoid overcrowding, what is the maximum number of people allowed to live in a house with 2 rooms?
questions.solution:
Maximum of 3 people are allowed to be living in a house of 2 rooms to avoid overcrowding.

Note :

  • Baby under 12 months is not counted
  • Children b/w 1 to 10 years is counted as half a unit

Overcrowding:

Overcrowding is considered to exist if 2 persons over 9 years of age, not husband and wife, of opposite sexes are obliged to sleep in the same room.

The accepted standards against overcrowding are as follows.

No of rooms  No of persons
1 room 2 persons
2 rooms 3 persons
3 rooms 5 persons
4 rooms 7 persons
5 rooms 10 persons (1 rooms for every 2 additional persons)

The floor space standards against overcrowding are as follows.

Area No of persons
110 sq. ft. and more 2 persons
90 – 100 sq. ft. 1 ½ persons (Children from 1 – 10 are counted as a half unit)
70 – 90 sq. ft. 1 person
50 – 70 sq. ft. ½ person

questions.text: A patient involved in a fire accident presents with burns that involve the reticular layer of the dermis. What is the degree of burn?
questions.solution:
Deep second-degree burns extend up to the reticular layer of the dermis. 

According to the depth and the extent of tissue damage, burn injuries can be classified as follows:

  • First-degree burns: In this, there is damage to the epidermis. These injuries are extremely painful but do not blister. They have a normal capillary refilling time.
  • Second-degree burns (Partial-thickness burns): In this, there is damage to the epidermis and dermis. Depending on the extent of the dermal involvement, they can further be divided into superficial or deep:
    • Superficial partial-thickness burns: They involve the epidermis and upper part of the dermis (papillary). These injuries are red, moist, and extremely painful and blisters are present. The capillary return is clearly visible when the injured skin is blanched.
    • Deep partial-thickness burns: They involve the epidermis and the deeper dermis. These injuries are less painful and some sensation is preserved. The capillaries do not blanch on pressure.
  • Third-degree burns:  In this degree, there is damage to the epidermis, dermis, and subcutaneous tissue. The injuries have a hard leathery feel with the absence of sensation.
  • Fourth-degree burns: In this degree, there is damage to the underlying soft tissues as well

Related Pearl: Degrees of Burns

  First-degree Second-degree (superficial partial thickness) Second-degree (deep partial thickness)

Third-degree (full thickness)

 Fourth-degree (full thickness)
Depth Epidermis Epidermis + superficial dermis Epidermis + most of the dermis (most skin appendages destroyed) Entire dermis + subcutaneous tissue Involves connective tissue, muscle, possibly bone
Colour/texture Red Red, edematous, and blistered Pale, mottled Hard, leathery Pale, dry, charred
Blanchable (capillary refill)  Yes Yes No No No
Pain Painful Painful Painful (only on pinprick) No No
Healing 5-10 days; no scar 10-14 days; no or minimal scar  4-8 weeks, often with scarring and contractures Prolonged, with scarring and contractures, requires skin grafting Requires skin grafting or even amputation.

questions.text: Contrast enhanced CT in the condition shown below will reveal

choices.text: Luminal filling defect in the pulmonary artery
Luminal filling defect in the pulmonary vein
Multiple nodules in peripheral lung parenchyma
Multiple nodules in central lung parenchyma

questions.solution:
The above X-ray is characteristic of pulmonary embolism. The CECT in this condition will show luminal filling defect in the pulmonary artery.

X ray findings shown above are:

  • Hampton's hump- A peripheral wedged-shaped density above the diaphragm with convexity towards hilum (black arrow).
  • Palla's sign- enlarged right descending pulmonary artery

Pulmonary vein is not affected in Bronchogenic carcinoma presents can present as multiple rounded or spiculated nodules in lung parenchyma. The X-ray given is not suggestive of bronchogenic carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

questions.text: Haab's striae and Vogt's striae are respectively seen in ________
questions.solution:
Haab's striae are seen in Buphthalmos and and Vogt's striae are seen in keratoconus.

NOTE :

  • Haab’s stria are tears and breaks in descemet’s membrane seen in Buphthalmos whereas Vogt's striae are vertical (rarely horizontal) fine, whitish lines in the deep/posterior stroma and Descemet's membrane commonly found in patients with keratoconus.

Related Pearl: Vogt's striae

The above image shows “Vogt’s Striae” which are characteristically seen in Keratoconus.

  • Vogt's striae are vertical (rarely horizontal) fine, whitish lines in the deep/posterior stroma and Descemet's membrane commonly found in patients with keratoconus.
  • It may be asymmetric depending on the degree of keratoconus in each eye.
  • It is considered that there is a positive correlation between the orientation of the lines with the steepest axis of the cornea and the mechanism is thought to be related to mechanical stress forces on collagen lamellae radiating from the cone apex.
  • The striae can temporarily disappear with external pressure to the globe.

questions.text: Epidemiological transition refers to shift from_________

choices.text: Low economic state of a country to high economic state of the country
Low birth rate to high birth rate within in the country
Major cause of death from communicable diseases to chronic non communicable diseases
High death rate in the country to low death rate

questions.solution: Epidemiological transition refers to shift from Major cause of death from communicable diseases to chronic non communicable diseases

questions.text: Lemierre’s syndrome is_________

choices.text: Triad of impotence, buttock claudication, and absence of the femoral pulses
Shooting pain in lower extremities on flexing the neck
Obstructive jaundice caused by a periampullary duodenal diverticulum
Septic thrombophlebitis in the internal jugular vein

questions.solution:
Lemierre’s syndrome is septic thrombophlebitis in the internal jugular vein.

  • This is a rare and potentially fatal complication of oropharyngeal infection. The organism is typically a fusiform bacillus.
  • Presents with severe neck pain, septicemia or a prolonged fulminant course in a patient with infection in the upper aerodigestive tract.

The other options correspond to sound alike signs/syndromes.

  • Leriche syndrome: Triad of impotence, buttock claudication, and absence of the femoral pulses seen in aortoiliac occlusive disease.
  • Lhermitte's sign: Shooting electric shock-like sensations in the lower extremities when the neck is maximally flexed in patients with cervical radiculopathy.
  • Lemmel syndrome: Obstructive jaundice caused by a periampullary duodenal diverticulum compressing the intrapancreatic part of the common bile duct with resultant upstream dilatation of the extra- and intrahepatic bile ducts.

questions.text: Procedural memory is a type of_______
questions.solution:
Procedural memory is a type of non declarative memory.

Implicit memory/Non-declarative memory: It does not require being conscious or aware. E.g., Remembering how to brush your teeth.

They are of 4 types:

  • Procedural memory: It includes skills and habits, which, once acquired, become unconscious and automatic. The areas involved are striatum, cerebellum, motor cortex.
  • Priming involves the neocortex.
  • Non-associative learning (includes habituation and sensitization, e.g., Byhearting facts)
  • Associative learning: classical and operant conditioning

Explicit/declarative memory: Memory of words, rules, language, etc. associated with consciousness/awareness. E.g., recalling first day in school.

They are of two types:

  • Semantic memory (facts) e.g., Knowing capital of India: Parts of brain involved are temporal cortex and prefrontal cortex
  • Episodic memory (events) e.g., Recalling first day in college: Parts involved are hippocampus, medial temporal lobe and neocortex.

questions.text: Which is not an indication for damage control surgery?

choices.text: Inability to approximate the abdominal incision
Penetrating injury to colon with hemodynamically instability

questions.solution:
Metabolic acidosis (pH<7.2) is an indication for damage control surgery., not alkalosis.

Damage control surgery is done in critically injured patients, which aims at

  1. Controlling hemorrhage
  2. Control contamination

Patients who have massive injuries are likely to develop the triad of coagulopathy, hypothermia, and metabolic acidosis, which puts them at risk of death from curative surgery.

Related Pearl: Damage Control Surgery

Five stages of damage control surgery:

1. Patient selection
2. Control of hemorrhage and control of contamination
3. Resuscitation continued in the intensive care unit
4. Deﬁnitive surgery
5. Abdominal closure

Phases of Damage Control Surgery:

Phase 0: Identification of patient for damage control surgery in emergency room
Phase 1: Emergency laparotomy to stop bleeding and prevent contamination
Phase 2: ICU care for resuscitation
Phase 3: Re-laparotomy for definitive repair

Indications for damage control surgery:

Anatomical

  • Inability to achieve haemostasis
  • Complex abdominal injury, e.g. liver and pancreas
  • Combined vascular, solid and hollow organ injury, e.g. aortic or caval injury
  • Inaccessible major venous injury, e.g. retrohepatic vena cava
  • Demand for non-operative control of other injuries, e.g. fractured pelvis
  • Anticipated need for a time-consuming procedure

Physiological (decline of physiological reserve)

  • Temperature <34ºC
  • pH <7.2
  • Serum lactate >5 mmol/L (normal is <2.5 mmol/L)
  • Prothrombin time (PT) >16 s
  • Partial thromboplastin time (PTT) >60 s
  • Blood transfusion approaching 15 units
  • Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg for >60 min

Environmental

  • Operating time >60 min
  • Inability to approximate the abdominal incision
  • Desire to reassess the intra-abdominal contents (directed relook)

questions.text: Sudden abdominal distension 24-48 hours after renal injury _______.
questions.solution:
• Sudden abdominal distension 24–48 hours after renal injury is called meteorism. It is due to retroperitoneal bleeding from renal artery or vein injury. IVP or contrast CT is performed to assess if functional kidney is present, so that a decision about nephrectomy can be made.
  • Severe delayed haematuria: Sudden haematuria between the third day and third week after trauma in a recovering patient is caused by a dislodged clot.

questions.text: True about handgrip maneuver is _______.

choices.text: Delays click of mitral valve prolapse
Decreases intensity of Aortic regurgitation murmur

questions.solution:
The true statement about handgrip maneuver is it delays the click of mitral valve prolapse.

Maneuvers like sustained handgrip, simultaneous inflation of blood pressure cuffs above the systolic in both upper limbs, infusion of vasopressors increase the systemic vascular resistance (Afterload).

The increased afterload increases the left ventricular end-diastolic volume. The enhanced ventricular volume helps to maintain tension along the chordae and to keep the mitral valve shut for longer. Hence, the click and murmur of MVP are delayed.

Murmurs that increase in intensity with sustained handgrip:

  • Mitral regurgitation
  • Ventricular septal defect
  • Aortic regurgitation

(Increased afterload increased reverse flow across valve)

Murmurs that decrease in intensity with sustained handgrip:

  • Aortic stenosis
  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

(Gradient across outflow increases, therefore flow decreases)

Related Pearl: Dynamic auscultation of murmurs

Bedside Manoeuvre Effect

Inspiration

(↑venous return to right atrium)
  • ↑ intensity of right-sided sounds

Handgrip

(↑afterload )
  • ↑ intensity of MR, AR, and VSD murmurs
  • ↓ hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and AS murmurs
  • MVP: delayed onset of click/murmur

Valsalva-Phase II, standing up

(↓ preload)
  • ↓ intensity of most murmurs (including AS)
  • ↑ intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • MVP: earlier onset of click /murmur

Rapid squatting

(↑venous return,↑preload,
↑ afterload)
  • ↓intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • ↑ intensity of AS, MR, and VSD murmurs
  • MVP: later onset of click/murmur

questions.text: Peripheral nuclei can be seen in _______.

questions.text: Ligament most commonly affected in elbow dislocation is_________
questions.solution:
Elbow dislocation results in injury to the joint capsule and rupture of the lateral collateral ligament.

The medial collateral ligament can also be involved.

Important points about elbow dislocation:

  • Most common joint to dislocate in children
  • Coronoid process is posterior to humerus
  • Most prominent part is olecranon in dislocated elbow
  • Myositis ossificans is a late complication
  • May be associated with soft tissue injury involving brachial artery, ulnar nerve(most common), median and radial nerve.

questions.text: Stain used for copper is ________
questions.solution:
Rhodamine stain is used for staining copper.

Copper deposition in hepatocytes can be demonstrated by special stains:

  • Rhodamine stain for copper
  • Orcein stain for copper-associated protein

Rhodamine stain:

questions.text: All are indications for cholecystectomy in gallbladder polyp except________
questions.solution:
Polyp over 10 mm is an indication for cholecystectomy.

Related Pearl: Indication for Cholecystectomy in Gallbladder Polyp

  • Polyp of size >10 mm
  • Evidence of polyp growth on serial ultrasonography

questions.text: A patient underwent inguinal hernia repair surgery, during which the nerve marked in the image below was injured.  Which of the following structures does this nerve supply?

choices.text: Skin on lateral aspect of thigh

questions.solution:
The nerve marked in the image is the genitofemoral nerve (L1, L2), which can be injured during inguinal hernia repair. Among the given structures, it supplies the cremaster muscle.

Branches of genitofemoral nerve:

  • Femoral branch:

    • Skin of mons pubis and labium majus in females

Related Pearl: Lumbar Plexus

Lumbar plexus is formed by the divisions of the first four lumbar nerves (L1-L4) and from contributions of the subcostal nerve (T12), which is the last thoracic nerve.

questions.text: Colorectal cancer is associated with infective endocarditis due to
questions.solution:
Streptococcus gallolyticus infective endocarditis is associated with underlying colorectal cancer.

If S. gallolyticus (previously bovis) is isolated in infective endocarditis, the patient must be screened for occult gastrointestinal malignancy.

questions.text: All of the following are used in the treatment of digoxin toxicity except______
questions.solution:
Cardioversion by DC shock is contraindicated because severe conduction defects may be unmasked in the digitalis intoxicated heart.

Treatment of digoxin toxicity:

  • Further doses of digoxins must be stopped at the earliest sign of toxicity if the manifestations are only extracardiac.
  • For tachyarrhythmias :
    • When caused by chronic use of digitalis and diuretics (both induce K+ depletion)—infuse KCl 20 m.mol/hour (max. 100 m. mol) i.v. or give orally in milder cases. High extracellular K+ decreases binding of the glycosides to Na+K+ATPase and K+ tends to antagonize digitalis induced enhanced automaticity.
    • When toxicity is due to acute ingestion of large doses of digoxin, plasma K+ may be high; it should not be given from outside.
  • For ventricular arrhythmias Lidocaine i.v. is the drug of choice. It suppresses the excessive automaticity, but does not accentuate A-V block. Quinidine, procainamide and propafenone are contraindicated.
  • For supraventricular arrhythmias Propranolol may be given i.v. or orally depending on the urgency.
  • For A-V block and bradycardia: cardiac pacing is recommended. Atropine 0.6–1.2 mg i.m.  can also be used.
  • Digoxin antibody can also be used in digoxin toxicity.

questions.text: Nitrogenous base with amine (-NH2) group on 2nd carbon is _________
questions.solution: Guanine has amine group on 2nd carbon.

questions.text: Reactionary hemorrhage in tonsillectomy occurs
questions.solution:
Reactionary hemorrhage occurs within 24 hours of surgery

Primary hemorrhage - Occurs at the time of operation

Reactionary hemorrhage - Occurs within a period of 24 hours.

Secondary hemorrhage - Usually seen between the fifth to tenth postoperative days

questions.solution:

questions.text: Feedback uptake of surfactant by type II alveolar epithelial cells is regulated by
questions.solution:
Feedback uptake of surfactant by the type II alveo­lar epithelial cell is regulated by surfactant protein type A.

Surfactant:

It is the fluid lining the alveoli. It is produced by type 2 pneumocytes. It is mainly made up of phospholipids and proteins. The majority of the phospholipid is phosphatidylcholine. The second most abundant phospholipid is phosphatidylglycerol (PG). 

The important surfactant proteins (SP) present in the surfactant are:

  • SP-A is a large glycoprotein with a collagen-like domain. It regu­lates the feedback uptake of surfactant by the type II alveo­lar epithelial cells that secrete it.
  • SP-B and SP-C are smaller proteins. They form the film of the surfactant.
  • SP-D is a glycoprotein. It plays an important role in the organization of SP-B and SP-C into the surfactant layer.

The important function of the surface is to reduce surface tension. The pressure required for the expansion of alveoli is directly proportional to the surface tension present over the alveolar sacs. Surfactant reduces this surface tension and thereby reduces the pressure required to expand lungs. It also prevents pulmonary edema.

Clinical correlate- Surfactant production starts around 20 weeks of life and peaks at 35 weeks gestation. Deficiency of surfactant leads to respiratory distress syndrome. This is common in preterm infants.

questions.text: Sign shown below is seen in _________.
questions.solution:
The sign shown above is bullet shaped vertebrae and is seen in mucopolysaccharidosis.

The Plain X-ray of dorsolumbar spine shows anterior beaking of vertebral bodies called bullet shaped vertebrae.

It is seen in the following conditions: Mucopolysaccharidosis (Morquio disease, Hurler disease), achondroplasia, congenital hypothyroidism

Spine X ray findings in

Spondylolisthesis: Scottie dog with collar

Osteogenesis imperfecta:

  • Basilar invagination
  • Wormian bones
  • Kyphoscoliosis
  • Vertebral compression fractures
  • Codfish vertebrae
  • Platyspondyly

Sickle cell anemia – chronic bone infarcts, osteonecrosis

Spondylolisthesis- Bilateral oblique views showing bilateral pars defect, which has the appearance of a Scottie dog with a collar

Sickle cell anemia- Lateral view of the spine shows angular depression of the central portion of each upper and lower endplate due to osteonecrosis.

questions.text: Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) and Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) differ in all of the following aspects except _________
questions.solution:
PT and aPTT levels are normal in both TTP and HUS.

HUS and TTP:

  • TTP is defined as the pentad of fever, thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, transient neurologic deficits, and renal failure.
  • HUS is also associated with microangiopathic hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia but is distinguished by the absence of neurologic symptoms, the prominence of acute renal failure, and its frequent occurrence in children.
  • In both conditions, intravascular thrombi cause microangiopathic hemolytic anemia and widespread organ dysfunction.
  • In HUS, microthrombi mainly contain fibrin whereas in TTP, these are composed of platelet aggregates, fibrin, and VWF.
  • PT and aPTT are usually normal.

 

Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura
  • Deficiency of ADAMTS13
    • Inherited (Schulman-Upshaw syndrome)
    • Acquired (autoantibodies)

Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome

Typical:

  • Escherichia coli strain O157: H7 infection
  • Endothelial damage by Shiga-like toxin
Atypical:
  • Alternative complement pathway inhibitor deficiencies (complement factor H, membrane cofactor protein (CD46), or factor I)
  • Inherited
  • Acquired (autoantibodies)
Miscellaneous associations
  • Drugs (cyclosporine, chemotherapeutic agents)
  • Radiation, bone marrow transplantation
  • Infections (HIV, pneumococcal sepsis)
  • Conditions associated with autoimmunity (SLE, lymphoid neoplasms)

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is breathing quietly. He then inhales as much air as possible and exhales as much air as he can, producing the spirogram shown in the figure. What is his expiratory reserve volume (in liters)?
questions.solution:
Expiratory Reserve Volume = Functional Residual Capacity - Residual Volume

In the given spirogram,

  • Functional Residual Capacity = 3L
  • Residual Volume = 1L 

Therefore,

Expiratory Reserve Volume = Functional Residual Capacity – Residual Volume = 3-1 = 2

Note:

The residual volume is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after the most forceful expiration.

The functional residual capacity equals the expiratory reserve volume plus the residual volume. This capacity is the amount of air that remains in the lungs at the end of normal expiration

The expiratory reserve volume is the maximum extra volume of air that can be expired by forceful expiration after the end of a normal tidal expiration.

Related Pearl: Lung volumes and capacities

Measurement

Description

Normal Value

Tidal volume (TV)

The amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration (or the amount that moves out with each expiration) during quiet breathing

500–750 mL.

Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)

The air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in excess of the TV

∼3 L

Expiratory reserve volume (ERV)

The volume expelled by an active expiratory effort after passive expiration

∼1.1 L

Residual volume (RV)

The air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort

∼1.2 L

Total lung capacity (TLC)

IRV+TV+ERV+RV

∼5.8 L

Vital capacity (VC)

IRV+TV+ERV

∼4.5 L

Inspiratory capacity (IC)

TV+IRV

∼3.5 L

Expiratory capacity (EC)

TV+ERV

∼1.6 L

Functional residual capacity (FRC)

ERV+RV

∼2.3 L

questions.text: Leopard skin sign on MRI brain is seen in all except__________
questions.solution:
Leopard skin sign on MRI brain is seen in all except Pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration.

Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease, Metachromatic leukodystrophy and Spastic ataxia of Charlevoix have a specific pattern of demyelination with sparing of perivascular white matter.

The spared perivascular white matter is seen as dark spots or dark linear areas against a background of bright affected white matter, giving the appearance of the skin of a leopard.

Leopard skin sign (A): linear hypointensities radiating from the ventricular margins within hyperintense periventricular white matter and the centrum semiovale on T2W MRI images.

Pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration (PKAN/ Hallervorden–Spatz syndrome) shows Tiger-eye sign on MRI brain.

Tiger eye sign is markedly low signal intensity of the globus palladi on T2W MRI images surrounding a central, small hyperintense area.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman at 28 weeks of gestation presents with chills and cyclical fever with sweats. She is diagnosed with P. falciparum malaria infection. Which of the following regimens will you prescribe her?
questions.solution:
A 28 week pregnant female suffering from falciparum malaria should be treated with Artemesinin based combination therapy.

Treatment of malaria in pregnancy:

  • 2nd and 3rd trimester: ACT is preferred as quinine can cause increased risk of hypoglycemia.
  • 1st trimester: Drug of choice for falciparum malaria during 1st trimester of pregnancy is quinine combined with clindamycin for 7 days. Artemisinin based combination therapy (ACT) is not recommended during 1st trimester of pregnancy because of lack of safety data.

Doxycycline is not indicated in pregnancy.

questions.text: Best indicator for excitability of tissue is______
questions.solution:
Chronaxie is a better index than rheobase and utilization time for comparing excitability of a tissue.

  • Rheobase is the minimum intensity (strength/magnitude) of stimulation required to generate an action potential when the stimulation is of infinite duration.
  • Utilisation time is the minimum time (duration) for which the rheobase has to be applied for excitation of tissue.
  • Chronaxie is the minimum time (duration) for which a stimulus double the strength of rheobase has to be applied for excitation of tissue.

questions.text: Highly stable vaccine vial monitor(VVM) is ______________
questions.solution:
VVM 30: High Stability

VVM 14: Medium Stability

VVM 7: Moderate Stability

VVM 2: Least Stable

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: Neuroimaging in post-traumatic stress disorder shows ________.
questions.solution:
Decreased hippocampal volume is seen on neuroimaging in post-traumatic stress disorder.

Disease Neuroimaging finding
Autism Increased total brain volume
Obsessive-compulsive disorder Abnormalities in orbitofrontal cortex and striatum
Panic disorder Decreased volume of amygdala 
Post-traumatic stress disorder Decreased hippocampal volume 
Schizophrenia Enlargement of cerebral ventricles

questions.text: Selenium acts as a cofactor for ___________
questions.solution:
Selenium act as a cofactor for glutathione peroxidase.

Glutathione peroxidases:

  • Also known as selenoproteins.
  • Selenium-containing glutathione peroxidases help transform hydrogen peroxide to harmless water (Anti –oxidant action)
  • Selenium deficiency results in Impaired function of glutathione peroxidases. As a result, destructive hydrogen peroxide breaks down into even more dangerous hydroxyl radical which damages cell membranes and cell DNA leading to serious disease

questions.text: In the lac operon model, a high level of transcription takes place only when____

choices.text: Both Glucose and Lactose are present
Glucose is present and Lactose is absent
Both Glucose and Lactose are absent
Glucose is absent and Lactose is present

questions.solution:
In the lac operon model, a high level of transcription takes place only when Glucose is absent and lactose is present.

Lac operon is an operon required for the transport and metabolism of lactose in E. coli and some other enteric bacteria.

Lac operon concept

Lac operon model - It is the regulation of lactose metabolism by the intestinal bacterium E. coli. It is switched on when the bacteria have to utilize lactose. Otherwise, it is switched off. The genetic arrangement of the lac operon helps coordinate the expression of the three main enzymes (5, 6, 7 below) involved in lactose metabolism. The genes include:

  1. lac I - It codes for the repressor protein that prevents transcription of the distal structural genes, lac Z, lac Y, and lac A by interfering with the binding of RNA polymerase to the promoter.
  2. CRE (cAMP response element)- It is activated by binding the cyclic AMP activator protein (CAP). When activated, it increases the binding of RNA polymerase and increases gene expression.
  3. Promoter site- It is the site where RNA polymerase binds the gene for transcription. 
  4. Operator site- It is the site where repressor protein binds.
  5. lac Z gene- It codes for β-Galactosidase that hydrolyzes lactose to galactose and glucose. 
  6. lac Y- encodes for lactose permease which increases the permeability of lactose into the cells
  7. lac A- encodes for thiogalactoside transacetylase 

The image below shows the genetic arrangement of the lac operon and the process of regulation of lactose metabolism

questions.text: What is the best way to describe the dermatological lesion seen in the image below?
questions.solution:
The skin lesion in the image is of chronic plaque psoriasis, which is best described as polycyclic.

Well-demarcated, erythematous plaque with silvery scales characteristic of chronic plaque psoriasis. Polycyclic skin lesions are present as circles that have merged together. In severe cases of psoriasis, plaques grow and merge into one another forming polycyclic lesions.

Reticulate skin lesions have a fine lace-like pattern. E.g. Oral lichen planus- Wickham striae in the oral cavity. They are fine white lines in a lacy or fern-like pattern that cross the plaques in lichen planus.

 

The image given below shows oral lichen planus with Wickham striae in the oral cavity. 

Annular skin lesions have a ring-like morphology with peripheral activity and an area of central clearing. E.g. Tinea Corporis and Granuloma annulare.

The image given below shows dermatophytosis or ringworm with a mildly raised boarder and central clearing, showing an annular morphology.

Target-like or bull’s eye lesions present as concentric circles of erythema. E.g. Erythema multiforme, erythema migrans

The image given below shows the characteristic target-like Lyme disease rash called erythema migrans. This rash often manifests itself in a bull's-eye appearance and is observed in about 80% of Lyme disease patients.

questions.text: A 67-year-old patient presented with swelling around the knee, restriction of movement and minimal or no pain. The x-ray of the knee is given below. The diagnosis is _________.
questions.solution:
The x-ray depicts severe joint destruction and instability, seen on (a) varus stress (b)Neutral (c) valgus stress on the patient's knee joint. There is minimal pain and this indicates a neuropathic cause like Charcot arthropathy.

Diabetes is the most common cause of Charcot arthropathy, while tertiary syphilis was one of the common causes previously.

Rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis and psoriatic arthropathy present with pain.

questions.text: All of the following sites are present in the alpha unit of Na-K- ATPase except ______.
questions.solution:
Glycolysation site is present in beta subunit (not alpha) of Na-K- ATPase.

Na-K-ATPase: It catalyzes the hydrolysis of ATP to adenosine diphosphate (ADP) and uses the energy to extrude three Na+ from the cell and take two K+ into the cell for each molecule of ATP hydrolyzed.

It is an electrogenic pump. It has a coupling ratio of 3:2. It is found in all parts of the body. Its activity is inhibited by ouabain and related digitalis glycosides.

β subunit:

  • 3 extracellular glycosyl­ation sites

α subunit:

  • Intracellular Na+ and ATP binding sites
  • Phosphorylation site
  • Extracel­lular binding sites for K+ and ouabain

When Na+ binds to the α subunit, ATP also binds and is converted to ADP. A phosphate is transferred to the phosphorylation site. This causes a change in the configuration of the protein, extruding Na+ into the ECF. K+ then binds extracellularly and there is dephosphorylation of the α subunit. The α subunit returns to its previ­ous conformation, releasing K+ into the cytoplasm.

questions.text: The technique of autopsy characterized by in situ dissection is:
questions.solution:
Rokitansky technique is characterised by ‘in situ’ dissection, in part, combined with removal of organ blocks.

Related Pearl: Autopsy Techniques

  • Virchow's technique: Organs are removed one by one from the body to be examined. Here the cranial cavity is opened first, then the spinal cord, followed by thoracic, cervical, and abdominal organs in that order.
  • Ghon's technique: Here the organs are removed 'en bloc'. The thoracic, cervical, pelvic, and abdominal organs are removed as organ blocks.
  • Rokitansky's technique: This is characterized by 'in situ' dissection in part combined with en bloc removal like Ghon's technique. The dissection begins at the neck and slowly works its way down the body and the organ is removed as a bloc. A cut is first made at the larynx to separate the esophagus from the pharynx. The larynx and trachea are pulled downward and using a scalpel, the chest organs are cut. The diaphragm is cut to expose the abdominal organs. Other organs like the bladder and rectum are separated from the body by using a scalpel to cut the pelvic ligaments.
  • Letulle's technique: Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed 'en masse' meaning as one big organ block. It allows the body to be made available for examination in less than 30 minutes as the process of removing the organs is much quicker.

questions.text: Blood stained nipple discharge is seen in _________.
questions.solution:
Types of Nipple discharge and causes:

  1. Discharge from the surface

a. Paget’s disease

b. Skin diseases (eczema, psoriasis)

     2. Discharge from a single duct

a. Blood-stained:

  • Intraductal papilloma
  • Intraductal carcinoma
  • Duct ectasia

b. Serous (any colour)

  • Fibrocystic disease
  • Duct ectasia
  • Carcinoma

       3. Discharge from more than one duct

a. Blood-stained

  • Carcinoma
  • Ectasia
  • Fibrocystic disease

b. Black or green

  • Duct ectasia

c. Purulent 

  • Infection

d. Serous

  • Fibrocystic disease
  • Duct ectasia
  • Carcinoma

e. Milk:

  • Lactation
  • Rare causes - hypothyroidism, pituitary tumour

Related Pearl: Important surgeries for breast cancer

  • Tylectomy: Excision of lump
  • Breast conservation surgery (BCS)/WLE (wide local excision): Tumour removal with a 3D clearance of a 1 mm margin of normal tissue
  • Simple mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast + Nipple–areola complex + overlying skin.
  • Extended simple mastectomy: Simple mastectomy + removal of level I axillary lymph nodes.
  • Skin-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope preservation and nipple-areola complex removal
  • Skin+ nipple/areola-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope and nipple-areola complex preservation
  • Total mastectomy: All breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin.
  • Level I oncoplasty (volume displacement surgery): Tumour excision with wide margins followed by defect repair via dual-plane mobilisation of the breast parenchyma to maintain shape and symmetry
  • Level II oncoplasty (volume replacement surgery): Skin excision and glandular mobilisation involving >20% resection of breast volume
  • Modified radical mastectomy:  Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + axillary lymph nodes (levels I + II ± III) dissection
    • Patey’s: Pectoralis minor is removed
    • Scanlon’s: Pectoralis minor incised
    • Auchincloss: Pectoralis minor only retracted
  • Halsted’s radical mastectomy: Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Levels I + II+ III Axillary lymph nodes + Pectoralis major and minor
  • Extended radical (Urban) - Halsted’s + internal mammary lymph nodes dissection
  • Extended radical (Dahl-Iverson) mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary and supraclavicular lymph nodes dissection
  • Super radical mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary, supraclavicular and mediastinal lymph nodes dissection.

*Dual-plane mobilisation of breast parenchyma: Mobilisation of the dermoglandular plane and plane between breast parenchyma and pectoralis muscle.

Related Pearl: TNM Staging of Carcinoma Breast

Note: LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) is considered a benign condition and not included under Tis.

Prefixes for TNM staging:

  • c: clinical staging (e.g. cT1b)
  • p: pathological (histological) staging
  • y: stage following systemic or radiation therapy (either prior to surgery or as a primary treatment)
  • r: staging at the time of retreatment or recurrence for disease progression

Suffix for TNM staging:

  • m: multiple primary tumours of the same histology in the same organ, e.g. T2(m) or T2(5), the latter meaning that there are five primary tumours

questions.text: A patient was brought into the emergency room by his friend with features of acute intoxication that are attributed to nicotine alkaloids derived from the plant shown below. What category of poisons does this fall under?
questions.solution:
Nicotine is a plant alkaloid derived from the Nicotiana tabacum plant shown in the image above. It is a cardiac poison.

All components of this plant are poisonous except its ripe seeds. Leaves of this plant contain toxic alkaloids, like nicotine, anabasine, nornicotine and lobeline. It is a cardiac poison that initially stimulates autonomic ganglia to produce symptoms of acute intoxication (tachycardia, bradycardia,  hypotension, tachypnea, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and headache). These symptoms later subside to give way to respiratory depression and collapse.

Other cardiac poisons are:

Digoxin is a cardiac poison derived from the roots, leaves, and seeds of the plant Digitalis purpurea (shown below). It acts to prolong the diastolic period of the cardiac muscle. Bradycardia, extrasystoles, ventricular tachycardia, and fibrillation are manifestations of toxicity. Ocular symptoms such as photopsia (colour changes), scotoma, and transient amblyopia can also be seen.

Aconite is a cardiac poison derived mainly from the root and root tubers of the plant Aconite napellus (shown below). Symptoms of intoxication are due to action on the voltage-gated sodium channels on the cell membrane of nerves, and skeletal and smooth muscles. Symptoms consist of intestinal (nausea, vomiting, perioral tingling and numbness, abdominal pain and diarrhoea), cardiovascular (chest pain, palpitations, hypotension, bradycardia), neurological (vertigo and restlessness), ocular (hippus - pupils alternately contract and dilate, diplopia and impaired vision.)

Aconite is an ideal homicidal poison - 

  • Cheap and easily available 
  • Lethal dose is small and short fatal period
  • Taste can be masked by giving it with betel leaves 
  • Cannot be detected by chemical analysis.
  • Also used as an abortifacient, cattle and arrow poison.

Thevetin is a cardiac poison derived from the plant Cerebra Thevetia (yellow oleander). All parts of the plant are poisonous. Symptoms of intoxication are characterized by vomiting, diarrhoea, headache, dizziness, mydriasis, and loss of muscular power. Cardiovascular signs include a weak and irregular pulse rate with hypotension. Possible complications are heart block and cardiorespiratory failure. 

Quinine - Derived from the bark of the Cinchona plant and it causes cinchonism due to repeated therapeutic exposures its symptoms are tinnitus, vertigo, deafness, scotoma, hypoglycemia and arrhythmias. 

Other options:

Option A: Spinal poisons- Strychnine (Strychnus nux vomica), gelsemium. Strychnine acts at the ventral horn by blocking the postganglionic glycine receptor sites in the spinal cord and brainstem. The blockade of these receptors by strychnine results in unopposed muscle contraction, resulting in the classical clinical features such as tonic-clonic seizures, opisthotonus (body arched in hyperextension) and risus sardonicus.

Option B: Deliriants -  Datura, belladonna, hyoscyamus, cannabis, cocaine.

Option C: Asphyxiants -  A toxic or non-toxic gas that causes respiratory embarrassment and leads to unconsciousness or death by asphyxiation. 

Asphyxiants can be classified into:

Asphyxiant Description Examples
Simple Asphyxiants Inert gases that displace oxygen
  • Noble gases
  • Carbon dioxide
  • Hydrocarbons
Chemical Asphyxiants Reduce the body's ability to absorb, transport or utilize oxygen
  • Carbon monoxide
  • Cyanide
  • Hydrogen sulphide
Irritant Asphyxiants Damage the respiratory tract
  • Ammonia
  • Formaldehyde
  • Methyl isocyanate
Systemic Asphyxiants Produce significant systemic toxicity by specialized mechanisms
  • Carbon monoxide
  • Cyanide

Related Pearl: Substances of abuse

Shows a biphasic pattern. 
Early stimulatory symptoms of vomiting, hypertension and tachycardia. Later depressive symptoms of hypotension and bradycardia.
Cannabis

Increased appetite, euphoria, conjunctival injection, dry mouth, panic, synesthesia, impaired time perception, amotivational syndrome, run amok and flashbacks.

Depressed mood, suicidal thoughts, unpleasant dreams
Acute: Sympathetic overactivity, paranoid hallucinatory syndrome, violent behavior, psychosis and diaphoresis.
Chronic: Runs & crashes, choreiform movements, tooth decay. Can resemble schizophrenia.

Acute: Sympathetic overactivity, agitation, euphoria, chest pain, seizures and mydriasis
Chronic: Cocaine psychosis (Magnan sign) and black pigmentation of the tongue.

Synesthesia, brisk tendon reflex, tachycardia, hypertension, panic, ataxia, visual hallucinations, euphoria and dysphoria.

Nothing significant 
Tachycardia, hypertension, ataxia, hallucinations, violent behavior, dissociation, amnesia and nystagmus.

  • Mnemonic: "hot as a hare, blind as a bat, dry as a bone, red as a beet, and mad as a hatter"
  • Also, remember the D's of Datura

    • Dilatation of pupils along with loss of accommodation

questions.text: The X-ray of a 10-year-old boy with fever, drooling of saliva, and stridor is shown below.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and thumb sign on the x-ray is acute epiglottitis.

Causative organisms are Streptococcus pyogenes, Streptococcus pneumoniae, H. influenzae, and Staphylococcus aureus.

Clinical features include high fever, sore throat, dyspnea, drooling, and progressing respiratory obstruction. Stridor appears late and indicates near-complete respiratory obstruction. Child sits in tripod position to relieve the obstruction.

Laryngoscopy shows large, cherry-red, swollen epiglottis. X-ray of lateral view of neck shows thumb sign. Management is to give antibiotics and emergency endotracheal intubation is done as required.

Other options:

Option-A: Retropharyngeal abscess is often polymicrobial caused by streptococcus, staphylococcus, and anaerobes. Clinical features include fever, drooling, neck stiffness, muffled voice, and trismus. Management is by giving intravenous antibiotics with or without surgical drainage.

Option-B: Laryngomalacia is a congenital anomaly presenting with inspiratory stridor which is low-pitched and exacerbated by crying or feeding. Symptoms usually appear within the first two weeks of life. Most symptoms resolve spontaneously as the child and airway grow.

Option C: Acute laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup) is a viral infection. Clinical features include low-grade fever, barking cough, inspiratory stridor, and hoarseness. Steeple sign is seen on the x-ray due to subglottic narrowing. If the child is hypoxic, immediate airway management is done.

Steeple sign in croup appears as in the image below:

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Unimmunized child, cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: CT number of lung parenchyma in inspiration is _______.
questions.solution:
CT number of lung parenchyma in inspiration is -1000 HU. Lung parenchyma in inspiration has a CT number similar to air.

On CT, each image consists of a matrix of data points (pixels) that are assigned a number that represents the X-ray attenuation(μ) at that point in the body.

CT number is a scaled version of μ that is normalised to the X-ray attenuation of water (μW) CT = 1000 × (μ/μW − 1).

The resulting numbers are called ‘Hounsfield units’(HU).

Due to this normalisation, and water is assigned 0 HU and air is assigned a CT number of −1000 HU.

The CT numbers of

  • Water = 0 HU
  • Solid soft tissues = 0 HU
  • Air = -1000 HU
  • Lungs = -1000 HU
  • Dense cortical bone = +1000 HU

questions.text: A patient presents to the ophthalmology OPD with a sudden, severe diminution of vision in his right eye. Relative afferent pupillary defect is present. What is the probable diagnosis in this patient with the fundoscopic findings shown below?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient is ischaemic central retinal vein occlusion.

The clinical vignette of a patient developing sudden, severe painless diminution of vision, with relative afferent pupillary defect and funduscopy of the eye showing massive retinal haemorrhages giving a splashed tomato appearance, are all suggestive of ischaemic central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO).

Other features of ischaemic CRVO on fundoscopy include numerous cotton wool spots - usually more than 6 to 10, disc showing oedema and hyperaemia, and the macular area is full of haemorrhages and is severely oedematous.

In later stages, the fundus shows marked sheathing around veins, with collaterals and neovascularization seen around and at the disc or periphery respectively.
Macula shows marked pigmentary changes and chronic cystoid oedema.

The complications include Rubeosis iridis, i.e. neovascularisation of iris and neovascular glaucoma occurs within 3 months and this is also called "90 days glaucoma".

Vitreous haemorrhage and proliferative retinopathy may also occur in a few cases. Treatment usually involves treating the underlying cause and complications.

Other options:
Option A: Non-ischaemic CRVO, also called venous stasis retinopathy, is characterised by sudden onset mild to moderate blurring of vision. Relative afferent pupillary defect is either absent or if present, mild. Pathognomonic features of ischaemic CRVO differentiating it from non-ischaemic CRVO are the presence of relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), visual field defects and reduced amplitude of b-wave on electroretinogram

Option C: Branched retinal vein occlusion is characterised by a sudden painless onset of blurred vision if the macula is involved, whereas peripheral occlusion is asymptomatic. Iris neovascularization and neovascular glaucoma are both less common in BRVO than in CRVO. On fundoscopy, dilatation and tortuosity of the affected venous segment is observed, with flame-shaped and dot/blot haemorrhages in the retinal area. Cotton wool spots and retinal edema may also be present.

Option D: Central retinal artery occlusion is characterised by sudden profound loss of vision, that is painless and visual acuity is severely reduced. Relative afferent pupillary defect is profound, giving rise to an amaurotic pupil and fundoscopy shows the presence of a cherry red spot at the region of the foveola. The peripapillary retina appears swollen and opaque.

questions.text: Cori's cycle is a link between _______.

choices.text: Aerobic Glycolysis and citric acid cycle

questions.solution:
Cori's cycle links gluconeogenesis and anareobic Glycolysis.  Cori’s cycle involves the synthesis of glucose in liver from the skeletal muscle lactate and  reuse of glucose synthesized by the muscle for energy purpose.

Glucose Alanine cycle is also known as Cahill Cycle.

Related Pearl: Transport of ammonia in blood (Cahill and Cori cycle)

questions.text: Which taste receptor has ligand-gated channels?
questions.solution:
Sour taste receptors are mediated through ligand-gated channels.

Taste Receptors

  • Humans have five established basic tastes: sweet, salt, sour, bitter and umami.
  • The taste receptors for these five basic tastes are of two major types:
    • Ligand-gated channels (ionotropic receptors): for salt and sour taste
    • G-Protein Coupled Receptors (metabotropic receptors): for sweet, bitter and umami
  • Salt and sour taste are mediated through epithelial sodium channels (ENaC)
    • Na+ movement through ENaC → salt taste
    • H+ movement through ENaC → sour taste
  • Sweet, bitter, and umami are sensed via GPCRs
    • T1R2 and T1R3 families→ sweet taste
    • T2R family → bitter taste
    • T1R1, T1R3, and Metabotropic glutamate receptor (mGluR4) → Umami

questions.text: A person who comes in contact with a case of coronavirus (COVID- 19)  needs to be followed up for __________.
questions.solution:
A person who comes in contact with a coronavirus(COVID-19) case (confirmed or probable) needs to be followed up for apperance of symptoms of coronavirus for the maximum incubation period of 14 days.

Treatment: There is no specific antiviral treatment recommended for COVID-19. People with COVID-19 should receive supportive care to help relieve symptoms. For severe cases, treatment should include care to support vital organ functions.

Basic protective measures against the new coronavirus: (SARS CoV 2)

  • Wash your hands frequently for atleast 20 seconds.
  • Maintain social distancing- Maintain at least 1 metre distance between yourself and anyone who is coughing or sneezing
  • Avoid touching eyes, nose and mouth
  • Practice respiratory hygiene- cover your mouth and nose with your bent elbow or tissue when you cough or sneeze, then dispose of the used tissue immediately.
  • If you have fever, cough and difficulty breathing, seek medical care early
  • Stay informed and follow advice given by your healthcare provider

Old age, Neutrophilia, Increased lactate dehydrogenase and D-dimer levels has been recognised as a significant risk factor for the development of ARDS and death in patients with COVID19.

questions.text: As compared to Taenia solium, Taenia saginata has__________
questions.solution:
Taenia saginata has Unarmed scolex

Taenia saginata:

  • It is larger than taenia solium.
  • It has no role in neurocysticercosis. It causes only taeniasis.
  • It has 1000-2000 proglottids.

Related Pearl: Difference between T. solium and T. saginata

Properties

Taenia solium

Taenia saginata

Common name

Pork tapeworm

Beef tapeworm

Definitive host

Human

Human

Intermediate

host

Pig/Humans

Cow

 Disease 

Taeniasis and cysticercosis

Taeniasis only

Transmission

Infection is common among those eating raw or insufficiently cooked measly pork containing the cysticerci.

Human beings are infected through the eating of undercooked beef containing the cysticerci (“measly” beef)

Size of adult worm

2-3 m

5-10m

Scolex

The scolex head is globular in outline and has four circular suckers.

The head is provided with the rostellum armed with double row of alternating large and small hooklets. The rostellar hooklets are shaped like daggers or Arabian poniards (armed scolex)

The scolex (“head”) is quadrate in outline and has four circular suckers.

Rostellum and hooklets are absent (i.e. unarmed scolex)

 Proglottid 

Less than 1000 proglottids are present.

The gravid uterus consists of a median longitudinal stem with 5-13 compound lateral branches on each side

The gravid segments are expelled passively, in chains of 5-6 at a time, and not singly.

T. solium may produce 50,000 eggs per proglottid.

The number of proglottids varies from 1000- 2000.

The gravid uterus consists of a central longitudinal stem with 15-30 lateral branches on each side; these in turn sub-branch leaving practically no space in between.

The gravid segments are expelled singly T. saginata may produce up to 100,000 eggs per proglottid.

 Eggs 

The eggs are about 30-35 micrometers in diameter and are bile stained.

The internal oncosphere contains six refractile hooks.

The eggs do not float in the saturated solution of NaCl.

T.solium and T. saginata eggs are morphologically indistinguishable.

Same as T. solium.

Taenia solium and Taenia saginata eggs are morphologically indistinguishable.

 Eggs (Infectious nature)

Infectious to humans (Human who ingested food contaminated with the egg of Taenia solium may develop cysticercosis)

Eggs of Taenia saginata are not infectious. Humans who ingest T. saginata eggs do not develop cysticercosis.
